story:
I'm going to Qatar for the UN climate change negotiations. Youth have one of the most powerful moral voices on climate change, and we need to be at the conference to make sure it is heard. I need to raise $5000 to pay for the trip, including buying resources like paint and cardboard, mirrors and internet data for actions at the conference. I am hoping to raise $500 from family and friends.

I would really appreciate it if you could chip in as much or as little as you can.

Your donations will go towards strengthening the youth voice on climate change both at the conference and around the world. We will be holding creative actions, making speeches, meeting with other delegations, non-government organisations and negotiators to try and get Australia to sign on to the second phase of the Kyoto Protocol. We will also be capacity building the youth climate movement around the world, by facilitating at two trainings for youth climate activists from across the world. 

My total fundraising goal is $5000, and I am sourcing these funds from my university, corporate sponsors, and my own savings. This budget covers flights, accomodation, and costs in country, and is based on previous years' delegations to the UNFCCC conferences. 

As a youth delegation, we will play an important role is pressuring the Australian negotiators to sign on to the second phase of the Kyoto protocol. The current Kyoto Protocol runs out at the end of this year, and there is no legally binding agreement to take over. While there is an 'agreement to agree' on a new, legally based agreement by 2015 to come into force in 2020, we need strong action now on the most important moral, social, and economic issue of our time. As Cristiana Figueres, executive secretary of the UNFCCC said, "There is no 'Plan B', becuase we don't have a Planet B". 

We're planning a big campaign for the weeks before the conference, so if you can't chip in but want to help, make sure you keep an eye out for it!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Duquesne Fednard and I am from Haiti. Four years ago I set up D&E Green Enterprises to help tackle some of the big problems facing my country.

My company has developed a  efficient charcoal cooking stove called the EcoRecho. The EcoRecho uses 50 per cent less charcoal than traditional Haitian cooking stoves. Our stove saves families money on fuel, leaving more to spend on food and education. We believe the EcoRecho can make a real difference to lives and the environment in Haiti.

Our first stove factory was destroyed in the 2010 Haiti earthquake. Since then we have been making our stoves in tents, and those tents were recently damaged by Hurricane Sandy.  Thus far, we have produced more than 33,000 by hand.


 

What We Need & What You Get

Our immediate goal is raise at least US $60,000 to rebuild the factory and get into full production so that we can make the maximum difference in Haiti. With your involvement, we will move from this shredded tent to a factory similar to the picture below.

In return for your generous contribution you'll be able to visit the project, experience Haiti through its arts and crafts and even be a part of a spcecial advisory board for the project. 

 

Impact

A majority of the three billion people in developing countries cook almost exclusively with wood and charcoal, which is also the primary cooking fuel in Haiti. Though cheap to purchase, these fuels have high hidden costs.

Health impact

“EcoRecho significantly reduces the indoor air pollution caused by burning charcoal "

The Indoor Air Pollution (IAP) caused by burning charcoal can lead to chronic, even fatal, respiratory diseases. It has been estimated that the average life span in Haiti is shortened by 6.6 years due to the impact of indoor air pollution caused by indoor burning of biomasses such as charcoal. Acute Lower Respiratory Illness (ALRI), the number one global killer of children under five years of age is also the number one killer of under-fives in Haiti, with ALRI mortality estimated to be over 11%.

Environmental impact

“EcoRecho has been shown to reduce charcoal consumption by at least 50%”

Charcoal is made from trees. Charcoal making is therefore highly detrimental to Haiti’s landscape, farming, and overall economic status. On average 0.1 hectare of forest is required to produce 1 ton of charcoal.

Tree cover in Haiti has fallen from 63% in 1923 to 1.5% of total land today. Rapid deforestation has led to soil erosion and severe flooding, thus affecting agricultural yields and spurring more people to leave the rural areas and move into already overcrowded cities. 


Economic impact

“A successful adoption of the stove would translate into cash savings of US$150 per year for a family”

The cost of cooking fuel is quite high in Haiti; typically a poor family spends about 23% of its income on cooking fuel. Several factors explain the high cost of cooking fuel in Haiti.

● First, there are many middlemen and distributors that cause a spike in the price of cooking fuel. 
● Finally, rapid urban growth has radically increased the demand for domestic fuels because charcoal is consumed mostly in cities. 

The recent earthquake in Haiti has devastated and laid bare its already fragile infrastructure. Unemployment is consequently rising and will further diminish the purchasing power of the population, creating a greater demand for Haiti's most accessible fuel.



Solution

Transforming the stoves market in Haiti by encouraging Haitian consumers to buy efficient charcoal stoves. If consumers replaced conventional charcoal stoves with efficient charcoal stoves in Haiti, deforestation will decrease, the health of users will improve and family and community spending on energy will decrease.

We need your help to rebuild our factory and bring EcoRechos to the Haitian market place! By doing so, you are contributing to economic and environmental renaissance of Haiti.

Your contribution will not only help Haiti escape the energy poverty cycle but will also help create at least 400 jobs through direct employment, distribution chain development and construction work while contributing to lowering carbon emissions and protecting the environment .

Recognitions and Awards:

Over the past three years, D& E has received recognition for bringing clean and efficient stoves to the Haitian market from institutions that include:

 

 

D&E is also a proud member of the Clinton Global Initiative (CGI), the UN Sustainable Energy for All initiative and the Clean Stove Alliance.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us by spreading the word about this campaign on  Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter and by inviting friends and family to contribute and support us. You can share this campaign with your network by using Indiegogo share tools.

You can also help us by spreading the word about this campaign on  Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter and by inviting friends and family to contribute and support us. You can share this campaign with your network by using Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Sounds of the Northern Wild

Sounds of the Northern Wild is a half-hour documentary about the first expedition of The Arctic Soundscape Project. It shows Dr. Bernie Krause and his team recording nature sounds in a remote and unspoiled land. This movie will open viewers' ears, as well as their eyes and minds, to the resonant beauty of nature.

Before publishing his newest book The Great Animal Orchestra , or his giving his popular TED Talk with over 350,000 views [see below], Bernie Krause led a team of expert field recordists to the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for a bioacoustic study, the first of its kind, in that extraordinary place. There they captured the song of the waters, the music of the hills, the calls and cries of wildlife.

With the money raised by this campaign, we will be able to finish the production of the film using the existing footage shot on that expedition, have it broadcast on PBS, and distribute it to educational markets. This film will raise awareness of the sounds of nature that we are losing at an unprecedented pace.



“...In undisturbed natural environments, creatures vocalize in relationship to one another very much like instruments in an orchestra. On land, in particular, this delicate acoustic fabric is almost as well-defined as the notes on a page of music…” -Bernie Krause


What We Need & What You Get

Our budget is broken down specifically for every task needed to finish the film from editing to DVD production. Our team of filmmakers is well versed in every aspect of production and distribution.

For donations at every level, we have wonderful perks. For just a few dollars, you can access sounds from Wild Sanctuary, Bernie’s unique catalogue of sound recordings.  Other rewards for your contributions include books, DVDs, and special invitations, on up to executive producer credit in the film.

"Forty years travelling the world to record more than 15,000 species have given Krause a rare insight into the importance of 'biophony'." -Nature


The Impact

With your help, we will be able to show that careful listening can give us a new perspective on the natural world and on the impact of human activities on the voices of nature. Hearing has survival value. Our eyes shut; our ears are always open.  Listening reveals the health of the life around us, from wildlands to rural areas to urban parks and perches.

"If a picture is worth a thousand words, what is a sound recording worth? Perhaps much more... We say we want peace and quiet, but Bernie knows better. What we really want is something worth listening to. There is plenty of it out there. Nobody knows how to find it better than Bernie Krause." -Jean Michel Cousteau


Educational Use

Soundscapes are available in the archives of Bernie Krause and his colleagues and in nature sound libraries at various universities. As Sounds of the Northern Wild becomes accessible via broadcasts, webcasts, DVD screenings, film festivals and educational venues, the public will become aware of the wealth of nature sounds within these archives and of their importance.

As this film tells the story of a singular soundscape expedition in the Arctic, it models the use of audio equipment in a natural setting, demonstrating for students and other viewers the methods and ethics of nature sound recording that apply to the work of professional and citizen scientists everywhere. Besides inspiring the kind of listening that counteracts civilization's nature deficit disorder, recording geophonic and biophonic sounds offers science, art, and eco-outreach an important form of data collection and investigation. Soundscapes recorded in the same places at different times of year, as well as from year to year, mark changes in climatic patterns and species behavior over time. Such phenological data tracks, for example, the migration northward of bird species into biomes where they have never been heard before—changes due to human impact, climate disturbance, and other factors.


The Filmmakers

Our award-winning filmmakers have extensive experience making documentaries about wide ranging topics and issues of our time.

Robert Hillmann, who led the video production team on the Arctic Soundscape Project, is the director of Sounds of the Northern Wild. He conceived and directed Hidden Hawaii, a 70mm IMAX film exploring how the most remote and isolated ecosystem on earth evolved uniquely until man and modern transportation introduced overwhelming challenges. His films have been shown and honored at many international film festivals including Cannes, New York, Telluride, Toronto, Melbourne, Rotterdam, Los Angeles, and Mannheim. He directed and produced Fire on the Water, winning Best Feature Documentary U.S./Park City Sundance, the Blue Ribbon First Prize in New York at the National Educational Film Festival as well as three national network EMMY nominations. He directed the Academy Award-nominated feature documentary Waldo Salt: A Screenwriter's Journey, broadcast on PBS American Masters. He has been awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship and been a member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for twenty years.

Stephen Most, the writer/producer of Sounds of the Northern Wild, has worked as screenwriter or contributing writer on four Academy Award-nominated films, including Berkeley in the Sixties and Promises, and he is the screenwriter of five Emmy-winning documentaries, including Wonders of Nature and Green Fire: Aldo Leopold and a Land Ethic for Our Time. The documentary River of Renewal, which he wrote and produced, won the Best Documentary Award at the American Indian Film Festival. He is the author of River of Renewal, Myth and History in the Klamath Basin, published by the University of Washington Press.

Steve Michelson, the Executive Producer, has been the Executive Producer of many award-winning documentary films, including Climb Against the Odds, Oil On Ice, Crude Impact, Burning the Future, River of Renewal, and Power Paths. He and partner Craig Malina founded Specialty Studios, which distributes films about the environment, social justice, and sustainability, and they acquired The Video Project, an educational distributor.

“Bernie Krause is, above all, an artist. I have watched him recording the calls of chimpanzees, the singing of the insects and birds, and seen his deep love for the harmonies of nature… He helps us to hear and appreciate the often hidden musicians in a new way. But he warns that these songs, an intrinsic part of the natural world and essential to human well being, are vanishing, one by one, snuffed out by human actions." -Jane Goodall


Broadcast and Distribution Strategy

Sounds of the Northern Wild is a perfect fit for the Natural Heroes series of the Sonoma County PBS station KRCB. That is especially the case in that Bernie Krause is a nature hero who lives there. Beyond broadcasting the documentary locally, KRCB can serve as a presenting station for the 300 PBS stations nationwide. The broadcast will be accompanied by a PR campaign seeking interviews and film from media outlets.

International broadcast markets will be approached through an international television distributor associated with Specialty Studios. There will be international interest, both because Bernie Krause is well-known worldwide as a leader in his field and because he has recorded nature sounds in many countries around the globe.

In addition to broadcasts, the documentary will reach the public through local screenings and DVD distribution. The film will have two distributors: Specialty Studios and The Video Project, a distributor of educational films. An enhanced DVD will be created for classroom use with extended interviews, a special study guide, and technical advice for nature sound recording. Additionally, the film will be available on digital platforms for classroom use and viewing.The home video version of the program will be released on DVD. Later the film will be shown on cable channels, followed by availability on cable VOD and Netflix, as well as online for digital download through Hulu and Snagfilms.

Sounds of the Northern Wild will appear in film festivals around the world. These provide occasions for public appearances and interviews that increase awareness of the film and its purposes.

“Bernie's research into the subtleties of animal and insect sounds is unparalleled, but it is his description of the radical changes that are taking place on this planet that really makes one stop and wonder... Listen carefully, for the sounds you hear may never be the same again." -Sir George Martin


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign with your friends and colleagues! IndieGoGo has provided tools to help us get the word out about our film.

Watch and share the TED Talk about Bernie Krause’s work:http://www.ted.com/talks/bernie_krause_the_voice_of_the_natural_world.html

Like our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Sounds-of-the-Northern-Wild/544961372238926

Take a peek at Wild Sanctuary, Dr. Krause’s organization:http://www.wildsanctuary.com/

Read Dr. Krause’s new book, The Great Animal Orchestra. http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/15/books/review/the-great-animal-orchestra-by-bernie-krause.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0

story:
Bikes, Bees & ButterfliesTMConcept:

Woven with the thread of urban sustainability, Bikes, Bees & Butterflies engages local artists and communities to vibrantly re-imagine the form and function of discarded bicycles, upcycling them as an ingenious, high visual impact framework to create urban habitats for pollinators while encouraging bicycling. Bicycle baskets planted with native plants used as a food source by pollinators will be attached to each bike to highlight the critical importance of pollinators in our food production, economy and a healthy ecosystem. In partnership with local and national organizations, educational programs will be developed that connect the community to biodiversity focusing on pollination ecology in the urban environment.

Goals: We will…

1.  Obtain recycled and reclaimed bicycles from local bike shops and organizations as a donation. Local artists will design, re-imagine and transform bicycles into public art installations that convey the importance of urban sustainability, biking and creating urban habitats for pollinators.  Each bicycle will be uniquely designed and promote the artist’s artistic style.

2.  Use native plants that will create a beautiful and ideal habitat for bees, butterflies and other pollinators. The plants used on this project will naturally form sustainable pollinator habitats that stimulate and rejuvenate the pollination process. Our efforts in this project will help to counteract the challenges of pollinator habitat loss and degradation in urban areas.

3.  Invite local organizations to partner in developing educational programs that will inform the public about the vital importance of pollinators in our economy, increase the visual impact of  bicycles and connect the community to the purpose of the Bikes, Bees & Butterflies project.

4.  Create spaces in which people will be comfortable, strengthen neighborhood connections, promote physical activity, help people understand the importance of pollinator habitats and encourage an educated, culturally vibrant environment.

Who are the Idea Makers creating this project?

Staffing/Administration:

Ann Cicarella, principal of Ann Cicarella Landscape Design LLC,  is a nationally recognized landscape designer with 25 years experience in the field. Ann’s passion for urban sustainability, fostering healthy habitats for pollinators and people, creating beautiful gardens; and bicycling inspired the Bikes, Bees and Butterflies initiative.  Ann will be leading and supervising the execution of the project.

Stephanie Clements has over 5 years of planning and development experience in the nonprofit sector. Stephanie is a passionate Project Specialist bringing ideas and people together. Stephanie conceptualized and implemented the emotionally provocative Art Interprets Alzheimers exhibition, which continues to travel to various hospitals and galleries in Northeast Ohio.

The facts about urban sustainability, pollinators and public art:

·  What is Urban Sustainability?

o  A sustainable city or sustainable landscapes are cities designed with consideration of environmental impact; sequestering carbon, clean the air and water, increase energy efficiency, restore habitats, and create value through significant economic, social and, environmental benefits. Citizens within sustainable urban areas are dedicated to managing resources in a way that guarantees welfare and promotes equity of current and future generations.

·  What are pollinators and why are they important?

o  Pollinators are vertebrate and invertebrate animals such as bees, butterflies, moths, beetles, hummingbirds and bats. Pollination is the movement or transfer of pollen/nectar between flowering plants that leads to plant reproduction. Stephen Buchman and Gary Nabhan wrote, “The process of pollination keeps the verdant world, known as the biosphere, running in endless cycles…The intrafloral commerce by birds and bees is what makes the world go round on its cycle.”

o  Bees and other pollinators provide a service to the ecosystem through pollination, soil nutrition, and carbon sequestration.

·  Why is the Bikes, Bees, Butterflies Project Important?

a.  Pollinators (specifically bees) pollinate $15 billion worth of crops each year in the United States alone.

b.  Pollinators (specifically bees) have globally been declining by 25% over the past 15 years. Pollinator diversity and populations have dwindled primarily due to threatening components such as habitat loss and pesticides.

c.  The global economic cost of bees declining (lower crop yields combined with higher costs of production) has been estimated as high as $5.7 billion annually.

d.  Annually bees pollinate about 150 crops in just the United States. Here are some of the crops that would disappear without bees:

Apples, almonds, blueberries, cherries,

Avocados, cucumbers, onions, grapefruit, oranges and pumpkins.

e.  88% of the world’s plants rely on pollinators for fertilization and plant reproduction.

f.  Three quarters of food consumed are fruits, nuts, vegetables and herbs. Almost all grains, nuts, fruits and some vegetables and herbs require pollination to reproduce. One third of all the food we eat is pollinated by bees.

·  How will public art help improve public spaces?

o  Cities gain value through public art – cultural, social, and economic value. Public art is a distinguishing part of our public history and our evolving culture. It reflects and reveals our society, adds meaning to our cities and uniqueness to our communities. Public art humanizes the built environment and invigorates public spaces. It provides an intersection between past, present and future, between disciplines, and between ideas. Public art is freely accessible. Public art shows that residents have an interest in their city—their blocks, neighborhoods, streets and fellow citizens.

o  Upcycled Art is the process of converting salvaged materials into new products of better quality or for better environmental value. It can be anything from an art installation to a temporary “action” or advocacy campaign to engage, educate and incite public involvement to repairing neighborhoods. The goal is to get people to care about their city.

Project Benefits:

1.  Cultural- We plan to fulfill a cultural need by igniting creativity, encouraging and supporting public art and local artists, promoting education of the importance of pollinators and pollination in every aspect of life.

2.  Social- The installations will serve as pollinator gardens/habitats that will help to increase the pollination process in challenging urban areas. As a result, pollinators will naturally help to serve the ecosystem and increase the production of foods, fibers and raw materials that improve our quality of life.

3.  Economic- The estimated annual agricultural benefit of all types of pollinators in the United States is $15 billion. Bees alone are responsible for the pollination of $150 million in honey generated annually. At a local level providing pop-up pollinator environments will bring attention to the importance of biodiversity throughout the city and have a positive effect on the economy of urban gardening  surrounding areas.

4.  Ecological- During pollination, a critical transfer of genetic material takes place between bees and the reproductive system of flowering plants. This process causes vegetables, fruits, nuts, oils, fibers and raw materials to blossom, and increases carbon sequestration. Artistically recycling bicycles to assist in the pollination process services a vital interaction between bees and flowering plants. 

As a Bikes, Bees & ButterfliesTMSupporter, your donation assists with the costs of this public art project that nurtures urban sustainability, increases pollinator habitats, supports the arts, encourages bike activism and promotes economic prosperity and environmental quality. Costs include:

·  Artist Designed Bicycles

·  Stipends for Artists

·  Signage & Publicity

·  Pollinator Plants

·  Bicycle Baskets

·  Installation Materials

·  Project Administration Fees

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow us on Facebook! 

https://www.facebook.com/bikesbeesandbutterflies?ref=hl
story_txt:
Bikes,
Bees & ButterfliesTMConcept: 
Woven
with the thread of urban sustainability, Bikes, Bees & Butterflies engages
local artists and communities to vibrantly re-imagine the form and function of
discarded bicycles, upcycling them as an ingenious, high visual impact
framework to create urban habitats for pollinators while encouraging bicycling.
Bicycle baskets planted with native plants used as a food source by pollinators
will be attached to each bike to highlight the critical importance of
pollinators in our food production, economy and a healthy ecosystem. In
partnership with local and national organizations, educational programs will be
developed that connect the community to biodiversity focusing on pollination
ecology in the urban environment.
Goals:
We will… 

1.  Obtain recycled and reclaimed bicycles
from local bike shops and organizations as a donation. Local artists will
design, re-imagine and transform bicycles into public art installations that
convey the importance of urban sustainability, biking and creating urban
habitats for pollinators.  Each bicycle
will be uniquely designed and promote the artist’s artistic style.

2.  Use native plants that will create a
beautiful and ideal habitat for bees, butterflies and other pollinators. The
plants used on this project will naturally form sustainable pollinator habitats
that stimulate and rejuvenate the pollination process. Our efforts in this
project will help to counteract the challenges of pollinator habitat loss and
degradation in urban areas.

3.  Invite local organizations to partner
in developing educational programs that will inform the public about the vital
importance of pollinators in our economy, increase the visual impact of  bicycles and connect the community to the
purpose of the Bikes, Bees & Butterflies project.

4.  Create spaces in which people will be
comfortable, strengthen neighborhood connections, promote physical activity,
help people understand the importance of pollinator habitats and encourage an
educated, culturally vibrant environment.

Who
are the Idea Makers creating this project?


Staffing/Administration:


Ann Cicarella,
principal of Ann Cicarella Landscape Design LLC,  is
a nationally recognized landscape designer with 25 years experience in the
field. Ann’s passion for urban sustainability, fostering healthy habitats for
pollinators and people, creating beautiful gardens; and bicycling inspired the
Bikes, Bees and Butterflies initiative.  Ann will be leading and supervising the
execution of the project.

 
 
Stephanie Clements has
over 5 years of planning and development experience in the nonprofit sector.
Stephanie is a passionate Project Specialist bringing ideas and people
together. Stephanie conceptualized and implemented the emotionally provocative Art Interprets Alzheimers exhibition, which continues to travel to various
hospitals and galleries in Northeast Ohio.

The
facts about urban sustainability, pollinators and public art: 

· 
What is Urban Sustainability?

o 
A sustainable city or sustainable
landscapes are cities designed with consideration
of environmental impact; sequestering carbon, clean the air and water,
increase energy efficiency, restore habitats, and create value through
significant economic, social and, environmental benefits. Citizens within
sustainable urban areas are dedicated to managing
resources in a way that guarantees welfare and promotes equity of current and
future generations. 

· 
What are pollinators and why are they
important?

o 
Pollinators
are vertebrate and invertebrate animals such as bees, butterflies, moths,
beetles, hummingbirds and bats. Pollination is the movement or transfer of
pollen/nectar between flowering plants that leads to plant reproduction.
Stephen Buchman and Gary Nabhan wrote, “The
process of pollination keeps the
verdant world, known as the biosphere, running in endless cycles…The
intrafloral commerce by birds and bees is what makes the world go round on its
cycle.”

o 
Bees
and other pollinators provide a service to the ecosystem through pollination,
soil nutrition, and carbon sequestration.
· 
Why is the Bikes, Bees, Butterflies
Project Important?


a. 
Pollinators
(specifically bees) pollinate $15 billion worth of crops each year in the
United States alone.

b.  Pollinators (specifically bees) have
globally been declining by 25% over the past 15 years. Pollinator diversity and
populations have dwindled primarily due to threatening components such as

estimated as high as $5.7 billion annually.
d.  Annually bees pollinate about 150
crops in just the United States. Here are some of the crops that would

Apples, almonds, blueberries,
cherries,

grapefruit, oranges and pumpkins.

e.  88% of the world’s plants rely on
pollinators for fertilization and plant reproduction. 

f.  Three quarters of food consumed are
fruits, nuts, vegetables and herbs. Almost all grains, nuts, fruits and some
vegetables and herbs require pollination to reproduce. One third of all the food we eat is pollinated by bees. 

·

public spaces?

story:
*** Project Update 7/2/2013***

Bayou Saint John wetland project is underway!
Many thanks to all who contributed to our online campaign. The money raised will be an important part of the site’s development. As the project progresses we will decide how the $1,700 will be used. It will likely be for tangible additions to the site such as signage, benches or other improvements.

As of July 1st we have constructed half of the eastern retaining wall, and have worked out our construction process. We have a core crew and are seeking volunteers to help fill and handle sand bags for the next few weeks.

We’ll be working most days from 8 am to noon. Our main volunteer days will be on Fri 7/5, Sat 7/6, Tues 7/9, Thurs 7/10 and Sat 7/13. Inquire about work on other days.
To sign up, email saintjohnwetland@gmail.com

 

*************

Introduction:

The Lake Pontchartrain Basin Foundation (LPBF) is excited to announce the Bayou Saint John Wetland Creation Project, a once-in-a-lifetime chance to build ½ acre of native marsh in the city of New Orleans. LPBF is a non-profit group that has been working for southeast Louisiana’s people and environment since 1989 under the banner, “Save Our Lake, Save Our Coast.” http://saveourlake.org

We came up with the plan to build wetlands as an add-on to a dredging project that was already scheduled for this spring. This opportunity came up quickly, and we have scrambled to draft plans, secure permits, and find partners before construction starts in mid-May 2013.

We are reaching out to everyone who loves New Orleans and cares about the vanishing Louisiana coast. Together we can rebuild a patch native habitat and bring some nature back to the Big Easy.

To learn more about the project, visit:  http://saveourlake.org/PDF-documents/our-coast/BSJ/BSJ-Wetland-Project-May2013.pdf

Email saintjohnwetland@gmail.com with questions or comments.

What we need:

We feel so strongly about this project that we committed to it without having all funding in place. We are raising money to cover construction costs, and then to fund ongoing maintenance and monitoring. If we raise more than we need for immediate costs, we will do more scientific research and add signage, wildlife viewing access and other improvements. Our ultimate goal is to make the Bayou St. John marsh a destination for education, recreation, bird watching and fishing.

This project will give lots of benefit for relatively low cost. Since it piggybacks on an existing dredge project, the earth moving is free.  Construction uses all local materials and new technology that is cheaper and more environmentally friendly than traditional methods. Several partners are providing material and technical support, including the Louisiana Dept. of Wildlife and Fisheries and the Restore the Earth Foundation.

Why are we so excited about this project?

Building wetlands where there is now a concrete wall will benefit the local wildlife, the city’s residents and visitors, and the imperiled Louisiana coast.

  • Improves aquatic habitat for fish, crab and waterfowl.
  • Traps sediment and improves water quality.
  • Protects adjacent bulkhead and levee.
  • Enhances the historic urban waterway and the Lafitte Corridor.
  • Provides a living classroom and wildlife viewing in an urban area.
  • Demonstrates new nature-based technologies that can help restore the Louisiana coast.

 Every dollar donated will go directly into constructing, maintaining and enhancing these wetlands, and then studying them scientifically and developing them as a resource. This is an opportunity to help build something tangible that you can visit to experience nature in the city. The habitat you help build will support more birds for you to see and fish for you to catch.  

Please consider helping build the Bayou Saint John wetlands. Tell everyone who loves New Orleans about this opportunity to restore its environment and support its culture.

Partners:

http://www.restoretheearth.org/

http://emsgreen.com/

http://www.wlf.louisiana.gov/

http://saveourlake.org

story:
Aim

Through continued research into bats and modern roofing membranes I aim to develop remedial measures, educational tools and knowledge to help provide bat workers and roofers with resolutions for current problems. 

About the Bats and BRMs project

Bats constitute an important component of urban biodiversity and several species in the UK are highly dependent on buildings, making them particularly vulnerable to anthropogenic and environmental changes. Many buildings suitable for use as bat roosts often require re-roofing as they age and traditional bituminous roofing felts are frequently being replaced with breathable roofing membranes (BRMs). Building regulations require all construction materials be fit for purpose, however, in the UK new building regulations and modern materials may substantially reduce the viability of existing and the potential of future roosts.


In 2009 this research was established following reports of bats dying after becoming entangled in filaments that had been pulled loose from the surface of BRMs. Subsequent reports revealed these were not isolated occurrences and suggested that both bats and BRMs may experience problems when the two interact.
This contributes knowledge on the risk of entanglement when BRMs are fitted into bat roosts, the effects bats may have on BRM longevity and functionality and the influence underlay type may have on microclimatic conditions within a roof void.


The original project determined what the problems are.....I am now hoping to find the solutions.
That is what I am aiming to do next.

Why am I crowdfunding?

The original project was set up as a collaboration between the University of Reading and the Bat Conservation Trust. Funding was obtained through a PhD stipend. However, this funding ran out at the end of 2013 and the current economic climate makes finding research funding difficult for any subject......let alone a strange combination of ecology and engineering.

Yet this interdisciplinary research will make a real impact on Bat Conservation, not only in the UK, but throughout Europe. Many people working within the bat and roofing community agree, so I want to ask for your help to continue this research.

In doing this I will get everyone affected by this problem working together to create sensible and usable solutions.

Many people have asked why the manufacturers don't fund this work...I have written a short blog about it here: http://www.batsandbrms.co.uk/updates/crowdfundi... 

What is the money for?

The minimum target amount I have set is for £20,000. This is a large amount of money, yet in terms of research projects it is very small. This money will help with several things -

• University fees- In order to use the laboratory spaces and facilities needed for some of the technical aspects of this research I will need to use equipment based at Reading and Leeds Universities. This includes material testing machines, electron microscopes and environmental chambers.

 • Travel costs - Going to sites in order to see where problems have occurred, visiting manufacturers, meeting with stakeholders, training events, workshops.....you get it, there's a lot of travel.

 • Equipment - often to test materials you have to destroy them. This means I need to buy in the products in order to see how bat friendly they are. Also to develop remedial measures we need to try different things to see which works best....often in-situ.

 • Website Upgrade - at present I pay for the website myself and it has done quite well for 4 years. But now I want to include more information, more images, videos and a searchable product database. This will require a much fancier website and the money raised will help achieve that.

The aim is that this money will help this project continue for another 2 years. The money raised will be primarily used to help develop remedial measures for roosts where these problems have already occurred. It will also be used to help investigate alternative products to help prevent this occurring in the future.

The other area the money will provide support is the production of educational tools. This will include an upgraded website with more information, image galleries for use and information. It will also aid the production of academic papers to increase the integrity of the scientific research, a booklet on bats in roofs for both ecologists and roofers and collaborative projects between industry and conservation. These projects may lead to further projects looking at producing bat friendly roofing membranes.

In this time I aim to achieve most of the objectives stated in the video. The amount to be raised is really the minimum needed, so any money raised over that amount will only further the potential of this research and my ability to complete it.

To give you a very brief idea of costs -

• a single day in a materials testing lab will cost around £400

• an hour using an Electron Microscope costs £30

• A roll of BRM costs between £50 - £200

• A custom-made panel to test a remedial measure in-situ ~ £500 (including fitting, travel and materials)

• To upgrade the website and run it for two years will cost approximately £600

Testimonials - (Why others think it's important!)

Steve Parker, Bat Conservation Trust Trustee and Trainer for South Lancashire Bat Group

The Bats and Breathable Roofing Membranes study has shone a spotlight on the risks of BRM’s to bats. It’s vital that the study continues, in order to increase knowledge of this conservation threat, to develop best practices and guidelines, hopefully leading to materials which are both effective whilst posing no risk to bat populations.

Daniel Whitby, AEWC Ltd

Every so often human ingenuity invents a new useful, beneficial and apparently harmless product. Only after time does it become apparent that there is some previously unforeseen issue with negative consequences, all too often with the negative impact affecting wildlife or environment. Work conducted in recent years has shown how bats interacting with modern breathable roofing membranes can result in entrapment and death of individuals, sometimes in notable numbers, for a product that initially was not considered a risk. BRMs are now incorporated into the roofing of 100,000s of buildings throughout the UK and more in Europe and the instillation of these ticking time bombs are continuing.

Although the chance of any BRM in any building trapping bats in any one year is low, even if only a small percentage of these roofs trap a bat with the huge numbers of membranes fitted and their 50 year lifespan this will result in worryingly high numbers of bats being killed, potentially adding up to percentages of the known population. In many cases any potential issues may not be for over a decade, but, given what we have learned about these products and potential to kill bats roosting on them this is an issue that needs addressing now before we lose massive populations of these species and look back, when it is too late, asking why we didn’t do more when we first knew there was a problem.

Bridget Parslow, Bat Carer Extraordinaire for Berks and South Bucks Bat Group

Dr Stacey Waring's PhD research went a long way to demonstrating the serious problems bats and breathable membranes cause each other when they are in the same roof space. The next phase is to try to find an alternative product which will have the advantages of the BRM whilst not harming or being harmed by the resident bats and then to establish protocols and an education programme to encourage the use of this alternate.

Having done such a great job on the first phase, Stacey is in the best position to work on the rest of the project and I, for one, can't wait to see the outcome.

Cheryl Stansbury BSc (Hons) MA MRTPI GradCIEEM, Team Leader for Devon Local Planning Authority Department

With the exception of the brilliant work done by Stacey to date, as far as I am aware,there has been no research into the implications of using BRMs in bat roosts, both in terms of the impacts upon bats and the longevity/effectiveness of the BRMs. Until recently, most of us were not aware of the problems. Now we are becoming aware, the project needs further development to build on the valuable research done so far to look to develop bat friendly alternatives, remedial measures for roofs where BRMs are already in situ, provide education for roofers (and others) and to create and maintain a website to enable people to self serve/research. The project could also be developed to educate and provide literature. There is a lack of awareness, extending across a wide range of disciplines – planning, architecture, ecologists, builders, roofers, building control officers, and the like. The project is vital in getting the message spread to as wide an audience as possible. 

Through my work in planning, it is growing evident that the more traditional building skills, including the use of bitumen felt, are being lost; many builders have only worked with BRMs and are therefore reluctant to use the more traditional, bat friendly bitumen, and through my job, I am seeing more and more “solutions” to the problems with BRMs, many of which will not work from the longevity side (use of felt over the BRM) or in terms of being bat friendly (fit battens over the BR so the bats can grip onto it rather than the BRM). People are making up their own solutions because of the lack of information in the public realm. I’ve even been told that “It’s OK, we used the nice new membrane stuff that the bats like because they can grip onto it”!

Stacey is the only person currently doing this research and the funding is crucial to enable her to carry on devoting her time to the “cause”. The research carried out so far is making great advances in terms of bat conservation and construction, and it would be a real shame if it were not able to continue, for the project to build upon the initial work. I therefore fully endorse any funding application.

Rewards

Throughout the original research the aim has been to provide information and help with regards to bats and BRMs. As such many of the rewards are things that already happen. 

However, by supporting this project you will ensure that the research into how to solve these issues continues.The website will be upgraded to include searchable features, video blogs and more information. The enquiries I receive on a daily basis will continued to be answered (free of charge of course). I also plan to develop educational materials such as a booklet on 'bats for roofers and roofs for bat workers'. I will be working with roofers and the NFRC to produce this but also to help come up with 'in the meantime' solutions and remedial measures. This could be invaluable as we find more cases where BRMs have been fitted into roosts. 

The money will also enable me to gather much needed information about the size of this problem around Europe. Armed with this information I can start convincing manufacturers to take the problem seriously. This will then lead to collaboration with BRM producers to develop more bat friendly products. 

About Me

My name is Stacey Waring and I have been researching bats and BRMs for the past five years (wow where did the time go?). In fact technically I am the only person in the world to study this topic.....and yes its a very niche area but I think quite important. 

Whats different about me is that I cross multiple science disciplines such as ecology, zoology, engineering, materials science and physics. This means that I can talk to all the parties involved in this project and convey the information they need to know effectively. Because of this I have a wide network of companies and individuals who collaborate with this research. Hopefully, because of this I am in a great position to help solve some of the problems my research has brought to light.

FAQs

I have tried to preempt any questions in the sections above...but if I have missed anything feel free to ask away. I'll even add it here so others know the answer too.

This is a large amount of money, yet in terms of research projects it is very small. This money will help with several things -• University fees- In order to use the laboratory spaces and facilities needed for some of the technical aspects of this research I will need to use equipment based at Reading and Leeds Universities. This includes material testing machines, electron microscopes and environmental chambers. • Travel costs - Going to sites in order to see where problems have occurred, visiting manufacturers, meeting with stakeholders, training events, workshops.....you get it, there's a lot of travel. • Equipment - often to test materials you have to destroy them. This means I need to buy in the products in order to see how bat friendly they are. Also to develop remedial measures we need to try different things to see which works best....often in-situ. • Website Upgrade - at present I pay for the website myself and it has done quite well for 4 years. But now I want to include more information, more images, videos and a searchable product database. This will require a much fancier website and the money raised will help achieve that.The aim is that this money will help this project continue for another 2 years. The money raised will be primarily used to help develop remedial measures for roosts where these problems have already occurred. It will also be used to help investigate alternative products to help prevent this occurring in the future.The other area the money will provide support is the production of educational tools. This will include an upgraded website with more information, image galleries for use and information. It will also aid the production of academic papers to increase the integrity of the scientific research, a booklet on bats in roofs for both ecologists and roofers and collaborative projects between industry and conservation. These projects may lead to further projects looking at producing bat friendly roofing membranes.In this time I aim to achieve most of the objectives stated in the video. The amount to be raised is really the minimum needed, so any money raised over that amount will only further the potential of this research and my ability to complete it.To give you a very brief idea of costs -• a single day in a materials testing lab will cost around £400• an hour using an Electron Microscope costs £30• A roll of BRM costs between £50 - £200• A custom-made panel to test a remedial measure in-situ ~ £500 (including fitting, travel and materials)• To upgrade the website and run it for two years will cost approximately £600Testimonials - (Why others think it's important!)
Steve Parker, Bat Conservation Trust Trustee and Trainer for South Lancashire Bat GroupThe Bats and Breathable Roofing Membranes study has shone a spotlight on the risks of BRM’s to bats. It’s vital that the study continues, in order to increase knowledge of this conservation threat, to develop best practices and guidelines, hopefully leading to materials which are both effective whilst posing no risk to bat populations.Daniel Whitby, AEWC LtdEvery so often human ingenuity invents a new useful, beneficial and apparently harmless product. Only after time does it become apparent that there is some previously unforeseen issue with negative consequences, all too often with the negative impact affecting wildlife or environment. Work conducted in recent years has shown how bats interacting with modern breathable roofing membranes can result in entrapment and death of individuals, sometimes in notable numbers, for a product that initially was not considered a risk. BRMs are now incorporated into the roofing of 100,000s of buildings throughout the UK and more in Europe and the instillation of these ticking time bombs are continuing.Although the chance of any BRM in any building trapping bats in any one year is low, even if only a small percentage of these roofs trap a bat with the huge numbers of membranes fitted and their 50 year lifespan this will result in worryingly high numbers of bats being killed, potentially adding up to percentages of the known population. In many cases any potential issues may not be for over a decade, but, given what we have learned about these products and potential to kill bats roosting on them this is an issue that needs addressing now before we lose massive populations of these species and look back, when it is too late, asking why we didn’t do more when we first knew there was a problem.Bridget Parslow, Bat Carer Extraordinaire for Berks and South Bucks Bat GroupDr Stacey Waring's PhD research went a long way to demonstrating the serious problems bats and breathable membranes cause each other when they are in the same roof space. The next phase is to try to find an alternative product which will have the advantages of the BRM whilst not harming or being harmed by the resident bats and then to establish protocols and an education programme to encourage the use of this alternate.Having done such a great job on the first phase, Stacey is in the best position to work on the rest of the project and I, for one, can't wait to see the outcome.Cheryl Stansbury BSc (Hons) MA MRTPI GradCIEEM, Team Leader for Devon Local Planning Authority DepartmentWith the exception of the brilliant work done by Stacey to date, as far as I am aware,there has been no research into the implications of using BRMs in bat roosts, both in terms of the impacts upon bats and the longevity/effectiveness of the BRMs. Until recently, most of us were not aware of the problems. Now we are becoming aware, the project needs further development to build on the valuable research done so far to look to develop bat friendly alternatives, remedial measures for roofs where BRMs are already in situ, provide education for roofers (and others) and to create and maintain a website to enable people to self serve/research. The project could also be developed to educate and provide literature. There is a lack of awareness, extending across a wide range of disciplines – planning, architecture, ecologists, builders, roofers, building control officers, and the like. The project is vital in getting the message spread to as wide an audience as possible. Through my work in planning, it is growing evident that the more traditional building skills, including the use of bitumen felt, are being lost; many builders have only worked with BRMs and are therefore reluctant to use the more traditional, bat friendly bitumen, and through my job, I am seeing more and more “solutions” to the problems with BRMs, many of which will not work from the longevity side (use of felt over the BRM) or in terms of being bat friendly (fit battens over the BR so the bats can grip onto it rather than the BRM). People are making up their own solutions because of the lack of information in the public realm. I’ve even been told that “It’s OK, we used the nice new membrane stuff that the bats like because they can grip onto it”!Stacey is the only person currently doing this research and the funding is crucial to enable her to carry on devoting her time to the “cause”. The research carried out so far is making great advances in terms of bat conservation and construction, and it would be a real shame if it were not able to continue, for the project to build upon the initial work. I therefore fully endorse any funding application.RewardsThroughout the original research the aim has been to provide information and help with regards to bats and BRMs. As such many of the rewards are things that already happen. However, by supporting this project you will ensure that the research into how to solve these issues continues.The website will be upgraded to include searchable features, video blogs and more information. The enquiries I receive on a daily basis will continued to be answered (free of charge of course). I also plan to develop educational materials such as a booklet on 'bats for roofers and roofs for bat workers'. I will be working with roofers and the NFRC to produce this but also to help come up with 'in the meantime' solutions and remedial measures. This could be invaluable as we find more cases where BRMs have been fitted into roosts. The money will also enable me to gather much needed information about the size of this problem around Europe. Armed with this information I can start convincing manufacturers to take the problem seriously. This will then lead to collaboration with BRM producers to develop more bat friendly products. About MeMy name is Stacey Waring and I have been researching bats and BRMs for the past five years (wow where did the time go?). In fact technically I am the only person in the world to study this topic.....and yes its a very niche area but I think quite important. Whats different about me is that I cross multiple science disciplines such as ecology, zoology, engineering, materials science and physics. This means that I can talk to all the parties involved in this project and convey the information they need to know effectively. Because of this I have a wide network of companies and individuals who collaborate with this research. Hopefully, because of this I am in a great position to help solve some of the problems my research has brought to light.FAQsI have tried to preempt any questions in the sections above...but if I have missed anything feel free to ask away. I'll even add it here so others know the answer too.

story:
Introduction

Belen is a forgotten district in Iquitos, the largest city of the Peruvian amazons. The district of Belen presents severe sanitary issues, social violence, and as a result of this reality, many health problems. There is no drinking water available nor daily food supply.
Kismaya theatre will go to Belen offering a workshop for kids and building an aqua phonic system, providing sustainable drinking water and food.

Background

Kismaya is theatre group founded in 2008, directed by Talya Weinberg, humanitarian clown, focusing in education through workshops, plays and ecology projects.

The Gezuntheid institute from the US, and Bola Roja association based in Lima, Peru, have been working for the last 9 years, bringing clowns, artists and health professionals to work for and with the community, for a healthier Belen. The main work is done through the organization of the annual Belen Festival that combines street performances and art workshops with public health guides, using art as a bridge to health. 

This year, with your help, Kismaya will join the Belen Festival and work with La Restinga, a local organization, established in 2004, working to empower the local community through education in ecology and art. As humanitarian clowns, we strive to make a change in a holistic manner, dealing with all aspects of the problems. We found out that our workshops can help the children minds, but can´t provide them with clear drinking water nor food... Without solving the hunger problem, even the funniest clown will find it hard to make a child smile. Therefore we researched and found the aqua phonic system as the best solution.

Aquaponics is the combination of aquaculture and hydroponics. In Aquaponics, the fish and plants are grown together in one integrated, soilless system. The fish waste provides a food source for the plants and the plants provide a natural filter for the water the fish live in. Simple, sustainable, safe, fresh, organic fish and vegetables are produced but mainly pure clean drinking water.

The system we aim to bring to Belen, will be done with the supervision of Shlomi zarihan, an expert marine biologist with years of experience in aquaculture and Aquaponics. Shlomi’s mission is to provide and teach methods for a sustainable way of life and preservation of the marine environment.

Mission statement

We believe that empowering the local communities, situated in one of the most important ecosystem in the world, the Amazon rainforest, will create a healthier more sustainable future for the earth.

We have identified some of Belen’s acute problems and as a holistic solution we want to offer the community help through educational workshops, clowning art and ecology. We have partnered with an expert marine biologist specializing sustainable water filtration and food cultivation in aquatic systems and we want to bring his experience in order to construct the aqua phonic system described above.

We strongly believe that this system and further education and cooperation with La Restinga, will bring a true and fundamental change to the local populations´ quality of living, mainly the children.

We realized that in Belen we can achieve the best results and help over 10,000 families in the region through educational workshops and the physical construction of the first Aquaponics system in the region.

Our goals

Kismaya is asking for your help in raising $6,250 in order to pay for the following:
- transport fees, 2 person - $2,100
- Living expenses, 2 person, 3 weeks - $900
- Educational materials & documentation - $150
- Educational plays and Workshops performed by Kismaya - Volunteered
- Construction materials for Aqua phonic system - $1,750
- construction labor - Volunteered
- Expert Biologist labor - $700
- Presents for donators - $400
- Indiegogo & payment processing services fees - $500

For every additional $6,000 we can establish another aquaphonic system and deliver the proper educational framework in order to make it viable. Siloe, Cali, Colombia being the next destination.

This Project is designated to help the children of Belen - the bigger portion of the poor population of Belen. This is a pilot project, empowering local community leaders, that can be implemented in numerous other communities in need, thus building strong sustainable communities, eliminating poverty, violence, children abuse and creating an ecologically sounds environment in the rain forest and other endangered ecosystems.

With your contribution you are enabling drinking water access, better education and happiness to numerous deprived children.

For your help we will commemorate your effort with different perks according to the magnitude of your donation. For a large donation of $500 or more, a named plank caring your name will be installed on the system.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that not all of us can contribute funds. That doesn’t mean you can’t help! Spread the word. Email your friends. Share us on Facebook. Help us make this world a better place, especially for the children.

story:
“The forest teaches us enoughness: as a principle of equity, how to enjoy the gifts of nature without exploitation and accumulation.” Vandana Shiva

To all who gather here; my name is Riley Hubbell and ever since I was a little girl, my favorite feeling has been that of bare feet sprinting across open groves of Sequoia trees semi-trucks taller than myself. Over time, this simple adoration of the natural world has transcended into a deeply rooted advocacy to protect it. As catalysts such as globalization and industrialization tirelessly develop our world’s communities, I have felt called to make sure the ecological health and social harmony of our earths communities develops as well.

As I approach the end of my third year at University of California, Santa Barbara I've solidified a passion for sustainable development because it assures our resources are shared; that no community is more entitled to vital amenities than another. After recent travels to an AIDS affected community in Nassau, the rural countryside of Bolivia and a number of agricultural based communities throughout Peru, I’ve experienced first hand the demand for both the egalitarian distribution of resources as well as a consideration for the holistic wellbeing of our earth’s developing communities.

I've recently been accepted into a program that works to secure these demands — Sustainable Vocations. Located at Quail Springs Permaculture in Maricopa, California this three-week intensive course teaches a number of critical skills centered on permaculture and sustainable development. The philosophy behind permaculture is that by working with nature using protracted and thoughtful observation rather than thoughtless action, we allow systems to demonstrate their own evolutions. Upon completion I will receive a widely recognized Permaculture Design Certification and will be equipped with a toolbox of skills vital to sustainable development such as:

  • Sustainable Living Skills
  • Watershed Restoration
  • Localizing Food & Economy 
  • Community Building
  • Animal Husbandry 
  • Rainwater Harvesting & Greywater Design

What I Am Asking For (And What You Get!)

Three weeks of food, camping accommodations, and the cost of my Permaculture Design Certification as well as a multitude of other skills makes the cost of this course $2,500. While that is a hefty chunk of change, it will allow me to further develop legitimate skills that will propel me into new avenues of change-making and set me apart from other applicants as I apply for my masters in Development at the New School in NYC upon graduation from UCSB. Because this course is important to me, I am reaching out to friends and family to assist me in raising $2,000 of this cost. 

The impact of your donation — regardless of the scope — will be critical in assisting me in my efforts to live out my passion of helping to create (and be a part of!) holistic communities that value social cohesion rather than individualistic capitalism. Don't think that I've forgotten about YOU as well. For different levels of donations, I will reciprocate the love in a number of ways. Check ‘em out in the column to the right of this page!

Other Ways You Can Help

While monetary donations would be the most helpful at this time, I understand that some people just can’t contribute in the form of cash. If you are interested in helping out in other ways, please consider sharing my cause with your friends either using social media or word of mouth!

story:
Proyecto MEIGA was created two years ago in Santo Domingo, at the beginning MEIGA started like an idea and today is a reality.

We are Vanessa Beiro and Nelly Taveras, two entrepreneur women with a common ideal, that means turn this company into an environmental reference in Dominican Republic.

This campaign is very important to us because we believe in green progress, in other words, we believe in ecological development in countries like Dominican Republic where economic development is closely related to the exploitation of natural resources.

What We Need & What You Get

In fact, our main goal is to recycle solid waste, and to do this we need tools like a specific waste truck that will be used to serve waste shipment.

In another hand, we need several containers; they will be used for the appropriate acquisition and separation of solid waste.

And finally, with these donations we will continue doing activities, workshops, conferences and coastal cleanups.

That's why in this campaign we need to collect 50,000 US dollars.

The magnitude of this campaign will be great way of positively impacting in poor communities in which we already work; and we could also offer our services to different companies that need management waste plans.

With your participation like a donor you will be part of a real solution.

With your contribution you will get:

  • Donations between 1$ and 5$you will receive a big thank you!
  • Donations between 6$ and 15 $ you will receive a big thank you and a Virtual MEIGA eco-card.
  • Donations between 16$ and 25$ you will receive a big thank you, a virtual MEIGA eco-card and virtual bulletin board (during 3 months)
  • Donations between 26$ and 55$ you will receive a big thank you, a virtual MEIGA eco-card, a virtual bulletin board and a video with our activities.
  • Donations between 56$ and 75$ you will receive a big thank you, a virtual MEIGA eco-card, a virtual bulletin board, a video with our activities and 2 hours of personal consulting in waste management.
  • Donations between 76$ and 100$ you will receive a big thank you, a virtual eco-card, a virtual bulletin board, a video with our activities and 4 hours of personal consulting in waste management.
  • Donation between 150$ and 250$ you will receive all the rewards that we mentioned, plus MEIGA products like (MEIGA Polos, Donor ID, and a set of pens)
  • Donation over 500$ you will receive all the gifts and rewards that we mentioned, and we will insert your name in our Website as an honorary member.
  • Donation over 1000$ you will receive all the rewards that we mentioned, plus an invitation of 3 days to collaborate in our activities, during this time everything will be included (Except travel flight and hotel).
  • Donation over 2000$ you will receive all the rewards that we mentioned plus an invitation of 7 days to collaborate in our activities, we will take in charge your hotel and you will receive a tourist tour in Santo Domingo. (Except the travel flight)

The Impact

In this campaign of donation there will be find direct and indirect effects.

The direct effects:

  • We will develop parts of the project thanks to your donation, with the truck we could go to different zones and be more effective in collecting waste.
  • We will develop alliances with municipalities and private companies.
  • We will continue our work with poor communities that are suffering of lack of efficient cleaning in their areas.

The indirect effects

  • With the recovery of the recyclable waste we could give them a second life of use.
  • The poor communities will be able to retrieve waste and sell it.
  • With the cleaning of coasts we will contribute to the growth of tourism in local zones.
  • With this project we all contribute to improving the environment.

Risks & Challenges

The challenge of this project is to get the funds to develop our schedule program and activities and make ourselves a reputational company in Santo Domingo city.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don ́t have the funds to contribute with our cause, you can HELP US just talking about our project with your social network and recommending our website www.proyectomeiga.com or visiting our campaign in INDIEGOGO PLATAFORM.

And as John Lennon said: " Imagine there ́s no countries, it isn ́t hard to do nothing to kill or die for... and no religion too, imagine all the people living life in peace"

story:
Short Summary

  • My Name is Tony Pizzo.  I have been a professional Rockstar, an Astro Physics Aviation Engineer and everything in between. I founded the organization Hangar 18 World Engineering to teach and design innovative "Open Source" world technology solutions 
  • I have converted my 1978 Motorhome "TARDIS 1" into an energy efficient experimentation center which I will be using as a tour bus to show the world during a tour with The Pretty Reckless/Crash Midnight starting Wednesday September 10th at the House of Blues Boston . The tour is 26 dates, covering most major US and Canadian cities and it is the perfect opportunity to fulfill my goal of combining music and science.
  • Funding is needed to take advantage of this great opportunity and show this unique energy vehicle to the world while holding educational workshops during the tour.
  • Growing up in Burlington, VT I was a prodigy of science, building rockets and flying airplanes at a very young age. At the age of 15, I moved to Cape Cod, MA where I started a successful music career and developed a professional reputation as the guy who can fix anything. When I say something will work...it does.
  • By contributing to this campaign you will be helping us to teach the world about free sources of energy and non-linear thinking, as well as to make this bus, "TARDIS 1," run completely from energy generated from the earth. Rather than thinking outside the box, we are going to tear it apart and rebuild.
  • The long term goal is for this project to work with other likeminded energy development projects in the future. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are currently setting 4 goals for this.  Once each goal is reached, the "TARDIS 1" will be outfitted with progressively more  and more cutting edge "green" technology.

  • Once the first level of the campaign is reached at $2,000, the bus will be ready to hit the road on this tour.

  • Once the second level of the campaign is reached at $6,000, the bus will be partial hybrid electric. By removing all additional loads from the engine, including braking/power steering assist and converting them all to electric systems completely separate from the engine, which will boost gas mileage. 

  • Once the third level of the campaign is reached at $10,000, the bus will be converted to run partially off clean hydrogen-electric power.

  • Once the fourth level of the campaign is reached at $15,000 we will have enough money for the large electric motors required to make this a full renewable energy vehicle . This will quite possibly make it the first major band tour bus in history to run off this free, renewable sources of fuel!

  • We will be holding workshops for both children and adults, public experiments, and research activities in each city to teach the basic hands-on skills of harnessing free energy in new and creative ways.
  • During the tour we will be continually working to refine my research and applications towards the goal of the bus running purely on free earth energy.
  • The entire venture will document fixing, designing, and recycling things in an outside-the-box manner for future showcasing.
  • In exchange for your contributions, rewards will be Advertising/Sponsoring/graphics on our fanpage www.facebook.com/hangar18research as well an option to have videos displayed inside and on the outside-mounted flatscreen of the TARDIS1 during this national U.S. and Canada tour.  For Major Business sponsorship/advertising please inquire.
  • Any funds generated through this campaign will go towards funding whatever portion of the TARDIS1 tour we are able to financially make. 

The Impact

  • Rather than waiting for massive companies to develop simple concepts into complicated expensive solutions, I would rather educate people on the simplicity of harnessing "alternative" forms of energy that are simple, require minimal technical skills, and can be made inexpensively.
  • References and endorsements may be viewed on our facebook page at www.facebook.com/hangar18research

Risks & Challenges

* Most of the parts I use are from either commonly available items or custom fabricated parts I make myself (or that I make on my homebuilt 3D Printer). Some parts that I am unable to create include: High Horsepower 110volt AC Motors, Large size capacitors, large industrial deep cycle batteries (we can fix "bad" ones), and tires. All of these are needed to make the TARDIS 1 run primarily on self generated electric power.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Spread the word, share my hashtag #savetheworldwithHeavyMetal and help introduce people willing to donate time or parts to this project. 
  • Come see us on the road (list of cities and dates will be posted on our webpage), bring parts you think may help (for a list of potential use-able household items go to our fanpage).
  • Share skills you are able to learn through us with others.
  • Having your support in any way will make this a success, sometimes the smallest "part" can make the biggest difference!! 

2014 Crash Midnight Tour Dates Featuring The Revolutionary "TARDIS 1" Green Energy Tour Bus

Sep-12 Washington, DC - The Fillmore Silver Spring
Sep-13 Philadelphia, PA - TLA
Sep-15 Atlanta, GA - Masquerade - Heaven Stage
Sep-17 Myrtle Beach, SC - House of Blues
Sep-18 Jacksonville, FL - Free Bird

Nov-08 New York, NY - Best Buy Theater
story_txt:
Short Summary 
My Name is Tony Pizzo.  I have been a professional Rockstar, an Astro Physics Aviation Engineer and everything in between. I founded the organization Hangar 18 World Engineering to teach and design innovative "Open Source" world technology solutions 
I have converted my 1978 Motorhome "TARDIS 1" into an energy efficient experimentation center which I will be using as a tour bus to show the world during a tour with The Pretty Reckless/Crash Midnight starting Wednesday September 10th at the House of Blues Boston . The tour is 26 dates, covering most major US and Canadian cities and it is the perfect opportunity to fulfill my goal of combining music and science.
Funding is needed to take advantage of this great opportunity and show this unique energy vehicle to the world while holding educational workshops during the tour. Growing up in Burlington, VT I was a prodigy of science, building rockets and flying airplanes at a very young age. At the age of 15, I moved to Cape Cod, MA where I started a successful music career and developed a professional reputation as the guy who can fix anything. When I say something will work...it does.
 By contributing to this campaign you will be helping us to teach the world about free sources of energy and non-linear thinking, as well as to make this bus, "TARDIS 1," run completely from energy generated from the earth. Rather than thinking outside the box, we are going to tear it apart and rebuild.
The long term goal is for this project to work with other likeminded energy development projects in the future. 

  What We Need & What You Get

We are currently setting 4 goals for this.  Once each goal is reached, the "TARDIS 1" will be outfitted with progressively more  and more cutting edge "green" technology.
Once the first level of the campaign is reached at $2,000, the bus will be ready to hit the road on this tour.
Once the second level of the campaign is reached at $6,000, the bus will be partial hybrid electric. By removing all additional loads from the engine, including braking/power steering assist and converting them all to electric systems completely separate from the engine, which will boost gas mileage. 


Once the third level of the campaign is reached at $10,000, the bus will be converted to run partially off clean hydrogen-electric power.

Once the fourth level of the campaign is reached at $15,000 we will have enough money for the large electric motors required to make this a full renewable energy vehicle . This will quite possibly make it the first major band tour bus in history to run off this free, renewable sources of fuel!
We will be holding workshops for both children and adults, public experiments, and research activities in each city to teach the basic hands-on skills of harnessing free energy in new and creative ways.

During the tour we will be continually working to refine my research and applications towards the goal of the bus running purely on free earth energy.

The entire venture will document fixing, designing, and recycling things in an outside-the-box manner for future showcasing. In exchange for your contributions, rewards will be Advertising/Sponsoring/graphics on our fanpage www.facebook.com/hangar18research as well an option to have videos displayed inside and on the outside-mounted flatscreen of the TARDIS1 during this national U.S. and Canada tour.  For Major Business sponsorship/advertising please inquire. Any funds generated through this campaign will go towards funding whatever portion of the TARDIS1 tour we are able to financially make.  
  The Impact 
Rather than waiting for massive companies to develop simple concepts into complicated expensive solutions, I would rather educate people on the simplicity of harnessing "alternative" forms of energy that are simple, require minimal technical skills, and can be made inexpensively. References and endorsements may be viewed on our facebook page at www.facebook.com/hangar18research


  Risks & Challenges

* Most of the parts I use are from either commonly available items or custom fabricated parts I make myself (or that I make on my homebuilt 3D Printer). Some parts that I am unable to create include: High Horsepower 110volt AC Motors, Large size capacitors, large industrial deep cycle batteries (we can fix "bad" ones), and tires. All of these are needed to make the TARDIS 1 run primarily on self generated electric power.

  Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: 
Spread the word, share my hashtag #savetheworldwithHeavyMetal and help introduce people willing to donate time or parts to this project. 
Come see us on the road (list of cities and dates will be posted on our webpage), bring parts you think may help (for a list of potential use-able household items go to our fanpage).
Share skills you are able to learn through us with others.
Having your support in any way will make this a success, sometimes the smallest "part" can make the biggest difference!!
