story:
The Problem

Pollinating insects, including honey bees, are disappearing from the landscape. Bees are dying in staggering numbers 

Pollinating insects can’t find suitable foods or places to multiply.

Brown desert

Green desert

Yellow desert

Monocultures may seem beautiful, but are not viable habitats to insects, birds or animals. To them it could as well be deserts, asphalt. (Landscapes courtesy of Ivan Bandera)

The Solution

We need biodiverse sustainable farming and forestry. Bees cant live on just one sort of pollen available one week per year. With additional environmental stressors, viruses and parasites they perish.

Business model

Our solution is to build a center for developing AI, based on our BeeScanning technology, and let enterprises use this so solve their problems.  

  1. Enterprises identifies the problem. Takes deep knowledge and domain expertise.
  2. The Swarm offers an app, AI and infrastructure. Charges enterprises. 
  3. Enterprises charge app users, farmers, forestry managers etc.
  4. User data is fed back to The Swarm for further development.

We should change how the land is used and help pollinators survive in a sustainable landscape.  AI technology can answer questions like; Which plant species are critical in the landscape, what culture brings biodiversity?  How can agriculture and forestry shift to profitable and sustainable  methods? 

Healthy bees thrive in healthy landscape
 
BeeScanning Homeland, cultivated biodiversity

The Swarm

We are building a research and knowledge center for bees and pollinators. 
Bees suffers from modern landuse. We need knowledge changing to sustainable farming and forestry. Moving away from industrial monocultures. The Swarm is a platform for projects using BeeScanning AI-technology improving future farming and forestry. 

Bees joining the swarm entering their new home

(A swarm is the bees way to propagate. The beginning of a new enterprise, new life, new opportunities. It is well prepared and bees have been scouting its new home assessing alternatives arguing collectively before decision . The bees bring resources to survive the first period. Establishing in a new environment is a great risk and challenge. A swarm is enormously industrious building their facilities collecting new resources.) 

The Swarm initiative, brings projects together that has identified issues that could be solved with the BeeScanning technology analysing images with artificial intelligence and cloud based infrastructure.

 

Projects reaching out for BeeScanning technology

Future farming, food production and forestry needs new knowledge.

Wherever a problem is observed and can be connected to an optically visible feature, image analysing with artificial intelligence may prove a powerful tool.

AI can be applied to analyse images for a number of reasons like monitoring pests, factors affecting crop quality, harvesting, management, plant breeding programs, research etc...

Projects

  • Monitoring factors improving habitat conditions for biodiverse pollinators, wild bees, beatles, flies, butterflies .
  • Multifloral zones, new harvest practice. Evaluation of honey and pollen supply, plant breeding. Even of weeds.
  • Program for alternate plants fulfilling multiple needs, Galega officinalis for grassland etc..
  • Smallscale biodiverse farming and forestry. Monitoring landuse evaluating successful methods.
  • Strip farming provides areas where life can dwell between harvest of next strip. Reduces need of pesticides, provides life space. Need of new knowledge, new technology, new monitoring tools.

Image analysing with AI can also be used in: 

  • Honey and Protein from Broad Beans. Improving atractivness to pollinators with AI plant breeding assessing factors.
  • Enhancing pollination and harvest in cultivated and wild berries.
  • Drone observing and collecting areal information analysing soil, plants, water supply etc., combined with satellite data.
  • Fruit pollination, best practice, sorts. Analysing factors increasing value reducing pests and costs.
  • Oilseed sort plant breeding program, evaluating honey and pollen supply.
  • Fruit pollination, best practice, sorts. Analysing factors increasing value reducing pests and costs.
  • Monitoring protein production from meal worms. Diagnosing health, mould, mites. Replacing monoculture soy bean farming.

 

 

 

 

WHAT WE ACCOMPLISHED

Awards 

The BeeScanning tech has received 15 international awards.

 

The BeeScanning app

BeeScanning technology is helping bees to better health!  For the first time ever. An app can detect the menace, the parasitic mite, varroa destructor, killing huge numbers of bees around the globe every second.

With the aid of Kickstarter backers, we built the first online tool "Tagger" at tagger.beescanning.com to facilitate uploading and collecting, now over 120 000 images.  75 000 regions of objects are labeled and used for training Neural Network, NN, detection. By researching  and developing new NN we are now able to detect:

  • bees with varroa parasite, 
  • bees with deformed wing viruses,
  • brood disorders,
  • the queen,
  • the colony strength.

AI detecting: Queen, Q, Varroa parasite, BWV, Deformed Wing Virus, DWV, Brood Disorders, BD.

Fully functional version 2.0 launched in may 2020 helping Beekeepers all over the world to combat the threat posed by the monstrous parasite mite. Diagnosing varroa is for free and has saved thousands of colonies. Please find out more at www.beescanning.com

Free to download and use for diagnosing parasite mite varroa.

AI diagnoses and depicts areas with varroa parasite.

Female varroa destructor mite. Feeds on bees larvae and adult bees bodyfluids. Transfers viruses. Kills colony in two years.

How we treat colonies

When free of brood in November, we trickle oxalic acid in 50% sugar solution 5 ml/comb. This reduces infestation with about 85%. We then evaluate fallen mites in february to find colonies wit resistance traits or in need to additional help, change of queens etc.


 

New goals

We now have learned to incorporate other features that will enable monitoring new aspects and new technique. Bee health and prognoses tools for the beekeeper and researching resistance against diseases. 

 
 

BeeScanning AI can follow infested bees and reveal disharmonic behaviours due to parasite on the bees body.

In our next step we foresee the ability to explore complex biological systems. Plants and animals as well as humans may well be monitored by image analyzing with our technology. That is what The Swarm will materialize.

The technology

We have developed new knowledge and processes to analyse images taken from bees on brood frames. We are now broadening the scope to include several indicative behaviours, including swarming preparations, and signs that may be interpreted by the NN and conveyed via the app. 

To give you an idea on the system complexity please study the simplified NN architectural structure. It is totally cloud based and scaleable to handle increasing numbers of users. The image database now contains 120 000 images and videos of live bees. Annotated regions of objects are 75 000 and counting.

The flow of images from the users to our databases, analyzing and presenting results are totally cloud based. This means it is unlimited scaleable as the number of users grow and data traffic increases.

Neural Network Architecture, simplified

Boxes are nodes, each with its own interface. Green boxes represent points of in and out communication between system and user.

 

 

Finances and where fundings go

  • BeeScanning was initially funded from Kickstarter. Then from the EIP, European Innovation Program, and the Swedish Board of Agriculture, SBA, with about 3,5 million SEK (418 000 USD) For BeeScanning 2.0 ending 2020 we were granted 4 million SEK from SBA and 1 million SEK from Vinnova , National board for Innovations. Venture capital has been secured for future BeeScanning development during 2021. 
  • The Swarm needs fundings for initial set up of the project. Establishing the team, designing pilot projects, coordinating and organizing 4 driven specialist in AI, IT-system architecture, Agronomist and Forestry experts, insect breeding and beekeeping. An example that is in the works is monitoring production of protein from mealworms. The mealworms needs to be monitored to sort out deviations like dead, sick or abnormal larvaes on a conveyour belt or in a sorting machine. AI could do that.

The major task for the team is to raise fundings for the coming years from similar sources as BeeScanning has managed to raise, mentioned above.

Here we ask for an initial stake 300 000 SEK (about 30 000 $). This is only about 10% of what will be needed for the total project. It will only suffice for a "Kickstart"!

Spreadsheet

Perks

Most importantly of course is the fact you are sharing and showing insight to a major problem in the culture of our landscapes, and we will make that visible (if you agree to). Both on our site, our social media channels, in the lobby to be and with T-shirts.

 

We want you to engage you and give you the opportunity to influence how The Swarm develops. This goes for all levels of pledging and on higher levels we invite you to engage among our advisors.

Music

Music for the video composed by Björn Lagerman, played and arranged by Mattias Risberg.

Funeral for a landscape

Swarm

 

 

Risks & Challenges

Spot on according to plan. BeeScanning 1.0 launched the first app feb 2018. It aimed to detect the varroa parasite and other features as finding the queen. 171219 decison came, project will be fully funded in step 1. We also submitted a new application for step 2 "Monitoring a biological system" and has fulfilled and developed our technology according to plan fully financed up until december 2020. May 2020 app version 2.0  launched and has attracted 6 000 users globally without marketing. The app has helped beekeepers globally to detect about 200 000 parasites saving thousands of colonies.
Venture capital has secured further development of BeeScanning 2021. 

For The Swarm we foresee allocating knowhow and resources from BeeScanning as well as a combination of financing options.
Major risk to The Swarm is we fail to raise soft capital fundings from Swedish and European Innovation authorities during 2021. We have been informed there are great resources going into European Green Deal, Artificial Intelligence as well as efforts addressing pollination issues. We therefore feel very well positioned in many aspects.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute,  doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about The Swarm campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank you so much coming this far with us. It will be great and so important to us all.

We want you to engage you and give you the opportunity to influence how The Swarm develops. This goes for all levels of pledging and on higher levels we invite you to engage among our advisors.
Music
Music for the video composed by Björn Lagerman, played and arranged by Mattias Risberg.



Funeral for a landscape

Swarm
 

 


Risks & Challenges
Spot on according to plan. BeeScanning 1.0 launched the first app feb 2018. It aimed to detect the varroa parasite and other features as finding the queen. 171219 decison came, project will be fully funded in step 1. We also submitted a new application for step 2 "Monitoring a biological system" and has fulfilled and developed our technology according to plan fully financed up until december 2020. May 2020 app version 2.0  launched and has attracted 6 000 users globally without marketing. The app has helped beekeepers globally to detect about 200 000 parasites saving thousands of colonies.Venture capital has secured further development of BeeScanning 2021. 
For The Swarm we foresee allocating knowhow and resources from BeeScanning as well as a combination of financing options.Major risk to The Swarm is we fail to raise soft capital fundings from Swedish and European Innovation authorities during 2021. We have been informed there are great resources going into European Green Deal, Artificial Intelligence as well as efforts addressing pollination issues. We therefore feel very well positioned in many aspects.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you just can't contribute,  doesn't mean you can't help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about The Swarm campaign.
Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much coming this far with us. It will be great and so important to us all.

story:
TRULY UNIQUE

In January 1991, David Scott and Scott Power wanted to live lives of adventure. So, they dropped out of college, quit their jobs and traveled 1200 miles north toward the Arctic Circle and built a log cabin on Canada's Little Beaver River. They were 19 and 20 years old.

For ten months, Scott and Dave lived in complete solitude among bears, wolves and moose without any electricity, plumbing or communications. The whole experience changed their lives (for the better) as Mother Nature taught them invaluable lessons about life and how to live it. 

Over the years, Scott and Dave's unique story has inspired young people to visit their cabin to learn those important lessons too. In fact, this wilderness area nestled between the Little Beaver and Churchill Rivers has been special ever since William W. Forgey, M.D., whom Backpacker Magazine called "The Father of Wilderness Medicine," built the original cabin there in 1977:

Sadly, a massive wildfire recently destroyed the whole wilderness area and burned these rustic log cabins to ashes. Now grown men in their forties, Scott and Dave are going back to see if it is possible to rebuild so young people may continue to seek adventure there and learn from Mother Nature.

WILL YOU PLEASE HELP?

Please support Scott and Dave as they mount their reconnaissance canoe expedition next month to determine if it is possible to rebuild the cabins.  

Here's their plan:

1. Charter a bush plane to fly them, their canoe and gear from Thompson Manitoba into the wilderness area where the fire burned.

2. From the landing site, they will canoe 30 miles to where the cabin was located and the fire burned.

3. Upon arriving at the location, they will evaluate the scorched earth to determine if it is possible to rebuild the cabin. 

4. Then, they will canoe 120 miles to Hudson Bay and the Polar Bear Capital of the World - Churchill, Manitoba. 

Weather and luck permitting, Scott and Dave anticipate it will take them 10 days to complete their journey.

THE ASK

Please support their expedition by helping Scott and Dave raise the $5000 they need to pay for the necessary transportation, equipment, food, etc. And, if you help them exceed their fundraising goal, they will donate every extra dollar raised to a great cause —  savethepolarbears.org. 

WHAT AFTER

Upon completion of this canoe trip,  Scott and Dave will know if it is possible to rebuild the cabin in 2015-2016. And, they will let you know their findings the first week of September. If so, they will launch a new crowd funding campaign next spring to help raise the necessary funds to do so.

What's more, a documentary movie  called "The Cabin"  is in development, which tells the unique story of this wild place and the people who have loved — and hated it — over the years. Coming soon, Dave and Scott will create a crowd funding initiative for the movie and you'll have the opportunity to became an executive producer on it. So, please stay tuned.

story:
Dear Global Community

I am a dedicated change maker, whom for the past 12 years has been travelling all over the Middle East and the globe working for the reconciliation between peoples and between us humans and the Earth. I have founded numerous initiatives, including EcoSpirit Middle East, and the EcoME centre a home for peace and Ecology in the West Bank. I am also deeply dedicated to the mysterious ways of Spirit and am always ready to be in service when called. I am a lover of the Earth (for more info see my bio below).

Over the years I have reached out on occasions asking for financial support for projects I have initiated or work that I have been called to do for the healing of our Earth and peoples.  The generous responses have been so touching, and I'm left feeling deeply supported by my wider community, believed in and trusted. Thank you!

The time has come for me to ask again.

I have been asked to take a very special journey to South Africa in Dec 2014 to do ceremonial healing work there. We will be working in a wilderness area, summoning support from Mother Nature and the Wild Animals in restoring order to our troubled human world and making a needed connection back to the Middle East. The journey is for 8 days and with travel and costs I need to still raise $1,500 to make it possible, every $ counts.


With much gratitude and a full heart. 
Ilana

P.S f you wish, you can donate directly through paypal to ilanameallem@hotmail.com (mark for services rendered)...and not through this campaign and that way we won't loose 9% in the process.

BIO
-Ilana Meallem has been organizing and facilitating spaces for connection and transformation between diverse peoples across the Middle East since 2006. She is dedicated to the research of holistic peace work: inner, interpersonal and between humans and the Earth. Amongst numerous projects, Ilana created the EcoSpirit Middle East initiative to help provide regional activists and changmakers with holistic leadership skills and co-founded the EcoME Centre next to Jericho, a home for peacework in the West Bank. Over the past 6 years Ilana has grown to love and serve the way of Earth Based ceremony through the Orco Waranka global prayer for Mother Earth, the Vision Quest, Inipi Sweat lodge and water rituals. On completion of her four year vision quest commitment in New Mexico (2012) she received the blessing to pour water for the people. She is devoted to integrating family life, community and spiritual service and currently lives with her partner Itamar in Adama. Together they are leading a group process to support transparency, growth and healing between neighbors

story:
Hi, I’m Raquel Gonzalez:

I'm president of Lompoc Cooperative Development Project.

We're working with six cooperatives in Santa Barbara County, California to start more cooperative businesses. I’m convinced that if we as a nation are going to avoid more episodes like The Great Recession, we need alternatives to top-down Wall Street investor-driven business. We have been working hard to create social and economic change in Santa Barbara County through the development of worker-owned cooperative businesses that create sustainable jobs and promote life-changing opportunities for unemployed and under-employed residents.

Worker cooperatives are owned and democratically controlled by the workers. The worker cooperative is a well-established, proven business structure with examples across the United States, Canada and the world.  Cooperatives are appearing everywhere. They’re inspiring and hopeful. We CAN make a difference.

In our local committee we have Isla Vista Food Co-op and Santa Barbara Student Housing Co-op, both of them long-established. And we have four small startup worker co-ops. One of them is a green cleaning business whose members/owners are mostly recently immigrated women of color.

To call attention to our work, we’re staging the first Santa Barbara County Co-op Festival. It will be November 8, 2014 in Lompoc. We’ll have educational booths and workshops on cooperative business models and economic justice.  We also want to ensure that the event is attractive to people who are not familiar with cooperatives and to families where children’s activities are important.  For this reason, we will also have  dance and music performances, and games.

All the cooperatives are contributing cash and volunteer labor but we’re still a little short, about $1,800 short: enough to pay for the interpreters (the whole event will be bilingual) and a few other things. 

We can offer a tax deduction and cool perks: a professional sleep study (if you live in our area), a bottle of non-toxic cleaning solution, a CD of the event, "I own a grocery store with my friends" grocery bag and hand-painted bookmarks by artist Tonya Romano Schultz.

We’re pretty confident we’ll reach our goal, but in case we don’t, since we can use whatever is sent, we’re choosing IndieGoGo’s flexible plan.

Please make a little donation. Every dollar counts. It will help our event and contribute to the nationwide movement toward a new economy based on grass-roots cooperatives. World wide, cooperatives are such a growing force that the United Nations named 2012 the Year of the Cooperative. 

If you can’t contribute, you can still help by putting out the word about our lightning campaign to all your friends on Facebook and anywhere. IndieGoGo provides share tools!

story:
Short Summary

SpeakEasy Music Productions In Association With The Northern California Music Community Presents "Rockers To The Rescue" A Campaign To Help Needy Families Provide A Christmas Through Local Church Victory Outreach Programs Located In Sacramento And The SF Bay Area With All Proceeds Going Directly To Help Families This Holiday Season With Food And Toy Donations.

What We Need & What You Get

What We Need Is Your Money....A Small Donation Less Than The Price Of A Movie Ticket!
What You Get Is Some Amazing Original Music In Return! Also You Will Receive A Warm Heart And Good Karma Knowing That You Have Helped To Make A HUGE Difference For Needy Families This Christmas!

The Impact

The Impact Will Be Letting The People Of Your Community Know That You Care! And That The People Involved In Our Industry Are The Best EVER! :-)

Risks & Challenges

There Is NO RISK At All And The Only Challenge Will Be Spreading The Good Word!

Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing This Campaign On Every Social Media Outlet Available Until We Have Reached Our Goal!

story:
WE’RE INCUBATING A MOVEMENT: A new generation of attorneys who can defend your environment no matter who you are or what your income might be. FAIR SHAKE fills the gap in legal representation for those who cannot afford market-rate legal services. And we teach young attorneys how to SUSTAINABLY DO THE SAME.
 
Help us DEFEND YOUR ENVIRONMENT by helping us build a 1-to-1 match fund for the upcoming 2016 Day of Giving. 


We have 25 days to secure $1,250 for our match fund to increase access to environmental justice.

We have until April 2 to take advantage of a double-your-impact opportunity with the 2016 Day of Giving:

  • That's 25 days to unlock access to environmental justice for those who never believed that their rights to a healthy environment mattered.
  • Let them know that we've got their back & display your Defend Your Environment pride with a sweet "thank you" gift at each level of support.

The Value of Your Gift? Listen to our Clients' Stories.

To keep the momentum going all 25 days and let you know the value of your gift, we'll release vignettes of our client stories every Wednesday through our deadline to let you see the value of your gift. Check back here and use the gallery tab to find each new vignette.

Here's our first: Meet Mick Luber, an organic farmer seeking to protect his land and livelihood from the taking of his land by a private company, for the installation of a pipeline intended to transport natural gas liquids that will be used by a Canadian plant to make plastics.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can afford to donate even at the smallest level. There are other ways to help:

  • Share what it means to you to #DefendYourEnvironment via social media, and keep the discussion going.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to let people know about our match campaign!

Thank you for your support!

story:
A Brief Rundown: 

  • Full funding will enable us to buy some of the most essential components needed to run our bus on waste veggie oil and help sell fresh, local, organically grown produce at affordable prices to areas that do not have access to fresh produce.
  • Every dollar helps, check out the perks for donating, and spread the word!

Moving Market Mission

The Moving Market’s mission: to make healthy, sustainably grown, organic foods more affordable and accessible to communities -- especially low-income residents, senior citizens, and "food desert areas" (areas with low access to healthy foods) -- by selling directly to the people, year-round at wholesale cost. Nutrition and the benefits of buying fresh, locally grown produce will be an educational emphasis of these interactions.

Food is an integral part of our lives and the Moving Market would promote a connection to organic agro-forestry/farming methods. We are members of the World Wide Organization of Organic Farmers (WWOOF), with a variety of experience with farmer’s markets, and are currently helping out at Six Circles farm in upstate New York. Six Circles Farm is a certified naturally-grown farm that uses organic farming practices and is well-known in the area for its unique garlic scape pesto and strong garlic powder (both perks for donating!). Many of the farms we have worked on have an abundance of good, tastey, totally edible produce left over from market. Much of the left over food is composted, which is great for the soil, but we see an opportunity where we can take that good food to people who need it. 

The Moving Market is a cohesive plan that would encourage sustainability, reduction and prevention of waste, and community empowerment. We have purchased a bus that would allow us to travel and share produce that we have helped grow.  With your help, the Moving Market Bus can be repaired and converted to run on waste vegetable oil (wvo)—which would therefore allow us to reduce fossil fuel consumption, utilize otherwise-wasted vegetable oil, and deliver nutritious sustainably-grown food to communities. 

Every dollar contributed goes toward making organic products and helping to keep the vegetable bus up and running properly.  

Meet the bus drivers:

Raven: Certified in Permaculture Design, graduated from Rudolf Steiner, entrepreneur (see Raven’s Nest on Etsy.com), member of Worldwide Organization of Organic Farmers, experienced farmhand, wild crafter, experienced in acro-yoga, musician, artist, motivated individual.

Emily: B.A. in Environmental Policy from University at Buffalo, experienced grassroots campaigner for the environmental group Clean Water Action, member of Worldwide Organization of Organic Farmers, experienced organic farmhand, road warrior, artist, aspiring herbalist, motivated individual.

We both are currently volunteering at Six Circles Farm in Lodi, New York, but will head south to help with permaculture projects in Florida.

What We Need & What You Get

Every dollar contributed aids in providing a cleaner and environmentally-conscious mode of transportation for organic farmers, permaculturalists, and environmentalists in general.  These community advocates will be able to get to and from their points of destination in an environmentally-efficient way.  Whether it’s bringing a fellow WWOOFer to their next organic farm, or transporting volunteers to help out at a green project, the Moving Market bus will actualize the sustainable principles which many of us seek to act upon yet fail to practically enact due to the lack of opportunities or capabilities.

Full funding will enable us to buy some of the most essential components needed to run a bus on veggie oil.  The bus also has the capability to support a solar panel system.  The solar panel implementation would provide clean energy which would power appliances.  The appliances would store food grown by organic farmers and would eventually be the storing system for our own food creations which we would sell from the bus – the new, organic, revolutionized “Skippy (or  whatever your local ice cream truck was called).”

A Breakdown of Costs: Injection pump $1500, walbro pump and Vegetable Conversion Kit's veg filter $290, veg and  coolant lines $300, new 50 gallon tank $400, tank heater $230 hot fox , wiring $50, $300 mechanic labor 

Once the bus is repaired and converted the funds will go towards buying a solar panel system (roughly $500) and cooler to store vegetables in the bus. Other funding will go to license, permit costs, promotions, and sustainability projects/workshops.  

The Impact

-Encourages health, community, sustainability

-Increases the availability of sustainably-grown food to underserved communities

-Creates a cleaner mode of transportation that will inspire and mobilize others

 This is not an impossible feat.  In fact, our neighbors in Albany have successfully launched a similar project.  Check it out and see how possible it really is! http://www.cdcg.org/VeggieMobile.html

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

story:
The Need

In the developing world 3 billion people rely on biomass fuels such as wood and charcoal for cooking.  The burning of biomass in inefficient cookstoves produces life-threatening smoke.  Tragically, this kills nearly 2 million people each year - mostly women and children - more than double the number of deaths caused by malaria.  Harvesting fuelwood also drives devastating deforestation of tropical forests.

BURN Design Lab

BURN is a Vashon, WA non-profit founded by Peter Scott in 2010 to address this global issue.  Its mission is to save lives and forests in the developing world by designing and locally manufacturing clean burning cookstoves.

Peter has been designing fuel efficient cookstoves for the past 15 years and is considered a leading expert in the field.  In 1990, Peter committed his life to saving the forests of Africa.  Since that time, he has designed countless fuel efficient technologies.  He's trained producers in over 20 countries who have made over 500,000 tree saving technologies, such as clean cookstove and bread ovens.  His work has been featured in The New Yorker and on CNN. In 2010, he was chosen as one of Foreign Policy Magazine's 100 Top Global Thinkers. 

The Tank - A Clean Burning Stove

In the last 18 months our team - in concert with Kenyan women - has created "The Tank", a new super fuel-efficient charcoal stove prototype. The stove uses 50% less fuel than the existing improved stove widely used in Kenya. The Tank is currently receiving rave reviews from cooks in Kenya and outperformed all other cookstoves in East Africa in recent independent trials. One woman has gone as far to say "it's like cooking with gas!"

 

                                     
                                                           A Happy Tank user!
 

Over the three-year life of each Tank stove, it will avoid 7.5 tons of greenhouse gases (tCO2e), as well as saving 39 trees and saving end users as much as $540 in fuel costs!

The Funding Gap - Our Indiegogo Plan

A manufacturer is ready to locally produce The Tank in East Africa once it has been fully proven in the market.  They will produce 1.5 million Tank stoves over the next 10 years that will save 53 million trees and impact the lives of 8.3 million people.  

In order to turn The Tank into a market ready product, we need your help to meet our target of $20,000 to launch the product.  This investment directly targets pilot programs, market tests, focus groups and the purchase of key equipment.  With your help we will save millions of trees and impact millions of lives in East Africa!

Contribute in Other Ways!

We need Your help!  There are a wide variety of ways that You can do:

  • Get the word out about this campaign!
  • Join us! Volunteer, intern or apply for a job!
  • Donate a bike or car (tax receipts available)!

Rewards

Top rewards include an opportunity to learn how to build rocketstoves for a week with BURN in the Maasai village in Kenya and Olivia Pendergast original paintings!

Email boston@burndesignlab.org with any questions regarding rewards.
 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Want to Geek Out? - How it Works?

We use basic principles of Heat Transfer, Combustion and Fluid Dynamics to make the super fuel-efficient Tank stove.  A batch of charcoal is loaded from the top and sits on a metal grate, similar to a Webber Grill.  The charcoal is lit igniting all of the fuel.  The combustion of charcoal naturally draws air through the ash-tray and below the fuel through the grate.  

  1. The combustion chamber holds a batch of charcoal that perfectly cooks a typical meal in East Africa to ensure that no charcoal is wasted after cooking!
  2. As air travels over the hot ash-tray on its way to the combustion chamber, it is pre-heated to improve combustion
  3. The air enters combustion chamber below the charcoal to give good mixing between the fuel and air to improve combustion  
  4. The hot combustion gases travel out of the stove and blast the bottom and sides of the pot through carefully optimized gap sizes 
  5. A "radiant shield" located below the grate reflects radiant energy back up to the pot!

A "radiant shield" located below the grate reflects radiant energy back up to the pot!

story:
Our Story

The 91 foot, tall ship Quinnipiack has been a fixture in New Haven Harbor and Long Island Sound since 1990. Her goal is to increase environmental literacy. This is accomplished by providing educational programs for schools and public sails for the community.

Running a traditional wooden boat takes a lot of work and maintenance. This campaign will help provide the funds need for her annual maintenance and US Coast Guard inspection. This will include checking fasteners, replacing covering boards and top timbers, and revamping our galley.  We will finish off with a new coat of protective marine paint.

 

The Impact

Reaching our goal and being able to complete our annual maintenance will mean that Quinnipiack can continue providing a great learning experience for the communities on Long Island Sound. If we are not able to complete our goal the future of the ship will be uncertain.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Below is a breakdown of where the money will go this year and a brief explanation of each item for those who might not be familiar with the terminology.

 

$2000 Hauling and Launching- Taking the boat out of the water and putting it back in.

$1000 Lumber and Fasteners- The wood needed for repairs and the hardware to attach it

$1000 marine coating- Special primer and paint for boats

$6000 Shipwright fees- These are the skilled professionals that specialize in traditional boat repairs

$2000 Tool Rentals

$2000 Crew Housing- While the boat is under repairs the crew cannot live on-board

$1000 Crew Provisions- Food, gloves, dust masks, paper coverall suits,etc....

$1000 Waste disposal- Everything scraped and taken off the bottom of the boat must be properly disposed of in an environmentally friendly manner

  

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation you can help by spreading the word. Pass this along to all of your friends and coworkers. Use the share buttons. We are also accepting volunteers to help with the haul-out process.

story:
Our Story

Hello there!

We are a pair of friends and amateur naturalists who are looking to get to South Africa next April. :) 

Carrie is an Archivist who is studying to become a Scientific and Nature Illustrator, and Erika is a Graphic Designer who also draws and sells indie books for charity.

We were united, fairly recently, in fact, by our shared love of the natural world and drawing, and soon we realized that both of our life-long dreams have been to visit Africa and study the animals there closely in their natural environment. We found out about a program that will allow us to do just that, and we decided to try to go for it.

Unfortunately we're not exactly well-off -- we both are thankfully employed, but we live in one of the most expensive places to live in the US, and neither of us are dentists or bankers. A huge portion of our earnings goes towards rent and it is difficult for us to save up any money for a trip, let alone one overseas.


The Impact

We decided to apply for the Game Ranger Guide course with African Conservation Experience, based in the UK. It is a highly regarded private volunteer placement organization.

The course will give us a thorough introduction to the wildlife, habitats and conservation issues of southern Africa, which will expand our knowledge and understanding of African fauna. In addition to it being an amazing experience, it will help us greatly with our ultimate dreams in life -- to work in a field related to helping animal conservation.


Donating to us will not only help us have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to interact with animals in the wild and learn more about them, but will go towards a myriad of conservation and humanitarian efforts. ACE has always contributed to local communities that the volunteer placements are in, such as supporting the Harmony Flats Working Group, helping build playgrounds and helping local soccer teams, and sponsoring local volunteers to take part in programs.


What We Need & What You Get

We are not asking you to pay for transportation costs, but for the placement program itself. This will at least be $3000 for the two of us. I think we can at least scrape together enough money for a plane ticket there.

And the awesome thing? You will most definitely get something in return once you donate! Check out the list of perks.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this page with other folks -- any little bit helps, even if it's $1 or $5. :)

Thank you so much for your help.


<3

Erika and Carrie

story:
What is H2OScore.com?

H2OScore.com is a website that helps you understand how much water you use.

Most water utilities send you a bill every three months, which shows your water usage in strange units like CCF.  If you get a bill for 15 CCF, what does that mean?  Is it good?  Is it bad?

Now, you can go to H2OScore.com, enter your address and the number of people in your household.  Using public information that utilities are required by law to make available, we look up your most recent water bill and translate your water usage into something you can relate to!

Instead of 15 CCF we give you average gallons per day and compare you to the average household with the same number of residents, giving you an H2O Score.

Without knowing where we stand, how can we even begin to approach the problem of water conservation?

Help us add 100 new cities to our database to empower more people to become water sustainable!

Our Story

When books are written about the great transformations of the 21st century, the ideas and innovations that promote sustainability will be at the forefront.  Our greatest challenges lie in managing demand for scarce resources.


When our most vital resource - clean fresh water - is inaccessible to more than ten percent of the world's population, we know that more sustainable solutions are required.


Our goals are both modest and expansive.  We began as a class of students, seeking to make a difference, and inspired by the idea of social entrepreneurship.  We built a website and started to dream.


Now we have become the leading example of a student-led sustainability enterprise in the Midwest, and the first trans-community resource for water sustainability that utilizes actual usage data to empower citizen conservation efforts. 


Where we go from here depends on your support!


Ultimately, we hope to become a national (or perhaps trans-national) resource for water consumption analysis, linking end-users with local businesses, civic associations, city governments, and regional planners to achieve comprehensive water sustainability.


How it works

Our mechanism is simple:  We obtain public data from municipal water utilities, add it to our comprehensive database, and allow the consumer to access their consumption history simply by typing in their address on our website.


Since there are thousands of municipal water utilities across the country, this is a massive undertaking of data collection and aggregation. 


When we finish, our site will be nothing less than transformative.  Instead of blindly paying a utility bill, consumers will have detailed information at their fingertips to make informed choices about their water consumption.  How much to water, what type of aerator to install, even which local businesses make efforts to conserve.  In short, our site promises to transform our culture of water waste into a culture of water awareness.


By contributing to our campaign, you are making it possible for us to add 100 or more cities to our database.  That will be a major step forward for us and a giant leap forward for water sustainability.


The Impact

The typical person uses 100 gallons per day of water on average.  This includes both essential uses like washing dishes and less essential uses like watering the driveway.


If just one million people reduced their water consumption ten percent, that would save 10 million gallons per day.


Imagine if your water utility didn't have to raise rates to pay for a new or expanded water treatment plant.  Or if your sewage treatment plant didn't overflow as much.  Imagine the greenhouse gases reduced because the energy required to treat the water didn't need to be consumed.  Imagine if that aquifer was still there for your grandchildren.


Or imagine that we continue on our current path.  When water becomes scarce, governments enact inefficient restrictions.  They penalize people by raising rates.  Or they sell the water utility to the highest bidder and turn it into a profit center.  We find all of those alternatives distressing.  Rather, we'd like to see people empowered to use water wisely and efficiently and to preserve it for future generations.


What We Need & What You Get

We believe that you should have a say in which cities we expand to cover.  So, we're offering the following proposition: donate the cost of adding a city ($65) and we'll let you pick which one we add.


If you have an aunt in Scottsdale who waters her lawn ALL THE TIME, we'll put in a request there if you donate the money.  Then you can type in her address and see how she compares to YOU (as long as your city is in our database too!).


Based on past experiences in obtaining water usage data from around the Midwest, we calculate the $65 average based on fees and costs that we incur.  That's $40 on average in fees and $25 in labor/overhead costs per city (explained in more detail in the video!).


If we don't reach our goal of $6500, we will add as many cities as we can for that amount.  And if we raise more, we'll just keep adding cities at the same rate.


If $65 is too little or too much for you to donate, we offer several alternatives in the column to the right!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about H2OScore.com.  Like us on Facebook. Follow us on Twitter. Ask your friends in other cities to contribute $65 so their cities can be in our database too!

story:
Coralbots has won equipment cash from the UK government! We have a small part of a autonomous robotics equipment award shared between Heriot-Watt University (where most of us are) and Edinburgh University. See http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-23332184. This means we will be able to buy a dedicated coralbot for the project, but still need your donation to accelerate development and testing of the control software and much else!

We are deeply grateful to Jonathon Porritt for his endorsement of our project. Jonathon says:  “I really like this idea. The scale of damage to the world’s coral reefs is already so overwhelming that we will need an army of coralbots to get the restoration underway!” - Jonathon is a leading light in environmentalism; see his biography, affiliations and current activities here

Our Mission  Coral reefs support over 500 million people, and harbour vital reserves of biodiversity that are crucial to current and future medicine. But reefs are being damaged on a global scale by storms, destructive fishing, ship groundings, making them even more susceptible to stresses such as pollution and ocean acidification. It can take many years to decades for them to heal. Start to read more about the vital importance of coral reefs and their untempered decline here. 

Restoration attempts currently take place on shallow reefs using  scuba divers attaching healthy coral back onto the reef. For example, see below two pictures provided by our colleague Lisa Carne from her highly successful "Fragments of Hope" Coral Nursery in Belize. The fist shows a healthy coral ecosystem in the seas around Belize, and the other shows divers working on the restoration of a damaged reef nearby.  Local fishermen and tour guides with expertise are vital to this success story, but such approaches cannot be used to repair reefs in deeper waters below about 600 feet where reefs also exist because of depth limits to humans diving. 

    

Our answer: Coralbots - autonomous undersea robots that will repair and restore damaged coral reefs.  When fully developed, coralbots will manipulate pieces of healthy corals (either scattered from their original position due to damage, or provided by a coral nursery), find appropriate places for these pieces to go in the original reef (to maximise the chances of regeneration), and then attach the fragment to the reef. This needs lots of adaptation and refinement of 'computational intelligence' algorithms around machine vision and robot control. All our developed and deployed algorithms will be open source (see here ).  

The Coralbots idea is unique and transformative - current robotics applications in the marine world, as well as on land and sea, are almost entirely about surveillance, monitoring and exploration - basically, robots see and report back.  The potential for robots to make positive changes to the environment by manipulating it has not been considered until now. Apart from missions to restore coral reefs, a key motivation for our team is to inspire many further activities of this kind, which we believe will transform marine conservation forever. Small steps beyond our current plans, for example, will enable myriad other marine conservation missions, including different types of intervention in relation to coral reefs (e.g. inoculating the 'crown of thorns' starfish that has devastated the Great Barrier Reef), through to collection of marine litter that kills millions of marine animals and birds every year.  

Below is the coralbot we will most likely buy (with manipulator included) with the equipment money recently raised, along with 3 smaller sea-surface robots for navigation and communication.

 

 

    

State of the art research is starting to attach manipulators to such robots (e.g. to recover valuable archeological artefacts, or tighten valves in undersea installations). The coralbots team aim to exploit this developing technology in ways that revolutionize marine conservation, in missions that carefully manipulate aspects of the marine environment, accomplishing tasks that scuba divers currently attempt, but immensely more speedily, tirelesly, and  without danger to human lives. Coralbots will be based on existing understea robot vehicles, with manipulators attached. Below left, one view of a prototype coralbot, on the right: model of an existing up to date AUV (Nessie VII) with a manipulator arm attached.

What makes our longer term vision particularly exciting and effective is the idea of using swarm intelligence to control robot behaviour. Swarm intelligence explains how simple behaviours in a group of creatures can lead to complex and functional structures – this is how bees build hives, and termites build complex mounds, and beavers build dams. Read more about that here.  

Who are we? The core coralbots team are a group of scientists and engineers that have internationally leading expertise and immense experience in all of these things. Our areas are coral biology and regeneration (Lea-Anne Henry), autonomous underwater robots technology (David Lane and Dick Blidberg), artificial and swarm intelligence (David Corne), and video/image processing (Neil Robertson). Please see more about the core team and our extended team here.

What you get: in addition to the obvious environmental and knock-on rewards we will all get, we are keen to provide whatever additional rewards we can for our backers. You will get thank you cards and/or videos, you can get your name on a coralbot, you can adopt a coralbot, get a coralbots game, you can have your name forever on a restored reef and more. We are also excited by and committed to global engagement in this programme - that means, working with our backers and involving you in the project itself. You can be a Coralbots Developer, or you can provide IT Support, and your school can engage with us and get exclusive updates.  The way all this translates into the 'perks' we can make availablle is on the right of the campaign page, and also explained further here. 

What we need:  Recent success in other efforts from the team means we will soon be able to buy a new undersea robot, including a manipulator arm, dedicated to the project! We now need the funds to:

  • develop and refine the necessary 'computational intelligence', with an initial focus on recognizing and manipulating the species of corals in the damaged Belize reefs, and stable control and manipulation from the robot;

  • refine the software and hardware to mission-ready and produce first live demo in a public aquarium.

    buy, and/or configure from existing equipment, an additional coralbot allowing us to demonstrate accelerated and co-operative restoration through 'swarm intelligence'  

  • cover transport, personnel and consumables costs (batteries) for first mission attempting to restore a damaged coral reef.

Before launching in the deep sea, our first mission will take place in Belize where we can carefully monitor the coralbots performance safe in the knowledge that land is nearby! Future missions are destined from deep coral reefs off Scandinavia in about 300 feet of water. Your support will provide a conservation solution that paves the way for coral reef monitoring and restoration across the globe, as well as a wealth of additional marine conservation programmes that become enabled by minimal further adaptation to this technology. 

Here is roughly what will happen depending on the funds we raise with your help: 

below $30,000:  a qualified keen researcher costs $3000 per month, and to secure an excellent Masters student to do their project with us may cost anything from $200 to $2000 (if they need accomm). We will optimise the funds against these and similar resources and make as much progress as possible on the computational intelligence underpinnings. Much of the work here will be in experimentaion to find out how big a piece of coral can be manipulated, appropriate design of robot frame, achieving good co-ordination between vision and manipulation, and improving precision in placement. At $30,000  we expect be able to do what's necessary to achieve our first demonstration in a public aquarium, with at least one coralbot.  The nearer we get to $30,000, the more of the underpinning techniques will have been developed and refined, and additional fundraising efforts will soon get us there, but we may well be able to achieve a representative but limied-functionality demo before that.  

between $30,000 and $80,000 - with $80,000, we should be able to procure the person time and transport to achieve our first in-the-wild mission in Belize with a single coralbot.  OR, we can procure a suitably capable second coralbot, install/test the required additional computational intelligence, and demonstrate restoration activities with a co-operating 'swarm' of two coralbots in a public aquarium. There is sense in developing the swarm-based solution before the first tests, since this may significantly improve the impact of missions. Between $30,000 and $80,000 there are many possibilities, and what we might do will be affected by other factors - e.g. we may have been able to obtain additional equipment from other sources. In any case we will discuss the options with our Funders.  

between $80,000 and $120,000 -  at $120,000 we should be in a position to deliver a two-coralbot tets mission in Belize.  Between $80,000 and $120,000, as above, many options are available that we will discuss with our Funders,  but most likely we would be further refining the technologies, in simulation and with tank-testing, to prepare mission ready capability for Belize, Sweden and other sites.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help additionally, or only, in ways other than by donating to the project, we are really grateful for your support and anything you feel able to do. The obvious things that come to mind are simply to help us spread the word. This can be done over your online or offline social networks, but also in other ways. E.g. print out leaflets and display them somewhere! Let us know if you want to do this, and we will send you designs that you can feel free to adapt. Or, translate our text materials into your native language and let us link to that on coralbots.org!  One of our supporters is already translating into German for us - please get in touch if you feel you would like to do this for another language. And, get in touch with any other ideas you may have!

Via the coralbots.org website you can find all the information you need to get in touch with individuals in the team, but our preference at first is if you go direct to coralbots@mail.com,  where we all see it and you are surest of a fast response - or of course you can contact us directly via indegogo.
story_txt:
Coralbots has won equipment cash from the UK government! We have a small part of a autonomous robotics equipment award shared between Heriot-Watt University (where most of us are) and Edinburgh University. See http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-23332184. This means we will be able to buy a dedicated coralbot for the project, but still need your donation to accelerate development and testing of the control software and much else!
We are deeply grateful to Jonathon Porritt for his endorsement of our project. Jonathon says:  “I really like this idea. The scale of damage to the world’s coral reefs is already so overwhelming that we will need an army of coralbots to get the restoration underway!” - Jonathon is a leading light in environmentalism; see his biography, affiliations and current activities  here 
Our Mission  Coral reefs support over 500 million people, and harbour vital reserves of biodiversity that are crucial to current and future medicine. But reefs are being damaged on a global scale by storms, destructive fishing, ship groundings, making them even more susceptible to stresses such as pollution and ocean acidification. It can take many years to decades for them to heal. Start to read more about the vital importance of coral reefs and their untempered decline  here. 
Restoration attempts currently take place on shallow reefs using  scuba divers attaching healthy coral back onto the reef. For example, see below two pictures provided by our colleague Lisa Carne from her highly successful "Fragments of Hope" Coral Nursery in Belize. The fist shows a healthy coral ecosystem in the seas around Belize, and the other shows divers working on the restoration of a damaged reef nearby.  Local fishermen and tour guides with expertise are vital to this success story, but such approaches cannot be used to repair reefs in deeper waters below about 600 feet where reefs also exist because of depth limits to humans diving. 
    
Our answer: Coralbots - autonomous undersea robots that will repair and restore damaged coral reefs.  When fully developed, coralbots will manipulate pieces of healthy corals (either scattered from their original position due to damage, or provided by a coral nursery), find appropriate places for these pieces to go in the original reef (to maximise the chances of regeneration), and then attach the fragment to the reef. This needs lots of adaptation and refinement of 'computational intelligence' algorithms around machine vision and robot control. All our developed and deployed algorithms will be open source (see  here ).   
The Coralbots idea is unique and transformative - current robotics applications in the marine world, as well as on land and sea, are almost entirely about surveillance, monitoring and exploration - basically, robots see and report back.  The potential for robots to make positive changes to the environment by manipulating it has not been considered until now. Apart from missions to restore coral reefs, a key motivation for our team is to inspire many further activities of this kind, which we believe will transform marine conservation forever. Small steps beyond our current plans, for example, will enable myriad other marine conservation missions, including different types of intervention in relation to coral reefs (e.g. inoculating the 'crown of thorns' starfish that has devastated the Great Barrier Reef), through to collection of marine litter that kills millions of marine animals and birds every year.  
Below is the coralbot we will most likely buy (with manipulator included) with the equipment money recently raised, along with 3 smaller sea-surface robots for navigation and communication.
 
 
    
State of the art research is starting to attach manipulators to such robots (e.g. to recover valuable archeological artefacts, or tighten valves in undersea installations). The coralbots team aim to exploit this developing technology in ways that revolutionize marine conservation, in missions that carefully manipulate aspects of the marine environment, accomplishing tasks that scuba divers currently attempt, but immensely more speedily, tirelesly, and  without danger to human lives. Coralbots will be based on existing understea robot vehicles, with manipulators attached. Below left, one view of a prototype coralbot, on the right: model of an existing up to date AUV (Nessie VII) with a manipulator arm attached.
What makes our longer term vision particularly exciting and effective is the idea of using swarm intelligence to control robot behaviour. Swarm intelligence explains how simple behaviours in a group of creatures can lead to complex and functional structures – this is how bees build hives, and termites build complex mounds, and beavers build dams. Read more about that  here.  
Who are we? The  core coralbots team are a group of scientists and engineers that have internationally leading expertise and immense experience in all of these things. Our areas are coral biology and regeneration (Lea-Anne Henry), autonomous underwater robots technology (David Lane and Dick Blidberg), artificial and swarm intelligence (David Corne), and video/image processing (Neil Robertson). Please see more about the core team and our extended team  here.
What you get: in addition to the obvious environmental and knock-on rewards we will all get, we are keen to provide whatever additional rewards we can for our backers. You will get thank you cards and/or videos, you can get your name on a coralbot, you can adopt a coralbot, get a coralbots game, you can have your name forever on a restored reef and more. We are also excited by and committed to global engagement in this programme - that means, working with our backers and involving you in the project itself. You can be a Coralbots Developer, or you can provide IT Support, and your school can engage with us and get exclusive updates.  The way all this translates into the 'perks' we can make availablle is on the right of the campaign page, and also explained further  here. 
What we need:  Recent success in other efforts from the team means we will soon be able to buy a new undersea robot, including a manipulator arm, dedicated to the project! We now need the funds to:


develop and refine the necessary 'computational intelligence', with an initial focus on recognizing and manipulating the species of corals in the damaged Belize reefs, and stable control and manipulation from the robot;


refine the software and hardware to mission-ready and produce first live demo in a public aquarium.
buy, and/or configure from existing equipment, an additional coralbot allowing us to demonstrate accelerated and co-operative restoration through 'swarm intelligence'  


cover transport, personnel and consumables costs (batteries) for first mission attempting to restore a damaged coral reef. 


Before launching in the deep sea, our first mission will take place in Belize where we can carefully monitor the coralbots performance safe in the knowledge that land is nearby! Future missions are destined from deep coral reefs off Scandinavia in about 300 feet of water. Your support will provide a conservation solution that paves the way for coral reef monitoring and restoration across the globe, as well as a wealth of additional marine conservation programmes that become enabled by minimal further adaptation to this technology. 
Here is roughly what will happen depending on the funds we raise with your help: 
below $30,000:  a qualified keen researcher costs $3000 per month, and to secure an excellent Masters student to do their project with us may cost anything from $200 to $2000 (if they need accomm). We will optimise the funds against these and similar resources and make as much progress as possible on the computational intelligence underpinnings. Much of the work here will be in experimentaion to find out how big a piece of coral can be manipulated, appropriate design of robot frame, achieving good co-ordination between vision and manipulation, and improving precision in placement. At $30,000  we expect be able to do what's necessary to achieve our first demonstration in a public aquarium, with at least one coralbot.  The nearer we get to $30,000, the more of the underpinning techniques will have been developed and refined, and additional fundraising efforts will soon get us there, but we may well be able to achieve a representative but limied-functionality demo before that.  
between $30,000 and $80,000 - with $80,000, we should be able to procure the person time and transport to achieve our first in-the-wild mission in Belize with a single coralbot.  OR, we can procure a suitably capable second coralbot, install/test the required additional computational intelligence, and demonstrate restoration activities with a co-operating 'swarm' of two coralbots in a public aquarium. There is sense in developing the swarm-based solution before the first tests, since this may significantly improve the impact of missions. Between $30,000 and $80,000 there are many possibilities, and what we might do will be affected by other factors - e.g. we may have been able to obtain additional equipment from other sources. In any case we will discuss the options with our Funders.  
between $80,000 and $120,000 -  at $120,000 we should be in a position to deliver a two-coralbot tets mission in Belize.  Between $80,000 and $120,000, as above, many options are available that we will discuss with our Funders,  but most likely we would be further refining the technologies, in simulation and with tank-testing, to prepare mission ready capability for Belize, Sweden and other sites.

Other Ways You Can Help


If you want to help additionally, or only, in ways other than by donating to the project, we are really grateful for your support and anything you feel able to do. The obvious things that come to mind are simply to help us spread the word. This can be done over your online or offline social networks, but also in other ways. E.g. print out leaflets and display them somewhere! Let us know if you want to do this, and we will send you designs that you can feel free to adapt. Or, translate our text materials into your native language and let us link to that on coralbots.org!  One of our supporters is already translating into German for us - please get in touch if you feel you would like to do this for another language. And, get in touch with any other ideas you may have!

story:
Small business owners Shafic Tayara and Chris Lopez are going to every city, starting with Los Angeles Ca, giving haircuts, clothes, water and more to the homeless. It starts here in California and the goal is to take this movement and spread it to every major city around the world.

Also every time they go out and donate their time, services, and goods it is being live streamed so you the donator will actually be able to see in live time how the money you donate will be changing peoples lives in a positive way. This is done through the live stream app Meerkat. Click the link or enter the URLto follow the movement.

meerkatapp.co/christofurlopez 

Thank you for all of your donations everything is greatly appreciated.

Lets Raise the World!

story:
SUMMARY

Hello. My name is Dominic Renda. I am the founder, president and chief executive officer of the Oceanseed Project, a public benefit, non-profit corporation that I established following a fast paced and distinguished career in technology and media. Through our work with at-risk youth and nature, Oceanseed Project profoundly improves participant’s life trajectories along with global communities, economies and our natural world.

By raising $30,000 Oceanseed Project can access 900 students, beginning to establish their direct connection with nature. This money will help cover transportation, curriculum printing costs, headcount and field equipment.

Join us in our work and be the change that you desire! Your support directly determines the magnitude of our impact.

  1. Watch our video

  2. Make a secure online donation – see our incentives below!

  3. Like us on Facebook

  4. Spread the word about this campaign, our organization and impact

  5. Request that all your friends and family do the same

Even if you can’t contribute, you can still help by getting the word out! Make some noise about this campaign!

  1. Tell everyone you know

  2. Post signs in your office

  3. Share online, Twitter, Facebook Linkedin, etc. to everyone in your groups

  4. Use the Indiegogo share tools

  5. Appeal to your rich Uncle Ned to give now as well as including Oceanseed Project in his estate plans

SPECIFICS
INTRODUCTION

In past roles as an entrepreneur, executive and artist I have driven an array of pressing objectives for technology startups and Fortune 500 brands alike. As an advocate for youth, our natural world, human potential and global sustainability, I have been alarmed by contemporary trends in global environmental concerns, societal behavior, growing economic disparity, immobility violent crime.

Associated contemporary science is abundant, clear and the need could not be more urgent. I felt compelled to do everything possible to use this insight to profoundly improve life trajectories and that of our natural world, for current and future generations. This ambition and possibility is actualized through Oceanseed Project.

IMPACT

Specifically, science shows that a connection to the natural world enhances mental creativity, promotes wellness, creates powerful human bonds and fosters environmental stewardship, ultimately benefiting communities, businesses and economies.

Science additionally proves that the most profound impact on our communities, society and economies is attained through engaging the youngest of children and at-risk youth communities in particular, providing a societal return-on-investment of 7-10%, a figure that is now being revised and is expected to be closer to 12%.

Oceanseed Project seeks to utilize the funds raised through this campaign to do exactly that in the Santa Cruz, Monterey Bay, Pajaro River Valley, Santa Clara and Southern San Francisco Peninsula regions. With your help we can fully implement our field-based programs and begin to engage hundreds of targeted youth for a most profound and lasting impact on our communities, economies and natural world.

UNIQUE APPROACH

Our unique approach and transformative impact on individuals, communities and our world is predicated on Nobel laureate science and related research that proves to achieve these objectives programs need to be ongoing in nature, spanning a significant period of time and include a mix of experiential, self-guided and undirected experiences. Furthermore, science shows that individuals, families, communities and nature are all part of one eloquently connected Earth ecosystem system in which human citizenry is an imperative for all to live and thrive.

Oceanseed Project inspires and empowers at-risk youth by facilitating the establishment of their direct connection with our natural world through a place-based, experientially attained, understanding of and appreciation for our oceans, beaches, estuaries and watersheds, accompanying ongoing mentorship including academic guidance, discussion and exploration of family and community events. This unique approach empowers youth participants to flourish into their full and true potential, resulting in significantly improved life trajectories, economic outcomes and global environments.

Additionally, each Oceanseed Project program is lead by a designated Oceanseed Project Scientist / Naturalist / Teacher / Mentor and includes Oceanseed Project's renowned curriculum that is aligned with both the Common Core State Standards Initiative and the Next Generation Science Standards.

CURRENT PROJECTS

Current, ongoing Oceanseed Project engagements include our "Oceanseed Spouts Plus” after school program for 1st, 2nd & 3rd grade children in the California state DELAC (English Language Learners) program, “Oceanseeds Juvenile Justice,” an ongoing, in-prison program working directly with incarcerated youth in the juvenile justice system.

Working even in the most restrictive of secured environments, Oceaseed Project’s unique approach ensures that all program participants have the opportunity to establish a strong, meaningful and personal connection with our natural world be it through science, ethereally, or the arts as well as develop a strong sense of personal values for human citizenry.

ALTERNATIVE WAYS TO CONTRIBUTE

We appreciate your financial support, ongoing consideration, recommendation to everyone you know and additionally welcome your participation in these other ways.

  1. Corporate Sponsorship

  2. Fleet Donation - a late model 40 person school bus in particular

  3. Computer Equipment Donations

INCENTIVES – In addition to the amazing sense of joy, inspiration and purpose that you will receive with your generous online donation, each online donation is also accompanied by an additional incentive as our way of celebrating you, your steps into being action and contribution to making our world as great as it can be! These additional incentives are noted with each donation amount on the left.

Thank you and love from,

Oceanseed Project

Fleet Donation - a late model 40 person school bus in particular

Oceanseed Project

story:
Short Summary

I am Lindsay Starr and a soon be be senior in the fall at Wittenberg University! I am majoring in geology (Study of rocks and whatnot) (http://www5.wittenberg.edu/academics/geology.html)and a minor in geography (GIS focus). I have participated in field camps with Wittenberg, but this field experience in Juneau, Alaska is for a much longer time than a week. I will be in Alaska for two months observing and studying glaciers and their movements. This is an important adventure for me as I will get to do real outside research with real researchers! Which will totally help with graduate school applications or finding a real big kid job. Contributors will be helping me achieve my first two month field experience!

What I Need & What You Get

The Juneau Icefield Research Program cost $4800. That money is spent for living costs over the two months such as food and transportation, also for research needs and equipment. Normally the program is able to give out some sort of scholarships for student attending, but because of the government freeze on spending in the beginning of the year, JIRP is unable to give scholarships this year. 

Incentives for Donating to my project are:

$10 or more: The satisfaction that you are donating to SCIENCE!

$25 or more : The above, PLUS a postcard with an image from the field from me!

$50 or more: The above, PLUS a signed 5x7 photo from the field!

$100 or more: The above, PLUS a GoPro video uploaded to my Blog (PLUS a hand written note from the field)

$150 or more: The above PLUS five photos from the field!

$250 or more: I will use a powerpoint presentation to show your class or interest group my trip and the research that I completed while in Alaska.

If I do not reach my goal of $2000 I will not get any of the funds and will back where I started! Any amount is awesome and will be appreciated beyond your wildest dreams!

The Impact

Glaciers are indicators of climate change. They keep a record of past temperatures and precipitation and their melt impacts sea level. I’m interested in how glaciers can be used to improve our understanding of the earth as a system.

Over the past year, I’ve worked as an undergraduate researcher at Wittenberg University to research nitrate and nitrite levels in the streams near my campus. This grant helped me begin my senior thesis & I presented it at Wittenberg. I hope to use what I learn from the Juneau Icefield Research Program to improve my skills as a researcher.

I understand that I am just a undergraduate and I have a lot more learning to do, but I truly love geology. It amazes me how intricate every rock and mineral are and how they all work together to form our great planet! I am super excited for the future and where geology leads me; either graduate school or finding a super awesome job!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute - have no fear! All I ask is that you past this along to anyone and everyone you know! The more people that know about JIRP the more they can help this great program grow and reach new people! PLEASE SHARE THIS!
