story:
Root. Respond. Rewild.

Toxic Realities & Radical Remedies: A Grassroots Bioremediation Intensive is a youth response to the toxic environments we have been born into in this industrial age. Initiated by five Vancouver youth, Nicky G, Matt K, Kelsey C, Jen S, and Annah M, and with the support and commitment of grassroots remediator and educator Leila D, the Purple Thistle Center and the Purple Thistle Gardeners, this course is a step towards accepting responsibility for the land, water, and clean air that gives us life. 

This unique and innovative 3-month intensive will share grassroots bioremediation skills with youth and other passionate community members who want to become involved in the regeneration of damaged and contaminated sites in their communities; who want to work with the land to grow and gather healthy food and medicine. From fence lines to frontlines, at the heart of this course lies the fierce desire to support environmental justice struggles, decolonize space and selves, and to care for and heal the lands and waters that sustain us all.


What is Grassroots Bioremediation?

Bioremediation is the art and science of working with living systems and our fungal, bacterial and plant allies to detox and regenerate the health of contaminated lands and waters. There are different techniques used in bioremediation:

  • Microbial remediation: using microorganisms to breakdown and bind contaminants

  • Phytoremediation: using plants to extract, bind, and transform contaminants

  • Mycoremediation: working with fungi to clean up contaminated soil and water.


Grassroots bioremediation offers valuable tools and techniques for community members interested in proactively addressing the legacy of environmental pollution we’ve inherited from our industrialized civilization. Often, conventional remediation techniques, employed by government and industry, tend to focus on mechanical and chemical solutions to pollution. They are not only expensive and resource-intensive, but can also cause further damage to the environment and spread contaminants to other communities.

Grassroots bioremediation is a sustainable remediation practice utilizing low-cost techniques with a focus on working with biological interventions and living installations to address contamination at the source.

Why Should You Support This Campaign and Our Course?

 

Many of us are aware that the Earth is suffering; its life-support systems are under severe strain. Resource extraction, aging infrastructure, climate chaos and extreme energy is leading to countless environmental disasters. The toxic legacy left in the wake of our industrialized society makes finding safe places to grow healthy food and medicine increasingly difficult.

Indigenous communities, low income neighborhoods and countries in the Global South are sites too often targeted for heavy industry, dangerous energy projects, military bases and waste dumps with heightened levels of pollution. When it comes to recovering from environmental disasters and industrial accidents, these communities often receive little notification, support or effective cleanup, if any at all.

Some of us may be familiar with grassroots bioremediation. Maybe we’ve heard stories or attended a workshop where we’ve learned certain mushrooms can clean up oil spills and some plants can suck up heavy metals. But when faced with contaminated places or environmental disasters, we often struggle to translate the myths and promises of regenerative solutions into living realities. There are a lot of problems facing the planet and our communities and it can be overwhelming! Though we don't have all the answers, we've got lots to learn and its time to skill-up and start practicing, experimenting, and implementing living solutions and radical remedies!

                   

This is a unique course and the first of its kind to be offered! Grassroots bioremediation courses are hard to come by and are often expensive.  This fun, hands-on, and practical course will provide grassroots bioremediation skills to youth and other passionate community members interested in engaging in the regeneration of contaminated sites in their communities. We will work with a diversity of tools, strategies, and living allies. We will learn to facilitate detoxification and restore degraded urban soils and waters and respond in the aftermath of environmental disasters such as oil spills.

Grassroots bioremediation must be affordable and accessible, so we are working hard to offer the course at the lowest possible cost. We hope to ensure that everyone who has the heart, passion and interest in learning these rad skills can attend. And that's where we need your support! 


The Course!

Where: Purple Thistle Centre, 975 Vernon Dr, Unceded Coast Salish Territories (Vancouver)

When: January 16th - March 20th

Thursday evenings from 7pm-9pm, and several weekend day long work parties or lab skills (Feb 1-2nd, March 1, March 15th).

A total of 14 classes will be offered, with 10 weeknight classroom sessions and 3 weekend day long work parties, field trips, or hands-on intensives.

Our living lab and work parties will take place at the Purple Thistle Gardens, community gardens, and other neighbourhood sites. By starting this class in winter, we’ll get a lot of theory, scheming and dreaming under our belts just in time to put our new skills into action come spring and summer.


The Course Will Cover:

                  

  • Grassroots Bioremediation 101 + Environmental Justice and Decolonization intro

  • Uncovering and Mapping the broken landscapes, and hidden stories of Vancouver

  • Contaminants 101 (heavy metals and chemicals)

  • Soil Testing

  • Site Assessment/Reading the Land

  • Radical Mycology

  • Grassroots Mushroom Cultivation Intensive

  • Mycoremediation Installations (mycoswales, mycofilters/bunker spawn, in-vessel remediation, spore slurries, etc)

  • Microbial Remediation

  • Thermophyllic Composting, Activiely Aerated Compost Tea preparation, Efficient Microorganisms and Biochar.

  • Phytoremediation

  • Hyperaccumulators and Extracting or Immobilizing Heavy Metals with Amendments.

  • Exploring the  Role of “Weeds” and  “Invasive” Plants in Ecosystem Healing

  • Working with Biodynamic Preps, Flower and Mushroom Extracts and Essences and Other Forms of Energetic Plant Medicine.

  • Starting and Designing Grassroots Bioremediation Project – social remediation, community organizing, project design, working with bureaucracies, companies, and regulations, fundraising, etc.

  • Solutions for Water Contamination and Filtration + Daylighting Streams + Wetlands + Watershed restoration + Floating Island Construction.

  • Oil Spills 101 and grassroots bioremediation responses

  • Self-Care for Grassroots Remediators (personal protective gear, plant and mushroom allies for supporting detox and good health in contamination situations + making a personal detox and preventative medicine kit).

  • Site Transformation Work and Art Parties – Putting it all into practice, throwing down some living installations and artful interventions such as mycoremediation installations, mushroom beds, plantings, compost, making signs, and more

Students will be encouraged to undertake independent study projects that they will present at the end of the 3 month course and can be shared with the greater community. Independent projects can include, but aren’t restricted to:

  • Designing a grassroots bioremediation experiment

  • Designing a grassroots remediation project for a community or personal site

  • Making a zine, audio or video for frontline communities on topics such as grassroots bioremediation, oil spill 101, environmental health issues, common contaminants, plant and mushroom remedies for detox and community care


Main Instructor/Facilitator

Leila Darwish is a community organizer, author, educator, permaculture designer, urban gardener, and grassroots herbalist with a deep commitment to environmental justice, decolonization, food sovereignty, and to providing accessible and transformative tools for communities dealing with toxic contamination of their land and drinking water.

Over the last decade, she has worked as a community organizer for different environmental organizations and community groups in Alberta, BC and the USA on campaigns such as tar sands, fracking, nuclear energy, coal, climate justice, water protection, and more. She is a certified permaculture designer, a graduate of the Linnaea Farms Ecological Farming Program, and has also apprenticed on different organic farms across Canada and the USA. She has given workshops on grassroots bioremediation for a diversity of groups and organizations across the United States and Canada, and is the author of the new book “Earth Repair: A Grassroots Guide to Healing Toxic and Damaged Landscapes”.

For more information about Leila’s book, check out www.earthrepair.ca

Guest Teachers

Several amazing guest teachers, such as radical mycologists and mushroom cultivators, herbalists, and grassroots bioremediators, will be brought in to assist in teaching different classes throughout the 3 month course. Stay tuned for this soon to be revealed list of talented collaborators!


Where is the Money Going?

             

Your generous donations will support the course in the following ways:

  • Subsidizing course registration fees so that we can provide an affordable learning opportunity to anyone who is interested, no matter their financial situation.

  • Providing our guest teachers with honorariums and travel

  • Paying for soil testing to be done on sites we will be experimenting with bioremediation

  • Purchasing any additional tools or supplies needed for different bioremediation activities and installations

  • Printing and photocopying expenses for classroom materials


In terms of applicantions and student interest, the class is at capacity! We just need your help in reaching our financial goal so that we can officially run this course and have it be affordable and accessible to youth and other community members. The funds will also allow the class to do some really great work with living installations in our community!

And if we have any extra money….

Toxic Realities and Radical Remedies BC Workshop Tour - Spring/Summer 2014!

We are pretty thrifty people, so whatever funds are left over would allow us to take the course on the road! Yes we love road trips! And we know that there are a lot of folks in communities outside of Vancouver who would love to learn these skills and apply grassroots bioremediation to the impacted lands and waters near them. We would love to share these skills and information with other cities, towns, communities along the routes of current and proposed tar sands pipelines, near fracking operations, mines and in the middle of big agriculture.

What You Get

We really appreciate all your generosity and support! As folks reach out to help us in our goals, we want to give back to and maintain those connections! All interested donors will receive regular updates as the course progresses, as well as electronic notes, resources from the course, and tabs on the hands-on projects we will be bringing to the community. We also have lots of great gifts we'll be offering in return for your generous contributions, from books, patches, t-shirts and artwork to compost tea and herbal salves! 

You'll also receive a lot of gratitude and big big thanks from us for helping us make this rad course a reality!

Other Ways You Can Help

Linking, Liking and Sharing this project on your social networks can help take us far and wide! Please help us spread the word so we can meet our goal and offer this incredible and unique course to our community!

Big Big Love and Thank You!!
story_txt:
Root. Respond. Rewild.Toxic Realities & Radical Remedies: A Grassroots Bioremediation Intensive is a youth response to the toxic environments we have been born into in this industrial age. Initiated by five Vancouver youth, Nicky G, Matt K, Kelsey C, Jen S, and Annah M, and with the support and commitment of grassroots remediator and educator Leila
D, the Purple Thistle Center and the Purple Thistle Gardeners, this course is a step towards accepting responsibility for the land, water, and clean air that gives us life. This unique and innovative 3-month intensive will share grassroots bioremediation skills with youth and other passionate community members who want to become involved in the regeneration of damaged and contaminated sites in their communities; who want to work with the land to grow and gather healthy food and medicine. From fence lines to frontlines, at the heart of this course lies the fierce desire to support environmental justice struggles, decolonize space and selves, and to care for and heal the lands and waters that sustain us all.What is Grassroots Bioremediation?Bioremediation is the art and science of working with living systems and our fungal, bacterial and plant allies to detox and regenerate the health of contaminated lands and waters. There are different techniques used in bioremediation:
Microbial remediation: using microorganisms to breakdown and bind contaminants
Phytoremediation: using plants to extract, bind, and transform contaminants

Mycoremediation: working with fungi to clean up contaminated soil and water.


Grassroots bioremediation offers valuable tools and techniques for community members interested in proactively addressing the legacy of environmental pollution we’ve inherited from our industrialized civilization. Often, conventional remediation techniques, employed by government and industry, tend to focus on mechanical and chemical solutions to pollution. They are not only expensive and resource-intensive, but can also cause further damage to the environment and spread contaminants to other communities.Grassroots bioremediation is a sustainable remediation practice utilizing low-cost techniques with a focus on working with biological interventions and living installations to address contamination at the source.Why Should You Support This Campaign and Our Course? Many of us are aware that the Earth is suffering; its life-support systems are under severe strain. Resource extraction, aging infrastructure, climate chaos and extreme energy is leading to countless environmental disasters. The toxic legacy left in the wake of our industrialized society makes finding safe places to grow healthy food and medicine increasingly difficult.Indigenous communities, low income neighborhoods and countries in the Global South are sites too often targeted for heavy industry, dangerous energy projects, military bases and waste dumps with heightened levels of pollution. When it comes to recovering from environmental disasters and industrial accidents, these communities often receive little notification, support or effective cleanup, if any at all. story:
We raised over $15,000 from more than 200 donors! Thank you!

You can still contribute via our website at www.ourhorizon.org

Please follow our tour via Facebook and Twitter

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our Campaign

Our Horizon is a registered non-profit organization that empowers people and communities to change the world. Our first campaign is a globally unprecedented approach to climate change: we want to put warning labels on gas pump nozzles just like those on cigarette packages.

We're asking municipalities across Canada to use their licensing powers to pass our idea into law. We have a game plan to take it global from there. It's time to get real about climate change. It's time to #FaceTheChange.

  

Our Story

Founder and Executive Director Rob Shirkey has been concerned about climate change for all his life. When Rob's grandfather passed away last summer, his final words to him were "Do what you love." He left Rob a small sum of money that he used to launch Our Horizon in January of 2013. Since then, Rob has funded almost the entire project out of his own pocket and now needs your support.

 

The Cross-Canada Tour

We have conducted workshops at schools in Toronto for students to express their climate change concerns by designing their own warning labels. We also inspire participants to use their voices to make our idea real; we now have a growing list of youth who have committed to speak at Toronto City Hall when our motion is debated.

We are taking our workshops from coast to coast this fall. Our objective is to inspire youth and give them the tools they need to advocate for the idea in their own communities. In the end, youth will inspire youth: every person that does a speech to their representatives at their City Hall and shares it on YouTube will be a hero. They will receive a Climate Change Champion medal from us in recognition of their courage.

We have hired a full-time tour coordinator and have a database with the contact information of every single elementary school, high school and environmentally-minded university club in Canada. It's going to be a lot of work but we're dedicated to making this happen.

The Warning Labels

Our use of fossil fuels has dangerously altered the basic chemistry of our planet. Addressing climate change is the greatest challenge of our time.

  

The labels show the effects of climate change right in the palm of your hand. They are a catalyst. Our idea will cause some individuals to change their behaviour but, more importantly, they will result in a shift in our collective demand to allow for real action on climate change.

Your Contribution

Citizens in countries all over the world have been cognitively primed for our idea with the warning labels already on tobacco packages. The first communities to pass our by-law will set a precedent for the world to follow. This campaign is the first step in our larger vision of putting these labels on gas pumps all over the world.

Your contribution can help make this happen. With this campaign, you have the opportunity to change the course of human history. The best perk of all isn't the stuff listed to the right, it's this: you will get to tell your children and grandchildren that your contribution helped change the world.

Thank you for your support!

CANADA'S CLIMATE CHANGE HEROES CUP

We're taking Canada's Climate Change Heroes Cup with us from coast to coast. The first communities to pass our by-law will be making world history. They will be global leaders in the most challenging fight of our times and will forever be remembered on Canada's Climate Change Heroes Cup.

 

VIDEOS

#FaceTheChange: Please watch our promo video and go to OurHorizon.Org to contact your councillor. Together, we can face climate change.

INTERVIEW WITH ROB: Michelle just joined the Our Horizon Team and had a bunch of questions for her new boss Rob. Please enjoy this candid interview that explores the theory, impact and vision behind our campaign.

PECHA KUCHA TALK: Rob was invited by PechaKucha to deliver a talk using their "20 Images x 20 Seconds" format. The video explains the journey and theory behind Our Horizon’s unique approach to addressing climate change.

 

MEDIA COVERAGE

UPWORTHY: "Our Earth's ecosystem is like a giant set of lungs, and we're all guilty of filling it with second-hand smoke. Luckily, we humans already figured out an effective way to help ourselves change our habits. Check out one genius proposal..."

The Warning Label That We Never Knew We Needed Until We Saw It. September 6, 2013.

GUELPH MERCURY: "It is kids that are going to inherit the earth and you can't sell an idea on research alone," says Shirkey. "That only appeals to intellect. You've got to appeal to the heart too."  Shirkey plans to appeal to the hearts of municipal committee members by packing the room full of students."

Guelph targeted by environmental groups for gas pump warning label workshops. September 6, 2013.

DESMOG CANADA: "A wiry presence even over Skype, Shirkey speaks at breakneck pace with a lawyer’s clarity and the energy of a children’s entertainer. He is beyond earnest… Now he’s decided to take that enthusiasm on the road. On September 14, he leaves for a cross-country tour of schools."

Warning labels on gas pumps connect consumers and climate change. September 5, 2013.

MONGABAY: "Denial or ignorance means we get to avoid the problem, but it's an ineffective strategy. The problem is only going to get worse the longer we ignore it. Our labels force us to face the reality of what we're up against. After all, if we can't even honestly face our problem, what hope do we have in actually addressing it?"

Organization proposes climate change warning labels at the gas pump. September 5, 2013.

THE HUFFINGTON POST: "Our warning labels compress time to mitigate the effects of the current moment bias. They bring future consequences -- like drought, the extinction of species, and ocean acidification -- into the here and now. In doing so, they build feedback to help us transition from a maladaptive economy to an adaptive one."

Warning Labels and the Psychology of Climate Change. September 4, 2013.

MUNICIPAL WORLD: "Here’s a great new idea for municipal action on climate change: warning labels! Assuming that labels would reduce GHG emissions, can municipalities do this? We think it’s worth a try." [Article by Dianne Saxe, one of the world's leading environmental lawyers].

Can municipalities require climate warning labels on gasoline? September 3, 2013.

ERICKSON COLLEGE INTERNATIONAL: "It is Rob’s vision to create similar warning labels to be placed on gas (petrol) pumps throughout Canada, the United States, and ultimately the world"

Face The Change: An Erickson Graduate's Aim To Raise Awareness of Climate Change. August 28, 2013.

THE HUFFINGTON POST: Adam Smith Called: He Wants Warning Labels on Gas Pumps. August 22, 2013. (Article by Executive Director Rob Shirkey)

THE WILD MAGAZINE: What If a Simple Sticker Could Change the World? (Original interview only available in the USA; an international copy has been posted here). August 20, 2013.

ENVIRONMENTAL NEWS NETWORK:  Warning labels for gasoline pumps? August 20, 2013.

THE HUFFINGTON POST: Want to stop climate change, tar sands, and pipelines? Throw an intervention. August 14, 2013 (Article by Executive Director Rob Shirkey)

THE NATION: Warning: This Gasoline Is Hazardous to Your Planet. August 9, 2013.

DEUTSCHE WELLE: Gas warning labels could help reduce emissions. July 1, 2013.

THE CORD COMMUNITY EDITION: Climate Game Change. July 5, 2013.

THE RECORD: Environmental group calls for warning labels on gas pumps. June 14, 2013.

ADBUSTERS: This machine causes global warming. May 9, 2013.

TRIPLE PUNDIT: Canadian lawyer wants climate change warning labels on gas pumps. April 25, 2013.

TREE HUGGER: Health warning labels proposed for gas pump nozzles. April 15, 2013.

MACLEAN'S: Group concerned about climate change proposes warning labels for gas nozzles. April 4, 2013.

GOOD NEWS TORONTO: Local environmentalist advocates warning labels for climate change. April 1, 2013.

TORONTO STAR: Is guilt the path to serious climate action? February 22, 2013.

 

RADIO INTERVIEWS

TERRA INFORMA: Terra Informa interviews Rob on a segment for their environmental program. The interview starts at minute 2:00 and ends at 8:30. June 30, 2013.

GARY DOYLE SHOW: Gary Doyle interviews Rob on his news talk program on 570 AM News, Kitchener-Waterloo. June 14, 2013.

HUMBER RADIO: Kevin Sexton interviews Rob for Humber Radio on 96.9 FM, Toronto. May 17, 2013.

THE GREEN MAJORITY: Daryn Caister does an in-depth show with Rob entitled "Second Hand Oil" for  the Green Majority on CIUT 89.5 FM, Toronto. April 12, 2013.

BILL GOOD SHOW: Bill interviews Rob and takes calls on his news talk show on CKNW AM 980, Vancouver. April 9, 2013.

YORK UNIVERSITY: Eric Robinson interviews Rob on CHRY 105.5FM, Toronto. April 5, 2013.

FRIENDLY FIRE: Ryan Doyle and John Downs interview Rob on Toronto's CFRB Newstalk 1010. April 5, 2013.

 

MAIL-IN CONTRIBUTIONS

Please use this Indiegogo website for your contributions. If you'd rather make a contribution via cheque, please make it out to "Our Horizon Society" and mail it to: Our Horizon, 432 Queen Street East, Toronto, ON, M5A 1T4, CANADA.

 

****

Note on perks: We will make our best efforts to fulfill all perks. If we are unable to fulfill a perk (for example, if a location is too remote to visit or if a speaking event does not align with our values), we will issue a full refund less any processing fees from Indiegogo. Feel free to contact us if you have any questions before making a contribution. Thanks!

Our labels force us to face the reality of what we're up against. After all, if we can't even honestly face our problem, what hope do we have in actually addressing it?"
 Organization proposes climate change warning labels at the gas pump. September 5, 2013.
THE HUFFINGTON POST: "Our warning labels compress time to mitigate the effects of the current moment bias. They bring future consequences -- like drought, the extinction of species, and ocean acidification -- into the here and now. In doing so, they build feedback to help us transition from a maladaptive economy to an adaptive one."
Warning Labels and the Psychology of Climate Change. September 4, 2013. 
MUNICIPAL WORLD: "Here’s a great new idea for municipal action on climate change: warning labels! Assuming that labels would reduce GHG emissions, can municipalities do this? We think it’s worth a try." [Article by Dianne Saxe, one of the world's leading environmental lawyers].
Can municipalities require climate warning labels on gasoline? September 3, 2013.
ERICKSON COLLEGE INTERNATIONAL: "It is Rob’s vision to create similar warning labels to be placed on gas (petrol) pumps throughout Canada, the United States, and ultimately the world"
Face The Change: An Erickson Graduate's Aim To Raise Awareness of Climate Change. August 28, 2013.
THE HUFFINGTON POST: Adam Smith Called: He Wants Warning Labels on Gas Pumps. August 22, 2013. (Article by Executive Director Rob Shirkey)
THE WILD MAGAZINE: What If a Simple Sticker Could Change the World? (Original interview only available in the USA; an international copy has been posted here). August 20, 2013.
ENVIRONMENTAL NEWS NETWORK:  Warning labels for gasoline pumps? August 20, 2013.
THE HUFFINGTON POST: Want to stop climate change, tar sands, and pipelines? Throw an intervention. August 14, 2013 (Article by Executive Director Rob Shirkey)
THE NATION: Warning: This Gasoline Is Hazardous to Your Planet. August 9, 2013.
DEUTSCHE WELLE: Gas warning labels could help reduce emissions. July 1, 2013.
THE CORD COMMUNITY EDITION: Climate Game Change. July 5, 2013.
THE RECORD: Environmental group calls for warning labels on gas pumps. June 14, 2013.
ADBUSTERS: This machine causes global warming. May 9, 2013.
TRIPLE PUNDIT: Canadian lawyer wants climate change warning labels on gas pumps. April 25, 2013.
TREE HUGGER: Health warning labels proposed for gas pump nozzles. April 15, 2013.
MACLEAN'S: Group concerned about climate change proposes warning labels for gas nozzles. April 4, 2013.
GOOD NEWS TORONTO: Local environmentalist advocates warning labels for climate change. April 1, 2013.
TORONTO STAR: Is guilt the path to serious climate action? February 22, 2013.
 
RADIO INTERVIEWS
TERRA INFORMA: Terra Informa interviews Rob on a segment for their environmental program. The interview starts at minute 2:00 and ends at 8:30. June 30, 2013.
GARY DOYLE SHOW: Gary Doyle interviews Rob on his news talk program on 570 AM News, Kitchener-Waterloo. June 14, 2013.
HUMBER RADIO: Kevin Sexton interviews Rob for Humber Radio on 96.9 FM, Toronto. May 17, 2013.
THE GREEN MAJORITY: Daryn Caister does an in-depth show with Rob entitled "Second Hand Oil" for  the Green Majority on CIUT 89.5 FM, Toronto. April 12, 2013. 
BILL GOOD SHOW: Bill interviews Rob and takes calls on his news talk show on CKNW AM 980, Vancouver. April 9, 2013.
YORK UNIVERSITY: Eric Robinson interviews Rob on CHRY 105.5FM, Toronto. April 5, 2013.
FRIENDLY FIRE: Ryan Doyle and John Downs interview Rob on Toronto's CFRB Newstalk 1010. April 5, 2013.
 
MAIL-IN CONTRIBUTIONS
Please use this Indiegogo website for your contributions. If you'd rather make a contribution via cheque, please make it out to "Our Horizon Society" and mail it to: Our Horizon, 432 Queen Street East, Toronto, ON, M5A 1T4, CANADA.
 
****
Note on perks: We will make our best efforts to fulfill all perks. If we are unable to fulfill a perk (for example, if a location is too remote to visit or if a speaking event does not align with our values), we will issue a full refund less any processing fees from Indiegogo. Feel free to contact us if you have any questions before making a contribution. Thanks!

story:
Hi, we're Novotera. We're embarking on this Indiegogo crowdsource fundraiser to distribute 1,000 of our new CarbonStove hybrid-biochar cooking stoves to remote villages in China, Thailand, and Indonesia during fall 2012.

Over 2 billion people cook indoors with inefficient wood fires causing deforestation, climate change and, according to the World Health Organization, more than 5000 premature-deaths a day due to smoke inhalation. After two years of working with Chinese villages to develop our stoves, we have finalized the design, and our manufacturer is ready to go into production.

CarbonStove helps to:

  1. Reduce indoor cooking smoke to a minimum.
  2. Mitigate air-born soot, which is responsible for 5-10% of man-made global warming.
  3. Reduce deforestation by increasing stove efficiency; villages reported using roughly 1/3 less wood than with traditional stoves.
  4. Sequester carbon (in the form of biochar) within the soil. 
  5. Improve the soil structure and drought resistance.
  6. Improve the financial situation and living conditions of rural populations.


How Does  it Work?

The CarbonStove is a TLUD, which means "Top-lit Updraft."

With a TLUD stove, you light kindling on top of a densely packed bundle of wood in a vertical tube nested inside a larger tube. Because the airflow is restricted, the fire on top heats the wood with very little oxygen, and the result is gases come streaming out of the wood; mostly hydrogen, and carbon monoxide. The gases rise towards the top, where they encounter jets of oxygenated air drawn through the gap between the tubes. When the gases meet, they ignite and burn just like a regular, clean-burning gas stove. 

What's left once you "gasify" wood, is charcoal, which when put into the earth, is Biochar. 

Biochar is Essentially Buried Charcoal

The agricultural benefits of burying charcoal have been understood for millennia in the Far East, but in the rest of the world this ancient knowledge was forgotten. While most of the Amazon’s soils are poor and thin, there are scattered patches of deep, fertile soil called "Terra Preta". In the late 90’s these soils were shown to have been caused by natives intentionally burying charcoal thousands of years ago.

When Charcoal is created in a controlled environment for agricultural application it is called biochar. A natural soil enhancer, biochar significantly boosts plant growth and root development when used properly, improves soil water retention and permeability, reduces soil acidity, helps to retains nitrogen and phosphorus in the soil, and encourages beneficial micro-organisms. Recent biochar soil-treatment trials have shown a doubling and sometimes even a tripling of crop yields. And of course, when you mix biochar in your soil, you're sequestering carbon and thus really doing something about climate change.

What Makes Our CarbonStove So Unique:

CarbonStove was designed to use locally purchased firewood, so unlike other available biochar-producing stoves, ours does not require villagers to re-cut their wood. 
The CarbonStove is a hybrid. It is a fully functional TLUD, but since a TLUD stove sometimes only burns for an hour, we added a door making it similar to a “Rocket Stove”, a more traditional high-efficiency stove being used in development work.  The benefit of this hybrid is that once there's no gas left in wood, villagers can add as more wood. This allows a family to cook for hours, even once the initial gasification is complete. 

CarbonStove Economics:

Biochar stoves provide villagers with the opportunity to earn extra money. A Carbonstove can produce one Kilo of charcoal for each three Kilos of wood fuel, both of which sell for three RMB in parts of China. The stove thus produces a valuable product that can be used by the owner for further cooking, for sale, or for soil improvement. Wood that a villager would have burnt anyway for cooking can thus provide further benefit without extra cost, other than the stove. Ideally, farmers will bury the biochar in the soil and reap the long term economic benefits of bigger and healthier crops, but whatever the user chooses to do, the economic and health benefits of producing biochar with cooking stoves are significant.

The stoves presently cost 25$ to produce in Kunming China, but shipping to other more remote customers is our biggest hurdle. Shipping costs vary greatly depending on the customer’s location.

Marketing:

For the past two years we have been in China testing out our stoves, getting feedback from villagers and modifying the stoves to better suit people's needs. The thing which first impresses villagers is how our fire looks and acts like a gas fire. They like the high heat which it gives off as well as the lack of smoke.

We employ a range of distributors, including village leaders. Such people are well situated to distribute due to their position of respect within the community, and their connections with other nearby communities. Cookstove dealers as well as pot and pan sellers are another important type of distributor, as are restaurant owners. Sometimes local farmers also see the business opportunity although they often need more credit support.

WHAT WE NEED:
We are heading back to China this autumn, and with our finalized design our goal is to get a thousand of our new stoves into the hands of rural people in East Asia before the year is out. The people we have shown the stoves to on previous trips are interested in buying them, but they often can't afford the $35 it costs to manufacture the stove and ship it to a remote area. That is why we decided to appeal to the crowd and start an Indiegogo campaign.  For every $25 that is donated, we will sell a stove for $15, a price rural people say they can afford. That $15 will cover the transport costs and if there is any leftover, 100% of this will be used to subsidize the production of more stoves.

About Novotera:
Our mission is to promote the use of biochar-based technologies to help governments, companies, and individuals improve their carbon footprint while at the same time improving air, soil, water quality and living conditions of the rural poor.

story:
My name is Steve Fox - I am an Eagle Scout.  I want to support all those who end up embroiled in the mess that is the current Boy Scouts of America policy on homosexuality, especially those who started out in innocence, only to be denied because of their own personal growth and self-knowledge.
 
I want to buy secondary market-available Eagle Scout Awards for those young men who, in all innocence, join the BSA and work their way to Eagle only to have it denied.  Denied because they discover a truth about their sexual orientation and do not hide it, but openly acknowledge it.  I am looking at the first recipient - Ryan Andersen, who recently had his Eagle application withheld and was released from membership in Scouting because he came out as gay.  I want $100-$200 to obtain the appropriate award paraphernalia and to ship it to him with as many Eagle Scout signatures as possible to welcome Ryan into the fold of our wings as a fellow Eagle.
 
It is my sincerest wish that the BSA end it's discriminmatory policies towards homosexuals and accept ALL American youth and leaders, regardless of their orientation.

Please keep your eyes on sites like change.org in order to add your voice to our chorus.  Please write your local BSA council or one of the national board members to encourage this change.  And accept all Eagles as Eagles.

 

Image by  Rennett Stowe

story:
My Story

Howdy, y'all! I have been selected to participate in Mizzou's Alternative Spring Break, a campus organization that sends groups of 12 students around the country to places in need of volunteers.  ASB gets its name for following a strict alcohol and drug free policy.

The Impact

My particular group is traveling to Delaplane, Virginia to help restore hiking trails from winter erosion; activities include clearing trails of debris, maintaining trail corridors, removing water bars and relocating some trails.  We will also assist with the creation of a new nature trail in a newly constructed picnic area.  My group is planning to take a day trip to Washington D.C., which I have never visited before!

What I Need & What You Get

I am very excited about going on this trip, and I hope that you can help me get there!  My group organizers have calculated that every person needs to raise additional money so that we can travel from Missouri to Virginia and back again.  As such, I would really appreciate if you could make a small donation to allow me to experience the spring break of my dreams!  Since I have already paid for an American Hiking Association membership and my share of the cabin that we are renting, your money would go directly to the cost of transportation and food for the week.  I will appreciate any amount given to my trip!

Stay Updated

I will be blogging about my experiences preparing for this trip at my personal website over the next few months so that everyone who donates can be involved with the trip.  You are also welcome to check out Mizzou ASB's trip blog.  As always, you are welcome to contact me directly if you have any questions about the trip or this website.

story:
Our Story

By: Bobby, Krow, Blanca, Casey
Occupy the Dance Floor: Urban Music for Urban Ag is an ongoing project to hold a series of music events (dance parties) to raise funds and consciousness for a new political action committee supporting young activists who want to work on issues of urban agriculture, start-up job-creating small-scale organic farms, food-processing ventures, environmental issues such as mining and watershed quality, and other related community campaigns.  The focus area of this committee will start with central Wisconsin. Our base will be the low-income folks of our region.

This funding campaign is to provide funds to get the ball rolling for our first such event on January 14th, at Kristinâ€™s in Stevens Point. Weâ€™ll have both live bands and performing DJs as well as video projection artists.  In order to have a successful event we want to pay the talent fairly and there will be rental costs for the sound equipment and lighting. It turns out this equipment is not cheap to procure, even when you rent it for a one-time event.

Good Grief ("cushion punk")
Back Alley Blossoms (bluegrass, etc.)
Shaye Mystery (solo indie act)
Free the Turtles (post-everything percussion)

DJ AnonyMouse
& Friends (call us if you want to play, hey)

If this campaign succeeds, we plan to use proceeds above expenses to begin funding the work of activists doing door-to-door canvassing as well as getting around the state of Wisconsin to attend hearings on legislation, and do voter education. We may initiate referendum campaigns and efforts to strike bad laws from the statutesâ€“those which prohibit or interfere with our mission of building sustainable urban agriculture that can affordably feed all our low-income people (a demographic group that keeps growing by leaps and bounds unfortunately).

We hope youâ€™ll like our little proposal.  You donâ€™t have to attend the dance party but if you can donate a small amount,, it will be as if youâ€™re there anyway. And weâ€™ll acknowledge your contribution happily.

The Impact

We think that having an action committee can accomplish some things to advance urban agriculture, small-scale organic farms, and do-it-ourselves job creation which not-for-profit organizations are sometimes restricted from doing.  For example, taking part in campaigns to remove restrictions from local ordinances and zoning regulations.  For example, let's legalize the formation of eco-villages rather than letting them remain prohibited on the law books.


What We Need & What You Get 

Where it says DONATION (OVER TO THE RIGHT) highlight the "100" and just put what you can afford.

We need you to dig into your e-pocket (but not too deeply) and come up with what you think is a fair donation. If you can attend the January 14th party in Stevens Point, think of it as your ticket.

If not able to attend, like if you live 1,000 miles away, think of your donation making possible a small effort to improve things--and perhaps in a short time, your community can take up this do-it-yourself approach to politically enabling sustainable urban ag in your area.  In return, we'll put on our thinking caps and come up with some sort of "perk" you might get.

Other Ways You Can Help

Without "spamming" people with unwanted messages, perhaps you can spread this idea to social networks in which you take part.

story:
Worm Poop and Charcoal!

An article published by the International Biochar Institute at Cornell University claims that we need to bury 2.2 billion tons of carbon in the soil every year until 2054 to restore our atmospheric CO2 levels to 2004 conditions. If every gardener improves their soil with biochar this will have a big impact on climate change. Biochar alone can have some bad side effects in your soil, but when combined with the rich organic beneficial microorganisms in vermicompost the results have been remarkable.

For over ten years I have been retired and promoting the conversion of organic waste with medium-sized vermiculture for the urban gardener. Sales of my vermicompost at Farmers Markets barely covered the cost of production. I wrote a book "Beyond Compost" that has been translated into "Mas Alla del Compost". I have told the story to garden clubs and schools. A year ago I learned about "biochar", or horticultural charcoal, and the benefits observed in Brazil for thousands of years (Terra Preta del Indios) and started a company to blend these ingredients into "BioPreta".

During 2012 my wife and I travelled around Michigan selling our 5-quart "TeaPot" to indoor garden supply stores. I attended many more Farmers Markets and found that most gardeners had not heard of "biochar". The need for education was obvious. We sold enough to break even, in spite of the rising costs of transportation.

This week, my largest customer asked me to provide free samples to hand out to hundreds of indoor gardeners at a conference where they will have a booth. People will travel long distances to this conference and there will be over 1000 participants who are passionate about growing plants indoors. The experiences growers have had who have added one-cup of "BioPreta" to a cubic foot of potting mix are remarkable, and we believe these small one-cup samples will launch a large demand for biochar and vermicompost.

It will be a serious financial strain for us to provide these free samples, but your help to support us will be very much appreciated and has the potential to make a big difference for our grandkids and yours.

Look up the subject of biochar on YouTube (The Promise of Biochar, and others). Read about it in the National Geographic. Mention this unique product to your friends and fellow gardeners. Maybe they could help with a donation, as well.

Thanks, in advance.

story:
Short Summary

Hi My Name is Matt Wright and I am the Managing Director of ShoppaBox Limited.  I have spent the last 15 years buying and selling products on Shopping TV and through Mail Order, Internet & Printed Media.  Tired of the corporate life and wanting to make a positive impact on the world I decided to do something about it…

My product is called MyBuddy-Box...  Truly A Box For Life!  (www.mybuddy-box.com) Based on an original 1984 award winning version invented by my father but never commercialised I wanted to start my own business and felt I could update and improve the original design and its functionality to address the worldwide environmental concerns over plastic environmental pollution, especially the pollution caused by discarded single use plastic carriers.  I am a start-up business and have just occupied a small manufacturing unit in Peterborough here in the UK where this British designed product is now manufactured by me from 100% recycled plastic waste.

So Here’s My Pitch…. 

“ Did You Know That More Than 8 Billion (58,000 Tonnes) Of  Polluting Carriers Are Dumped In The UK Each Year?  Surely This Has To Stop?  What We Need Is To Mobilise An Army Of Everyday Heroes !! “

May I introduce a way to dramatically reduce demand for those billions of environmentally unfriendly (but useful) humble carriers which – when dumped – will kill wildlife, pollute our landscape, rivers and seas and create a dangerous legacy for generations to come as they do not degrade over time?

 “MyBuddy-Box” ... Truly A Box For Life - A Perfect Solution ! “

So serious is this worldwide threat to our environment that people here in the UK are urging our government to levy a 10-20pence tax in England (already introduced in Wales and most recently in Northern Ireland) for each carrier given away by supermarkets and other retailers in an attempt to force us to change our behaviour.  I think MyBuddy-Box could be part of an alternative practical solution.  Your involvement will be a game changing positive step to address this growing disaster.

“Is It Really Possible To Re-Invent The Wheel ... Or Box ?  ABSOLUTELY ! !”

MyBuddy-Box is British designed and made in the UK from 100% recycled waste plastic and is 100% recyclable and will last a lifetime .. guaranteed!.

“So Many Uses ! “

MyBuddy-Box can be used for your grocery shopping, laundry, filing, storage or many other practical everyday uses.   It’s a simple, easy-to-use, reliable folding box and is incredibly durable and strong yet lightweight, weighing around 800gms, it can carry up to 20kg! Following the principles of origami, it folds down from a rigid box into a chic, contemporary and desirable ‘briefcase’ when not in use.  The secret to its strength is the ‘living hinge’ which means it can be safely folded up and down tens of thousands of times, enabling MyBuddy-Box to be guaranteedfor a lifetime!

“Using it For Grocery Shopping?”

Just hang it on the trolley as you shop the store and at checkout simply open in seconds, place in the trolley and fill.  If you have a lot of shopping, you can safely stack one on top of another in the trolley to wheel back to your car.  When home, empty and simply fold down ready for your next shopping trip or to use around the home.

 

So Why Do I Need Your Help??

At the moment I am personally producing each box by hand in an industrial unit in Peterborough – although I am producing a high quality product it is not very cost effective and is keeping the retail price higher than I believe it should be – with your help I can buy new machinery to be able to mass produce these boxes here in the UK, not only bringing the cost down making it affordable for everyone, but also creating new UK jobs for local people.

With your help I can centralise production of all of the components taking out cost and the environmental damage of shipping multiple parts from multiple locations – this will make production cheaper, more efficient and ultimately bring the price of MyBuddy-Box down so there are no excuses for everyone not to own at least one!  This will not only take out 1,000s of tonnes of plastic waste from landfill, but will also help stop the waste and pollution of single use carrier bags – together we can make a difference!

 

What I Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise £60,000 to purchase two semi automatic ultrasonic welding machines to weld each box much more cost effectively into the super strong finished product here in the UK (each box currently requires 16 individual welds).  Once we have the production streamlined we can not only address the UK’s plastic pollution problem but take on the world – this truly is a product with no boundaries and could make such a difference to the worldwide pollution problems!

As a thank you for your help I would like to offer some exciting perks for you:-

£1 Donation - I will send you a special offer code allowing you, your friends and families to order MyBuddy-Box at a 10% discount with no limit to the number you can order.

£5 Donation – I will send you a unique personal special offer code that will give you 10% discount on every purchase AND I will also give you £5 back for every 5 boxes sold using your unique code.

£15 Donation – I will send you a unique personal special offer code which will give you 20% discount on every purchase AND I will also give you £5 back for every 5 boxes sold using your unique code.

£30 Donation – This is where it gets really interesting….  I will send you two MyBuddy-Boxes AND I will send you a unique personal special offer code which will give you 20% discount on every purchase AND I will also give you £5 back for every 5 boxes sold using your unique code AND if your code is used for 10 boxes or more I will double up your commission to £2 per box!!!

£150 Donation – I will send you Twelve! Yes Twelve! MyBuddy-Boxes AND I will send you a unique personal special offer code which will give you 20% discount on every purchase AND I will also give you £5 back for every 5 boxes sold using your unique code AND if your code is used for 10 boxes or more I will double up your commission to £2 per box!!!

£300 Donation – I will invite you to my factory to come and make your own MyBuddy-Box – I will show you how it is made and tell you the story of my amazing journey so far – along with that you will receive all of the extra perks of the £150 donation and to top it off I’ll even take you out for a nice cold beer!  (or glass of wine if you are sophisticated!)

Please note for any donations outside of the UK for the £30 and upwards perks I will have to ask for an extra donation of £25 to cover international courier charges.

Estimated delivery of perks within 30 days of the completion of the funding round.

 

The Impact

You really can help me in many ways – firstly in bringing the production cost down to reduce the selling cost, so making it a no-brainer for everyone to use – secondly by spreading the word – it is a brand new and unique product and very few people know it exists – everyone who has seen it and used it loves it and I am sure you will too – please help spread the word in any way you can – word of mouth, Twitter, Facebook, Newspaper & Magazine Articles any way you can!  With your help we can take MyBuddy-Box worldwide reducing plastic waste, pollution and the massive environmental impact that comes with it.

I have spent my whole life working with good products and I know one when I see it – the challenge I have now is raising awareness and only people power can really do that – please become an Every Day Hero – use MyBuddy-Box – love it, need it and share it!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I am sure - like me - you can see what a great idea this is and the positive impact it can have not only on your lives but on worldwide pollution – if you can’t donate to the cause at this point don’t worry but please help spread the word, tell your friends, your family, your colleagues – anyone that will listen – they can see the whole story on my website www.mybuddy-box.com– Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, write an article about us, add us to your blog, write about is in your newspaper or magazine – I will genuinely appreciate any help you can give!

 

So What Happens If I Don’t Get All The Funding I Need?

Firstly I don’t buy all the equipment I need and it takes longer to bring the cost and selling price down.

Secondly I continue living in a tent eating nuts and berries while taking no salary so I can plough every penny back into the business.

Thirdly I may have to list my 3 beautiful children on Ebay to raise the cash I need to get this amazing product worldwide…..

With your help we can make this a success and reduce plastic waste and pollution worldwide!
story_txt:
Short Summary

story:
Short Summary

I am a resident of Northridge, CA, in the heart of the San Fernando Valley (near CSUN). I've lived here most of my life and recently came across some information about our local environment (and the environment of our country at large), which was of great concern to me. Allegations made by several experts in the fields of meteorology, environmental science, and geo-engineering, contend that weather modification efforts in CA are resulting in alarming levels of heavy metals, in micronized form, raining down on us every day.

Here are my two sources:

"What In The World Are They Spraying?"

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jf0khstYDLA

"Why In The World Are They Spraying?"

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mEfJO0-cTis

The scientists in the video stated that the best time to collect a sample is on a rainy day after a heavy "spray day". So I followed some online instructions on how to collect rainwater and recently (5/5/13) captured about a half-inch of rain and consolidated it into a vessel containing about 1 pint of liquid.

I contacted a local lab to test it, but the cost was prohibitive ($75 per each element; aluminum, barium, and selenium). I asked if he could swing a discount for a concerned citizen, and he said couldn't do it, but he suggested I contact a local university, which led me to CSUN. After several requests I have reached the conclusion that they [CSUN] are not willing or able to help me; which is what has led me to indiegogo.com and to YOU.

It is understood that there are many other more worthy causes to support on indiegogo.com as opposed to helping some "conspiracy-analyst" confirm data, but I am hoping that you might share my concern for this potentially catastrophic practice that is going on right over our heads every day.

In advance, I thank you for your consideration of funding this project, and I'm looking forward to working with you in verifying or dispelling these horrific claims.

What We Need & What You Get

So here's the deal: The test(s) for each of the three heavy metals (Aluminum, Barium, Strontnium), at $75 per, will cost a total of $225. The minimum amount indigogo will allow me to campaign for is $500, which is more than twice what is needed. I have chosen the "Flexible Funding" option, which allows me to keep the funds raised even if they don't meet my goal, at a rate of a 9% fee (4% if I do).

If the goal is reached (or exceeded), the funds will be used to assist in presenting the lab results to local elected representatives (City, State, Federal), also known as "lobbying". Funds will be used to supplement income for the day(s) taken off of work to do so, and for travel expenses. It is also planned to contact Ana Garcia, an investigative reporter at NBC News LA, to present the findings. Additionally the results will be shared "press release-style" to many other news media outlets across the country.

In sum, what you'll get is the truth; and if that truth turns out to be as horrific as I suspect, you will have somebody fighting for your very life!

The Impact

The goal here is to do much more than raise a little money to run some lab tests. On a larger scale, the goal is to stop weather modifaction efforts over California and eventually nation-wide. The biggest benefit is that we will all cease to be bombared by heavy metals. Perhaps the ever-increasing rates of cancer will begin to recede; or the number of children born with autism will begin to fall. Who knows?

I have experience in making an impact in my community. From 2001 through 2009, I helped safely deliver nearly 45,000 intoxicated drivers home in their own vehicles, free of charge, across the State of California, when I co-founded and operated the Designated Drivers Association. During that time I also successfuly lobbied for an amendment to California law to allow us to conduct background checks of our prospective drivers through the CA Department of Justice.

Since that time I helped to identify and shut down the "Overdraft Protection" racket being run by Bank of America, educating many in the process as to how to recover their stolen money from the bank(s). Here's the incriminating evidence: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hIR0unK2aYE

I've always been one to stand up to bullies; one to protect those who are unable to to protect themselves. In this case, there are various "bullies" involved in what is most likely a deadly practice agaisnt an unsuspecting, unprotected, public. And I'm here to put a stop to that. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute money (believe me, I know), but that doesn’t mean you can’t help!

Share this campaign with your friends on Facebook and other social media sites. Send an email to your friends and family, or post a video about it on youtube or Vimeo. You can even come join me at an upcoming LA City Council meeting when I present the data. And as always, please remember to use Indiegogo's share tools!

And that’s all I have to say 'bout that.

story:
Your support will allow us to take advantage of land gifts worth nearly $2,000,000 that would permanently protect islands in the Great Lakes watershed

AMERICAN FRIENDS OF CANADIAN LAND TRUSTS (www.afoclt.org) is a US charity that protects Canada's unique natural heritage cherished by people around the world. It achieves its mission through partnerships with Canadian conservation organizations. The directors are  from Canada and the US. They share a passion for Canada's most scenic and ecologically significant landscapes.

Our CONSERVE THE GREAT LAKES campaign will underwrite preservation of some of the most beautiful and undeveloped of the 32,000 islands in the Great Lakes. Islands are fragile environments that often are home to rare species. They are also highly sought after sites for vacation homes, particularly in areas that are popular with summer visitors. As more and more people are attracted to the Great Lakes' cool, clear waters for sailing, kayaking, fishing, swimming and camping islands are increasingly important for public enjoyment.

Happily, some Great Lakes islands are owned by families who want to permanently preserve these special places. They want to leave a legacy of clean water, protected plants and animals, and undeveloped lands for generations to come. By donating their land to American Friends of Canadian Land Trusts these generous individuals can achieve their conservation dreams, and give us all an important gift. Our campaign provides our organization with the funding to accept ownership of at least two islands, with a market value of close to $2,000,000 USD.

CAMPAIGN DETAILS:

  • $20,000 will cover the costs of completing the donations of islands in the Ontario portion of the Great Lakes that have been offered to American Friends of Canadian Land Trusts.
  • Every donated dollar secures over $80 in contributed land value.
  • Canadian conservation organizations are also contributing funds to permanently manage the donated islands, further leveraging your gift.
  • All contributed funds will be used to advance land and water conservation in the Great Lakes, regardless of how much or how little is raised through our campaign

WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL ACCOMPLISH

  • Protecting islands prevents future development and accompanying damage to the natural treasures of the Great Lakes.
  • Our work exemplifies bi-national cooperation to conserve globally important resources.
  • Your gift advances an innovation in philanthropy by facilitating very valuable land donations.
  • American Friends of Canadian Land Trusts and its partner organizations have already received five land gifts in the Ontario watershed of the Great Lakes (and six other gifts in other Canadian provinces) so this is a proven conservation mechanism.
  • Visit our website, www.afoclt.org, for more information on American Friends of Canadian Land Trusts

PLEASE SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN WITH OTHERS:

  • The Great Lakes comprise the largest freshwater system on earth! They are valuable to everyone. Anyone can help.
  • 84% of the surface water in the Americas is in the Great Lakes. Tell people who will understand the importance.
  • Indiegogo's share tools will help you spread the word

THANK YOU!

story:
A few weeks ago I participated in the Mountain Mobilization with RAMPS (Radical Action for Mountain People's Survival) in protest of mountaintop removal strip mining - an extremely destructive means of coal extraction occurring across Appalachia and endangering communities, people's health, and the beautiful, mountainous ecology of the region.  I was arrested along with 19 others on the Hobet coal mine in Lincoln county, West Virginia on July 28 and charged with trespassing. I was held for 10 days in Western Regional Jail with a $25,000 surety bail, and released early August after a court hearing where I was offered a plea deal of a fine and a binding promise to not trespass on mine property in West Virginia for one year.  Before the action I thought very hard about what risks I was willing to take and what possible repercussions they would have to my other plans and I went into this as confident with my decision and aware of potential consequences as I think I will ever be.
 
This was a very hard experience in many ways, especially as some of my fellow activists faced some very legitimate police brutality, but it was also a very empowering one.  The trust and communication that was established between the people who participated was incredible and the support offered by my fellow comrades within the jail and folks on the outside made me feel as safe as possible in such an oppressive and violent setting. (There's been a lot of news coverage, so if you want more information check out rampscampaign.org).
 
As to why I felt it was important to take this action now, I have been working hard for a while now on anti-fracking activism and over the course of the summer I was blown away by solidarity and support offered to this fight by people across the US, especially many from RAMPS in Appalachia.  The argument has been made that natural gas is the "cleaner" alternative to coal and the increased drilling and use of natural gas has been a contributing factor to the decline in coal use.  I believe whole-heartedly that the process of fracking for natural gas extraction is just as socially and environmentally detrimental as any other extractive industry and is a pivotal fight for this movement as a whole and I believe it is my duty to fight this in my home state.  However, I don't think we can ignore the devastation that is occurring in Appalachia and the urgency to address that because we are all in this movement together.  My experience in West Virginia has only strengthened my resolve to continue using nonviolent direct action as a tactic to prevent fracking from occurring in NYS and to fight the drilling in Pennsylvania. 
 
I am working to raise the additional $364 I need to cover my fees, but I am also hoping to help buffer the costs of the court fees of others I was arrested with.
story_txt:
A few weeks ago I participated in the Mountain Mobilization with RAMPS (Radical Action for Mountain People's Survival) in protest of mountaintop removal strip mining - an extremely destructive means of coal extraction occurring across Appalachia and endangering communities, people's health, and the beautiful, mountainous ecology of the region.  I was arrested along with 19 others on the Hobet coal mine in Lincoln county, West Virginia on July 28 and charged with trespassing. I was held for 10 days in Western Regional Jail with a $25,000 surety bail, and released early August after a court hearing where I was offered a plea deal of a fine and a binding promise to not trespass on mine property in West Virginia for one year.  Before the action I thought very hard about what risks I was willing to take and what possible repercussions they would have to my other plans and I went into this as confident with my decision and aware of potential consequences as I think I will ever be.
 
This was a very hard experience in many ways, especially as some of my fellow activists faced some very legitimate police brutality, but it was also a very empowering one.  The trust and communication that was established between the people who participated was incredible and the support offered by my fellow comrades within the jail and folks on the outside made me feel as safe as possible in such an oppressive and violent setting. (There's been a lot of news coverage, so if you want more information check out rampscampaign.org).
 
As to why I felt it was important to take this action now, I have been working hard for a while now on anti-fracking activism and over the course of the summer I was blown away by solidarity and support offered to this fight by people across the US, especially many from RAMPS in Appalachia.  The argument has been made that natural gas is the "cleaner" alternative to coal and the increased drilling and use of natural gas has been a contributing factor to the decline in coal use.  I believe whole-heartedly that the process of fracking for natural gas extraction is just as socially and environmentally detrimental as any other extractive industry and is a pivotal fight for this movement as a whole and I believe it is my duty to fight this in my home state.  However, I don't think we can ignore the devastation that is occurring in Appalachia and the urgency to address that because we are all in this movement together.  My experience in West Virginia has only strengthened my resolve to continue using nonviolent direct action as a tactic to prevent fracking from occurring in NYS and to fight the drilling in Pennsylvania.

story:
Our Story

1 out of every 20 babies die from illness such as diarrhea in Kiribati.  That's unacceptably high for an illness that is treatable and preventable.

  • Hi, I'm Carol Armstrong, Founder of The Island Rescue Project. We are a small group of passionate volunteers who are working to improve the lives of babies in Kiribati. 
  • Babies are defenseless and need our protection.  But we need your help to do this.
  • The water supply of Kiribati is rainwater that seeps underground through the porous coral and forms a bubble of fresh water that they draw from through wells. Unfortunately, everything else above ground also leaches through to the water supply: pig droppings, toilet pit leakage and other decaying material. Their polluted water is a potential source of disease.
  • Clean water is essential. Without mountains or rivers, rain is the only source of water and sometimes there is drought. We need to harvest water from the sea through industrial sized solar de-salination panels and home sized units.
  • The main island of Tarawa is approximately 16 km squared, with a population of more than 50,000 people. 
  • Sometimes when a baby is born, there is not enough water at the hospital to wash the baby clean.
  • Our team is ready to travel to the islands to introduce water purification strategies, water storage plus education and remedies for diarrhoea.

Do you know that just $30 will provide safe clean water to a child for 3 years or more? Just $10 per year or approximately 20 cents a week. You can make this real for a young child by donating $30 for a Lifestraw personal water filter, which will filter our 99.99% of bacteria, virus and parasites. Help us take a swag of these Lifestraws to Kiribati please? See our demo video next . . 

 

WATCH us drink dirty water with horse poop in it!

Hope you have a few laughs with us as we demonstrate one way we plan to create safe drinking water for Kiribati.

                                        

Listen in to my interview on Pacific Beat - ABC News Radio Australia.

http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/pacific/radio/program/pacific-beat/water-purification-plan-to-cut-kiribati-baby-toll/1315288

                   


What We Need & What You Get

We have raised some funds already but we need your help to achieve our goals:

  • We need to raise $27,000 to purchase items we need. We want to build affordable solar water de-salination home kits and purchase water storage tanks for strategic places on the islands. The sun and sea water are free and abundant.
  • For your support and contribution you can earn some nice perks such as t-shirts, organic insect repellent, personal water filters, solar lamps, personalized videos of our work in the islands mentioning you by name, opportunities for major donors to travel to the islands and see our work first hand, naming rights to water tanks and de-salination units - great for your business social responsibility. All contributors will have their name on our website supporters page.
  • All donations will reach the people who need it. We have diarrhea remedies, water purifiers, solar lamps and everyday needs like soap and insect repellent to take in. However, water is the key issue and we really need your help to purchase several rain water tanks be most effective. Water resources are stretched to the limit now and the future looks grim. An El Nino effect is predicted this coming season. Disease, such a s cholera, is a real concern if water quality continues to decline. 

  • The Island Rescue Project has had some rain water tanks generously donated for Kiribati. We just have to pay the shipping which is not cheap to a remote area like Kiribati. If you can help with a donation $5 or $10 or more, your name will be painted on the side of the tanks as a kind friend. You will be sent a photo of your name on the tank and your name will be listed on the supporters webpage. Importantly, you will be helping tremendously.

  • Follow our blog and facebook page to keep up with what's happening.

                                    


                          

                    Drawing water from a well on the main island of Tarawa 


          

We will be teaching the islanders how to make family sized solar water desalination units which will provide their daily drinking water.


Your Impact

YOU can be an honorary member of our team. If you would like a certificate with your name on it . . email us and share with us how you contributed. 

  • The success of our project will be meaningful to other areas of the world as we demonstrate it's affordability, effectiveness and that it can be duplicated.
  • YOU can help make this happen! You are an integral part of our project.
  • You can rest assured that we have no high overheads or "fat cat" salaries, and we personally take the aid to the people on the ground and implement the programs.

                                     


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. 
  • We want this video to go viral in a BIG WAY!
  • Share with your friends and contacts on all your social media with the Indiegogo share tools!

                          

                         

                              A big heartfelt thank you from me, Carol

story:
WE REACHED OUR FUNDING GOAL!! If anyone is still able to donate, all additional proceeds will go directly towards printing costs enabling us to make copies of the guide available for local schools and environmental organizations! Thank you everyone so much for making this project possible!


The Project

The transboundary Grenadine islands are divided between the small island developing states (SIDS) of St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Grenada, and derive their economies largely from foreign tourism and fisheries. These 50+ islands and cays (the largest of which is only 32 km2) are biologically rich and diverse, yet extremely fragile and vulnerable to environmental change and developmental pressures. In an area where there is an increasingly intense demand for such little space, we strive to encourage both foreign and community-driven stewardship of species and their habitats. To do this, we are in the process of creating a comprehensive, user-friendly avian field guide, which includes scientific and local ecological knowledge (LEK) and folklore from Grenadine citizens, and showcases a collection of photographs taken within the Caribbean. This guide will be a valuable resource for training local bird monitors, educating the general public, promoting sustainable tourism initiatives, enhancing the overall conservation and management of Grenadine resources, and will be useful to both locals and foreigners with an interest in the avifauna of the region.

Specific goals for this project are to:

  • Preserve LEK and cultural heritage unique to the Grenadine islands;
  • Instill a sense of pride, ownership, and community-driven stewardship for the natural resources of the Grenadines;
  • Educate tourists about the natural history of the region, while promoting Grenadines-specific environmentally conscious and sustainable tourism initiatives;
  • Produce a valuable resource for local participation in conservation and management initiatives (e.g. monitoring) by compiling several regionally specific multi-disciplinary datasets; and
  • Continue the existing momentum of participatory research and community outreach in the region.

We are very grateful for the assistance provided to us thus far by BirdsCaribbean (formerly the Society for the Conservation and Study of Caribbean Birds) and Environmental Protection in the Caribbean (EPIC), as well as towards all of the photographers who have graciously donated images featured in the guide. For more information about this project, the Grenadines, and birds, please visit our website: Birds of the Transboundary Grenadines or contact us directly at grenadinesbirds@gmail.com.

What We Need

This project is an entirely volunteer-driven effort that has been underway for over a year. Existing datasets, including a comprehensive list of birds, their descriptions and photos, have been compiled into a near-complete draft of the field guide. We believe that the success of this project however, lies in the documentation and incorporation of local ecological knowledge (LEK) to ensure that the guide is truly representative of the culture of the Grenadines, as well as useful to its citizens. To do this, we will conduct a two-week LEK collection effort, involving meetings with individuals and small groups spanning the nine—distinctly unique—inhabited islands, of the transboundary Grenadines. Themes we wish to explore include population trends, behavior, range and distributions, as well as local folklore about birds (e.g. notable birding spots and unique stories from the perspectives of local citizens). As a volunteer-run project, we need financial support to enable us to complete this final stage!  Your generous donations will cover costs associated with travel to and within the islands, and room and board expenses during the two-week LEK collection.

During this time, we would also like to take the opportunity to share our own knowledge of avian conservation and management issues by providing a complimentary workshop for locals on the adverse effects of marine debris, while introducing creative and locally feasible strategies to address the issue. Marine debris, an issue in which plastics predominate, is distributed throughout the world's oceans, arriving at even the most remote beaches and islands. It has been shown to cause injury and mortality to over 260 marine wildlife species worldwide (particularly seabirds) through entanglement, smothering, and ingestion. Although there are annual beach clean-up events on some islands in the Grenadines, the coastal areas continue to be cluttered with marine debris. Combining our interests in avian conservation and community outreach, we will host a workshop with local handicraft vendors to both demonstrate techniques and facilitate discussions on how to incorporate marine plastics and beach debris into marketable handicrafts directed at the tourism industry. This workshop is intended to provide incentives for local stewardship of marine and coastal areas, while simultaneously improving the livelihoods of locals.

We are also actively securing funds to print these guides. Although partial funding to print the final draft of the guide has been secured, any money that we raise over our goal will enable us to print more guides, and to provide Grenadine locals involved in this project with free/affordable copies. The balance on these additional printing costs is not included in our funding goal at this time.

The Team

Juliana Coffey, BA, MREM (Project Lead, Ethnobiologist/ Ornithologist): Juliana lived on Union Island in 2011 while working as the Marine and Coastal Coordinator at the Sustainable Grenadines Inc. through the Canadian International Development Association program (CIDA). While in the Grenadines, she liaised extensively with local stakeholders and community groups and was primarily involved in marine spatial planning workshops, and the Caribbean Waterbird Census (CWC). She is an ethnobiologist with a focus on seabirds, local and traditional ecological knowledge (LEK/TEK) and experienced in participatory co-management of resources within Canada and the Caribbean. Juliana is currently researching tropical seabird movements and Indonesian fishers' TEK in the Timor Sea, Indian Ocean.

Alison DeGraff, BA (Project Coordinator, Ethnocartographer/Graphic Designer): Aly lived in the Grenadines (Union, 2011–12; Mayreau, 2012–13) and worked extensively with local stakeholders and communities in coordination with the University of the West Indies (UWI) in Barbados and non-governmental organizations on each of the inhabited transboundary islands. Her research involved the collection of data on important historical, cultural, and ecological heritage sites for use in the countries’ joint application for designation as an UNESCO World Heritage Site. As an award-winning cartographer focused on participatory mapping in island and coastal environments, Aly is highly skilled in the collection and visual representation of local knowledge and community outreach strategies.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot monetarily contribute but still want to help, we would love it if you would get the word out about our project. If you have been bird watching in the Grenadines or nearby islands and have stories, hot spots, or photos to share, please do. If you are a local business and would like to instead donate a meal, transportation, or place to sleep while we are on your island, that would help us put more money towards getting this resource out into the community!
