campaign_city: Mayreau, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

story:
Windjuicer

     

Selected as a semi-finalist in the auspicious Minnesota Entrepreneurial Cup Competition 2013

 

Winner GreenTech Exchange of Vancouver BC

best  new business concept competition 2011


Windjuicer;    What are we all about?

>  It is the first wind power capture machine that is attached to a building in town, rather than sitting on a tall pole far away from users.

>  The Windjuicer is like an amplifier for wind. Think of a cone that takes wind in at the broad end and amplifies it to exit the narrow end with great intensity.

>  It is the only building affixed wind acceleration technology that will produce 10 times more power per dollar invested than photo voltaic.

>  It will produce 17 times the power of a standard pole-mounted turbine of comparable size, at only twice the cost.

>  It is enclosed so it is silent, virtually invisible and undetectable.

>  It is derived from wind tunnel technology that has a history of success going back to the 1880’s. We have brought a new breed of wind power into twenty first century midtown.

>  The Windjuicer can use wind speed as low as 2 mph (3 k/h), which is too low for standard wind turbines. This means that it will produce some energy almost all hours of every day, while standard turbines are dead two-thirds of the time. 

VALUE COMPARISON BETWEEN 'WINDJUICER' & TRACKING PV

(Please note due to patent application restrictions explicit information on proprietary functionality have been withheld)


Why do we stress that this is an urban system?

As mentioned in the film transporting power over long distances is a burden.  Wind power in town has not caught on for a number of reasons but the most prominent reasons are; noise, esthetics, and perceived threat of danger to people property and birds.

The system depends on wind flow through the urban grid along the street system acting like rivers.  Although there is a prevalent urban legend that wind deteriorates as it encounters an urban fabric, recent studies have shown that wind velocity at ground level can actually double in urban transition zones between tower and home scale structures.  Anecdotally we all know that people walking at street level can certainly feel strong wind effects from the suburbs to urban canyons.  We all see that wind reaches everywhere.

Clean sustainable energy is the only way to stem global climate change and stable independent local economies.  Wind energy permeates the earth’s surface; the need and the solution are as close as 2 sides of a coin.

Coal gas and oil are concentrated forms of energy converted by plant photosynthesis over thousands of years.  Hydro power is commercialized through concentration of potential energy through h retained volumes of water produced potential energy.  Even nuclear comes from refined uranium 238.  Wind is one of the few energy sources that is used raw and unrefined; but not anymore.

Where's The Money Going?


Please note that approximately 12% of total contributions remaining after PayPal, Indiegogo and bank fees have all been paid will be earmarked to offset the costs of creating and printing presentation material, also grant and competition entry fees.


                                 INITIAL 3 YEARS SALES PROJECTIONS



Larry Pepper- is our General Director

Larry is an established expert in the young industry of building energy conservation.  He has over the past 5 years gained unprecedented skill in carbon footprint reduction techniques and the implementation of tax & rebate incentives to squeeze out optimal ROI for his clients.  He is able to bring this knowledge and clientele list to bear focused precisely into the market area we intend to penetrate; building energy cost reduction.

Sam Roter- is our Director of Research and Implementation

Sam created the initial Windjuicer design and directs the ongoing research and development.  He will lead the prototype and beta site initialization, system optimization and long-term monitoring.  Sam’s experience in architecture, project management and construction brings hands-on experience to the process of project installation administration.  He is LEED certified, holds a B.A. in environmental systems from U.C. Berkeley and a graduate degree from SCIArch

Richard Billion- is head of exclusivity of concept protection and patenting

Richard directs the concept protection process. He brings many years of experience to the patent and other legal procedures for shielding concept exclusivity.

invisible and undetectable.
> 
It is derived from wind tunnel technology that
has a history of success going back to the 1880’s. We have brought a new breed
of wind power into twenty first century midtown.
> 
The Windjuicer can use wind speed as low as 2
mph (3 k/h), which is too low for standard wind turbines. This means that it
will produce some energy almost all hours of every day, while standard turbines
are dead two-thirds of the time.  
VALUE COMPARISON BETWEEN 'WINDJUICER' & TRACKING PV(Please
note due to patent application restrictions explicit information on proprietary
functionality have been withheld)

Why do we stress that this is an urban system?
As
mentioned in the film transporting power over long distances is a burden.  Wind power in town has not caught on for a
number of reasons but the most prominent reasons are; noise, esthetics, and
perceived threat of danger to people property and birds.
The system depends on wind flow through the
urban grid along the street system acting like rivers.  Although there is a prevalent urban legend that
wind deteriorates as it encounters an urban fabric, recent studies have shown
that wind velocity at ground level can actually double in urban transition
zones between tower and home scale structures. 
Anecdotally we all know that people walking at street level can certainly
feel strong wind effects from the suburbs to urban canyons.  We all see that wind reaches everywhere.
Clean sustainable energy
is the only way to stem global climate change and stable independent local
economies.  Wind energy permeates the
earth’s surface; the need and the solution are as close as 2 sides of a coin. 
Coal gas and oil are concentrated
forms of energy converted by plant photosynthesis over thousands of years.  Hydro power is commercialized through
concentration of potential energy through h retained volumes of water produced
potential energy.  Even nuclear comes
from refined uranium 238.  Wind is one of
the few energy sources that is used raw and unrefined; but not anymore. Where's The Money Going?
Please note that approximately 12% of total
contributions remaining after PayPal, Indiegogo and bank fees have all been
paid will be earmarked to offset the costs of creating and printing presentation
material, also grant and competition entry fees.
                                 INITIAL
3 YEARS SALES PROJECTIONSLarry Pepper- is
our General Director
Larry is an established
expert in the young industry of building energy conservation.  He has over the past 5 years gained unprecedented
skill in carbon footprint reduction techniques and the implementation of tax
& rebate incentives to squeeze out optimal ROI for his clients.  He is able to bring this knowledge and clientele
list to bear focused precisely into the market area we intend to penetrate; building
energy cost reduction.
Sam Roter- is our
Director of Research and Implementation

Sam created the initial Windjuicer design and directs the
ongoing research and development.  He
will lead the prototype and beta site initialization, system optimization and
long-term monitoring.  Sam’s experience
in architecture, project management and construction brings hands-on experience
to the process of project installation administration.  He is LEED certified, holds a B.A. in
environmental systems from U.C. Berkeley and a graduate degree from SCIArchRichard Billion- is head of exclusivity
of concept protection and patenting
Richard directs the concept protection process. He
brings many years of experience to the patent and other legal procedures for shielding
concept exclusivity.

story:
Raise Awareness about the Environment by supporting PELICAM, the only International Environmental Film Festival taking place in Romania, at the gateway to the Danube Delta, the largest well-preserved delta in Europe.

About PELICAM International Film Festival

PELICAM is the only International Film Festival in Romania dedicated to the environment and people.

We have chosen the city of Tulcea to organize this unique event on the Romanian cultural scene, Tulcea being the urban gate to the wild wetlands of the Danube Delta. The Danube Delta Biosphere Reserve is ranked the third largest biodiversity in the world and it is a UNESCO World heritage site.

We are organizing a city based Film Festival, which is non-invasive to the environment but nevertheless, provides a very close look from various perspectives, focused on community and environmentally informed.

PELICAM organizes four international competitions for films, amongst which the  Fresh Perspectives competition, dedicated to films that show innovative approaches to environmental issues (for this competition the jury is formed of high-school students from Tulcea) and the Black Sea Docs competition, with films from the countries neighboring the Black Sea (Romania, Bulgaria, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, Georgia, Moldavia).

For four days Pelicam brings to its audience film screenings, workshops, open-air concerts and photo exhibitions, all focusing on environment.

We place strong emphasis on the festival’s educational mission and on its interactive nature. We invite national and international speakers who bring a valuable contribution to the Festival, and who get a chance to discover Tulcea and the Danube Delta.

All the Events organized by the Festival are FREE OF CHARGE and we are also trying to provide free transportation for children and young people who live in the neighboring rural areas. This year we hope to expand our reach and bring children from the remote villages inside the Delta to the festival.

PELICAM HARD FIGURES

PELICAM’s public has grown from 2000 attendees (the 1st edition, 2012) to over 5,000 attendees (the third edition, 2014). Most of the films in the competition are premiered at PELICAM. For the 2014 edition, 35 films from 19 different countries were screened, 27 of which were national premieres. Films are shown within the four competitions, Feature Documentaries, Short Documentaries, Black Sea Docs and Fresh Perspectives.

PELICAM began in 2012 as an initiative of Les Herbes Folles Association and it has been a member of the Green Film Network since 2013. Twenty-seven film festivals around the world are part of this network, and they share one goal: raising awareness for the environment.

The first three editions have brought to Romania for the first time films like “Gasland” (USA, 2012) winner of the first PELICAM trophy in 2012, “My Name is Salt” (Switzerland/India, 2013) winner of the third PELICAM trophy in 2014, “Pipeline” (Russia/Czech Republic/Germany, 2013) dir. Vitaly Mansky, “Amazon Gold” (USA, 2012) dir. Reuben Aaronson,  “More Than Honey” (Switzerland, 2013) dir. Markus Imhoof , winner of the Berlinale Silver Bear in 2013, “La Soif Du Monde” dir. Yann Arthus Bertrand, “Aral, The Lost Sea” dir. Isabel Coixet (director nominated for the Cannes Palme d’Or and the Berlinale Golden Bear) and  “Gone Wild” (Romania, 2012) by Dan Curean.


60 special guests attended Pelicam in 2014, bringing a valuable contribution to the debates and activities of the Festival: film directors Cristi Puiu (Romania), Klaus Drexel (France), Stefano Martone (Italy), Jan van den Berg (The Netherlands), Carl Fechner (Germany) and others; anthropologists Michael Stewart (UK) and Vintilă Mihăilescu (Romania); Ivan Patzaichin, Olympic champion in canoe sprint racing (Romania); Pedro Pinero Fuente, director of the International Environmental Film Festival in Zaragoza – ECOZINE (Spania), festival member of the Green Film Network.

WHAT WE NEED

We need your support in order to continue to make PELICAM a rich and engaging event, accessible to a wide audience, free of charge.

Your donations will help us provide the following:

-  Free Entry to All Festival Events

-  Cover Screening Expenses

-  Free Transportation for Children from the surrounding villages (including more isolated villages inside the Delta)

-  Promotion Costs in the Local and National Media

- Bring guests that will contribute to the festival with public debates, Q&A discussions, Workshops and accommodate them in Tulcea

THANK YOU! MULȚUMIM!

story:
Save the Sundarbans, home of the beloved and endangered wild Bengal tiger! 


OIL SPILL IN WORLD'S LARGEST MANGROVE FOREST:

A PUBLIC HEALTH DISASTER.  

A GLOBAL ECOLOGICAL CATASTROPHE.


The Sundarbans Are Unique and Special for the entire planet. 
Save OUR Sundarbans.


"On the morning of Dec. 9, 2014, a tanker carrying heavy furnace oil to a powerplant in Bangladesh was struck in the fog by a cargo vessel and partially sank, releasing thousands of gallons of oil into the Sundarbans, the world's largest continuous mangrove forest and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. This tidal river delta, already threatened by climate change, is home to incredible biodiversity including rare Irrawaddy and Ganges dolphins and what is believed to be one of the largest populations of the very endangered Bengal Tiger. The "Southern Star 7" was carrying somewhere between 66,000 and 92,000 gallons of furnace oil, but how much was actually spilled into the river remains unknown.

Residents have been seen collecting the oil by hand and with buckets to sell for a small reward to the state run Padma Oil company, while fishermen attempt to use their nets to contain the spill. This is one of the most fragile and delicate ecosystems on the planet and home to much beloved creatures like river dolphins and the royal Bengal tiger." [via SkyTruth]


HOW TO HELP: 

The locals of the Sundarbans need treatment and protection as they are employed to clean up the oil - this includes small children. Funds will be used to purchase medical supplies and safety equipment for the locals who are cleaning up the spill. PLEASE DONATE NOW.

Funds will be dispersed 3 times to expedite funds on-the-ground during this 45-day campaign - on December 29th, January 21st and February 5th.

 Items needed to be purchased include:

1. Paracetamol 
2. Antihistamines
3. Cough Syrups
4. Nasal decongestants
5. Antibiotics (oral, topical and ointments)
6. ORS packets
7. Artificial tear drops
8. Halogen tablets 
9. Antiemetics 
10. Vestibular sedatives
11. Antispamsodics
12. Bronchodilators (inhalers and tablets)
13. Steroids

PLEASE DONATE NOW.
All contributions will benefit Save The Sundarbans.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the news out about this spill. Due to being an impoverished region, this spill has barely gotten the international attention it deserves. 

Share on social media, Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

#SaveOurSundarbans #SOSBengals

Follow https://twitter.com/Sundarbans_SOS for updates.

MORE INFORMATION

"After oil spill in Bangladesh's unique mangrove forest, worries about rare animals." National Geographic, Dec. 16, 2014

story:
Sustainable Cycles: Who are we?

Sustainable Cycles is a collective of "spokeswomen" who travel across the country by bicycle to lead workshops about eco-friendly menstrual products. The project was started in 2011 by Sarah Konner and Toni Craige, who biked down the West Coast meeting with groups of women to discuss the cultural taboos of menstruation and pass around a show-and-tell kit of alternatives to single-use pads and tampons. The project gained momentum and a year later, Rachel Horn led a second bicycle tour, talking about periods and the environmental impact of the products we use everywhere she went.

Now, SIX WOMEN from diverse backgrounds want to take the project to the next level! Rachel and Olive from Los Angeles, Ruby and Sarah from New York City, Rosie from Australia, and Kim from South Africa are going to bike from the West Coast to Boston. Our six riders will follow two separate routes (one southern and one midwestern) from California to converge in Richmond, VA. Then we will ride in one big group up the east coast  to end at the Society of Menstrual Cycle Research's National Conference in Boston, Massachusetts. We will present our project at the June 2015 event and network with others doing work in this field.

SO FAR, MENSTRUAL CUP AND REUSABLE CLOTH PAD COMPANIES HAVE DONATED OVER 1,000 SAMPLES FOR US TO PROMOTE AND DISTRIBUTE ON OUR TRIP! OUR SPONSORS INCLUDE DIVA CUP, LUNETTE, MY OWN CUP, RUBY CUP, PARTY IN MY PANTS, AND GLAD RAGS.

During our three months on the road, we will host events in different cities along our routes and start person-to-person conversations with hundreds of women about menstrual health and alternative products. We will encourage them to switch to methods that are safer and more environmentally friendly, and spread the word to their friends and communities. Let's break the cycle of shame and embarrassment around "cycling"!


We want your support!

We want to raise $10,000 to help cover the cost of food, bicycle maintenance, emergency repairs, and transportation to and from our start and end locations. While we are doing our best to be frugal and source used and donated gear, there are still many items we don’t yet have that will be necessities on the road, especially since we will be riding through a variety of climates and terrain. We will definitely need to replace things like tires, tubes, and brake pads as they wear out over the trip. We will also need to keep ourselves fed and watered. Remember, the money we raise will be distributed between six riders!

If you aren’t able to contribute financially at this time, please check out our list below of other donations we will gladly accept!


Why donate?

By donating to this campaign, you are supporting a cultural shift towards more environmental and health-conscious practices, as well as more open discourse surrounding women’s bodies and menstruation. We have done bike tours like this before, and we have been successful in spreading knowledge about alternative products and getting hundreds of women across the country to make the switch to reusables. We are already supported by many of the companies who manufacture these sustainable products, but we need YOUR SUPPORT to make our largest cross-country tour ever a reality!


There are many ways to contribute!

In addition to monetary contributions, we will gladly accept donations of the following (things in used condition or temporary loans are A-ok!):

-lightweight camping gear (tents, sleeping bags, sleeping pads, camping stoves, water purifiers, camel backs)

-Up-to-date bicycle maps of the following states: California, Nevada, Utah, Colorado, Kansas, Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Kentucky, West Virginia, Virginia

-bicycle gear (clipless shoes, lots of bike lights and batteries, warm lightweight layers, racks, panniers, safety flags and triangles, water bottles and bottle cages, toe covers, bar mitts for cold weather)


Help us make connections!

Besides the physical "stuff", connections to potential hosts and communities who would be interested in workshops along our routes are invaluable! Know a women's health center, bicycle coalition, social/environmental/student group, health food store, or other potentially interested party in any of the following cities or surrounding areas? Please reach out to us and let us know!


Ruby, Sarah, and Kim:

CA- San Francisco, Sacramento

NV- Carson City

UT- Salt Lake City

CO- Boulder, Denver

KS- Topeka

MS- Kansas City, St. Louis

IN- Bloomington

OH- Cincinnati

VA- Roanoke, Richmond


Rachel, Olive, and Rosie:


CA- San Diego

AZ- Phoenix

NM- Las Cruces

TX- Austin

LA- New Orleans

MS- Jackson

AL- Montgomery

GA- Atlanta

NC- Asheville


ALL:

DC- Washington

PA- Philadelphia

NYC and Boston- we have many connections here already, but we’d be happy to make more! :)


Please share our campaign with your friends and pass the word along about our project! 

Even if you can’t contribute at this time, supporting our work by talking about it with others will help us greatly!

story:
Help Wayne Talmage, Colorado's pioneering organic fruit farmer and communitarian educator, fund staff development and expand revenues while his farm is on the market.  Wayne seeks to ensure White Buffalo Farm is transferred to the best possible hands to steward the farm's organic and communitarian legacy:  Restoring Our Food, Our Earth, Ourselves. Contribute ideas and funding for the best possible next step for his story book farm!

Resettling America

Food production in the U.S. begs for a new paradigm in land tenure in America to reduce urban dis-ease, expand healthy food production and to foster contemporary rural families and lifestyles!  Wayne hopes to optimize the conditions for a farm-based eco-village at White Buffalo Farm to support restorative livelihoods and expand agrarian education.  A farm-based eco-village moves towards "resettling" America!

We are working on developing a replicable proto-type essential at this time in the agrarian movement. We need communitarian agriculture rather than sole proprietorship to rebuild farming and distributive land tenure.  We will disburse campaign funds for staff development, farm clean up, outreach and building management and communications competency in a start up eco-village management group!  Thank you!

Helping us now offers a chance to raise awareness about farm-based eco-villages.  If not at White Buffalo, then elsewhere!   Keep in mind, Wayne cannot ensure the farm will become a farm-based ecovillage.  Financial matters are pressing and Wayne is dependent on farm crew volunteers.  One can try!

Let's grow a movement that includes equitable land distribution!  Wayne is open to offers on the farm lower than the list price for a vision and team that moves towards demonstrating a communitarian approach to farming with pooled resources to protect resources like the state's oldest organic fruit orchard or pure agricultural water!

Learn more about a model for communitarian farm-based livelihood on the White Buffalo Farm website under the column heading, "Sustainability." 

About the Farm's Owner and Founder

Wayne pioneered organic fruit production on Colorado's western slope with other back to landers in the early 1970s.  They opened markets for organics in Colorado and beyond.  He is the last man standing from those days as all of his fellow farmers moved on to other livelihoods long ago.  

Wayne's children are not able to farm in Colorado and so arises the question of who to carry on the legacy?  Who is the best possible next owner of White Buffalo Farm? 

Wayne's story is soon to be told in a comic strip loosely based on the stories he shares with interns and farmers market goers alike!  The fun-loving comic strip is full of wry wit and gentle grace to be "aired" in weekly comic strip installments!  Stay tuned to the stories of "Paradox Farm and the Peacenik Warrior."   Even now, the creative process is unfolding in the hip earthy cafes of Long Beach, California.  Wow!  Stayed tuned ~

Pioneering Organic Farm for Sale

Who is the best possible next owner of White Buffalo Farm?  A great buyer for the farm would extend operations on the farm to benefit the region, generate wholesome livelihood for more than a few, offer delicious and nutritious local organic foods and other goods, maintain the farm's natural beauty and expand the number of visitors and youth that can visit the farm for restorative experience. 

Through this Indiegogo campaign, Wayne hopes more people learn about the farm and this wonderful opportunity to farm in a story book place!  Now the growing season is coming to an end, Wayne is ready to talk with the Ute Nations, foundations and others.  He seeks to open conversations on how best to benefit healing and restoration during these difficult times through living, visiting or working on this extraordinary farm. 

Wayne plans to sell to the optimal buyer when the conditions are ripe.  He hopes whoever buys the farm moves towards developing a farm-based ecovillage.  Sale of the farm could also lead to other sustainable possibilities.

The farm could be sold to 1) a tribal body "first peoples" who develop an ecovillage with the added benefit of youth programs near a wilderness setting; 2) a foundation may permit the development of small-scale organic agriculture programming on a Colorado fruit farm;  or, 3) a good, wonderful, extended family providing a hopeful family model in these times when families are often fractured in the striving for upward mobility.  Whoever meets Wayne's sense of what is best, may the outcome provide powerful restorative benefits for all.  Learn more about the farm on the farm's website and in our property listing.  Please spread the word!

What We Need

Your help now covers staff development and operational expenses as Wayne keeps the farm producing food through the winter.  Wayne grows greens and lettuces during our long, but sunny Colorado winters in his geo-thermal grow tunnels!

2013 was a difficult growing season to due both a late freeze of the cherry crop and an early freeze of the tomato crop.  In addition, June rolled out blazing hot impacting germination of lettuces and greens for our farmers market.  It was a challenging year to farm!  Good thing they are not all like that!

Operating expenses to feed and shelter the current residents on the farm who keep farm operations in full swing exceeds $3000 per month.  We are currently short by $1000 a month, but expect to restore revenues through our Community Supported Agriculture program by February 2014.

Seven Other Ways You Can Help

1)  Encourage your friends to donate to ensure the farm's best possible transition!   Please share our campaign with friends and have them sign up for our email newsletter either on the White Buffalo Farm website or through the farm's Facebook page.

2) If you or your friends live in our region, check out our CSA!

3) Wayne is accepting loans of $1000 or more which he will plan to repay at 12.5% interest from the proceeds of the sale of the farm.  To learn more, visit the peer-to-peer lending platform the farm is using to administer loan agreements.  Please also send a message to Myriem, the fund raising campaign lead, or Wayne to discuss details.  You can reach us both by clicking on our profile below.

4) Offer an auction item for our upcoming online auction:  CDs, Books, Poetry, Jewelry, Art, Artisan Goods, Services, Dining, Travel, Tickets, Health, Fitness.  For ideas check out a recent online auction held by Esalen.  You benefit by exposure to our wonderful group of farm friends!  We benefit by reaching our fund raising goals! 

5)  Can you host a house party to raise awareness and do fund raising to support our hopes for the farm?  We can send you everything you need to have a lovely party and feel good about your connection to the farm!  Call or write for details.

6) Seasoned Vegetable Manager 2014.  Wayne seeks a deeply-knowledgeable vegetable manager-educator for the 2014 growing season.  Learn more about our programs on our website.  Wayne welcomes interns and apprentices for 2014.  Updated information will soon appear in our Growfood.org and Wwoof listings.  We also post occasionally in goodfoodjobs.org  Even now, you can write wltalmage@tds.net for a 2014 WBF staff, intern or apprentice infosheet to complete and return to the farm.

7)  Stay tuned!  We plan ongoing fund raising campaigns to make up revenue shortfalls through the winter to ensure the farm is in tip top shape for the 2014 growing season and for the new owners of the farm.  Spread the word!  Thank you!

Farm Gift Baskets for You!

As perks, we have lovely organic farm-made items for you to share during the holidays!  Enjoy the first comic of "Paradox Farm and the Peacenik Warrior," exquisite eco-ethical yarns and knits, as well as uniquely divine artisan small batch USDA organic fruit preserves by a French-American local foods master.

...and, Happy Thanksgiving everyone!
story_txt:
Help Wayne Talmage, Colorado's pioneering organic fruit farmer and 
communitarian educator, fund staff development and expand revenues while
 his farm is on the market.  Wayne seeks to ensure White Buffalo Farm is
 transferred to the best 
possible hands to steward the farm's organic and communitarian legacy:  Restoring Our Food, Our Earth, Ourselves. Contribute ideas and funding for the best possible next step for his story book farm!Resettling America
Food production in the U.S. begs for a new paradigm in land tenure in America to reduce urban dis-ease, expand healthy food production and to foster contemporary rural families and lifestyles!  Wayne hopes to optimize the conditions for a farm-based 
eco-village at White Buffalo Farm to support restorative livelihoods and expand agrarian education.  A 
farm-based eco-village moves towards "resettling" America!We are working on developing a replicable proto-type essential at 
this time in the agrarian movement. We need communitarian agriculture 
rather than sole proprietorship to rebuild farming and distributive land
 tenure.  We will disburse campaign funds for staff development, 
farm clean up, outreach and building management and communications 
competency in a start up eco-village management group!  Thank you!Helping us now offers a chance to raise awareness about farm-based eco-villages.  If not at White Buffalo, then elsewhere!   Keep in mind, Wayne cannot ensure the farm will become a farm-based ecovillage.  Financial matters are pressing and Wayne is dependent on farm crew volunteers.  One can try!Let's grow a movement that includes equitable land distribution!  Wayne
 is open to offers on the farm lower than the list price for a vision 
and team that moves towards demonstrating a communitarian approach to farming with pooled resources to protect resources like the state's oldest organic fruit orchard or pure agricultural water!Learn more about a model for communitarian farm-based livelihood on the White Buffalo Farm website under the column heading, "Sustainability."  About the Farm's Owner and FounderWayne pioneered organic fruit production on Colorado's western slope with other back to landers in the early 1970s.  They opened markets for organics in Colorado and beyond.  He is the last man standing from those days as all of his fellow farmers moved on to other livelihoods long ago.  Wayne's children are not able to farm in Colorado and so arises the question of who to carry on the legacy?  Who is the best possible next owner of White Buffalo Farm?  Wayne's story is soon to be told in a comic strip loosely based on the stories he shares with interns and farmers market goers alike!  The fun-loving comic strip is full of wry wit and gentle grace to be "aired" in weekly comic strip installments!  Stay tuned to the stories of "Paradox Farm and the Peacenik Warrior."   Even now, the creative process is unfolding in the hip earthy cafes of Long Beach, California.  Wow!  Stayed tuned ~

Pioneering Organic Farm for SaleWho is the best possible next owner of White Buffalo Farm?  A great buyer for the farm would extend operations on the farm to 
benefit the region, generate wholesome livelihood for more than a few, 
offer delicious and nutritious local organic foods and other goods, 
maintain the farm's natural beauty and expand the number of visitors and
 youth that can visit the farm for restorative experience.  Through this Indiegogo campaign, Wayne hopes more people learn about the 
farm and this wonderful opportunity to farm in a story book place!  Now 
the growing season is coming to an end, Wayne is ready to talk with the 
Ute Nations, foundations and others.  He seeks to open conversations on 
how best to benefit healing and restoration during these difficult times
 through living, visiting or working on this extraordinary farm. Wayne plans to sell to the optimal buyer when the conditions are ripe.  
He hopes whoever buys the farm moves towards developing a farm-based 
ecovillage.  Sale of the farm could also lead to other sustainable possibilities. The farm could be sold to 1) a tribal body 
"first peoples" who develop an ecovillage with the added benefit of youth programs near a wilderness setting; 2) a foundation may permit the development 
of small-scale organic agriculture programming on a Colorado fruit farm;  or, 3) a good, wonderful, extended family 
providing a hopeful family model in these times when families are often 
fractured in the striving for upward mobility.  Whoever meets Wayne's sense of what is best, may the outcome provide 
powerful restorative benefits for all.  Learn more about the farm on the farm's website and in our property listing.  Please spread the word! What We Need
Your help now covers staff development and operational expenses as Wayne
 keeps the farm producing food through the winter.  Wayne grows greens 
and lettuces during our long, but sunny Colorado winters in his 
geo-thermal grow tunnels!2013 was a difficult
 growing season to due both a late freeze of the cherry crop and an 
early freeze of the tomato crop.  In addition, June rolled out blazing 
hot impacting germination of lettuces and greens for our farmers 
market.  It was a challenging year to farm!  Good thing they are not all
 like that!Operating expenses to feed and shelter the current residents on the farm who keep farm operations in full swing exceeds $3000 per month.  We are currently short by $1000 a month, but expect to restore revenues through our Community Supported Agriculture program by February 2014.Seven Other Ways You Can Help1)  Encourage your friends to donate to ensure the farm's best possible transition!   Please share our campaign with friends and have them sign up for our email newsletter either on the White Buffalo Farm website or through the farm's Facebook page.2) If you or your friends live in our region, check out our CSA!3) Wayne is accepting loans of $1000 or more which he will plan to repay at 12.5% interest from the proceeds of the sale of the farm.  To learn more, visit the peer-to-peer lending platform the farm is using to administer loan agreements.  Please also send a message to Myriem, the fund raising campaign lead, or Wayne to discuss details.  You can reach us both by clicking on our profile below.4) Offer an auction item for our upcoming online auction:  CDs, Books, Poetry, Jewelry, Art, Artisan Goods, Services, Dining, Travel, Tickets, Health, Fitness.  For ideas check out a recent online auction held by Esalen.  You benefit by exposure to our wonderful group of farm friends!  We benefit by reaching our fund raising goals!  5)  Can you host a house party to raise awareness and do fund raising to support our hopes for the farm?  We can send you everything you need to have a lovely party and feel good about your connection to the farm!  Call or write for details.6) Seasoned Vegetable Manager 2014.  Wayne seeks a deeply-knowledgeable vegetable manager-educator for the 2014 growing season.  Learn more about our programs on our website.  Wayne welcomes interns and apprentices for 2014.  Updated information will soon appear in our Growfood.org and Wwoof listings.  We also post occasionally in goodfoodjobs.org  Even now, you can write wltalmage@tds.net for a 2014 WBF staff, intern or apprentice infosheet to complete and return to the farm.7)  Stay tuned!  We plan ongoing fund raising campaigns to make up revenue shortfalls 
through the winter to ensure the farm is in tip top shape for the 2014 
growing season and for the new owners of the farm.  Spread the word!  Thank you!Farm Gift Baskets for You!
As perks, we have lovely organic farm-made items for you to share during the holidays!  Enjoy the first comic of "Paradox Farm and the Peacenik Warrior," exquisite eco-ethical yarns and knits, as well as uniquely divine artisan small batch USDA organic fruit preserves by a French-American local foods master....and, Happy Thanksgiving everyone!

story:
A reunion for 1,000 adopted cats!

Kitty Bungalow Charm School for Wayward Cats just celebrated our 1,000th adoption!  With over 1,000 graduates we felt it was time to throw a big reunion, but our cats have taken over the planning committee and have created and outrageous reunion plan!  

A letter to the humanz from us catz: 

Please give we some monies.  Catz don't haz monies or thumbs.  Can you help us? We are planning a big party but need monies to make it happen.  Here is the budget from our feline planning committee:

Food:  Seafood fountain buffet.  $10,005 -  With one thousand cats we haz budget $1000 of seafood for each cat.  We also haz $5 for food for our humanz.

Drinks:  Toilet water.  $300 - We haz hard time with budget for this as we could not find toilet water being sold at any Whole Foods or other grocery stores.  We finally found a plumber who sayz he make for us!  We hope it is enough, we do not know how much toilet water our humanz may drink.

Entertainment:  Taylor Swift. $12,000,000 - Taylor Swift is our favorite.  She loves we catz too!  If we can't get Taylor Swift we will ask her red headed boyfriend Ed Sheeran.  

Lighting:  Laser Show. $5,000 - We catz love laser lights!  So how happy we will all be with GIANT laser show!  We can all catch a red dot and take it home!

Recreation: Cat Nip. $15,000 - It is okays, we is old enough now!  Cat Nip is $15 a pound so we hope a thousand pounds is enough!  We could haz more but we needz to be budget savvy.

Budget total: $12,030,305  -- We hope you humanz will give us your monies for our goal!:)

A note from the Bungalow School Board:

Please know that Kitty Bungalow Charm School for Wayward Cats is run by humans and the proceeding budget put together by our planning committee of felines has not been approved.  It was hard for them to truly grasp the concept of money, they were more interested in our thumbs.
That is not to say that our non profit cat rescue is not in the need of your tax deductible donation.  We need your dollars to continue to  provide free spay and neuters and medical needs for homeless street cats.
So please toss in some dollars to the kitty  while it will not be used for party purposes we will make sure our cats have a wonderful reunion party (even without Taylor Swift).  We will however use your donation for the important work making certain that the next 1000 cats are well cared for and loved prior to their adoption to their forever homes.

Plus you can get in on the fun with cat themed gifts, personalized live video links to the event, and Kitty Bungalow logo Ts, and cat themed condoms!

Please share our cats dream event with other cat lovers!

Most of you probably rescued your cat.  Your support to our organization not only helps us to continue the good rescue work we do, but allows us to continue to promote a positive adoption message and broaden our reach for good pet parenting education and spay and neuter necessity.

As an organization we believe in advanced socialization.  Our event will help show the world the expansive social abilities of cats and encourage owners to provide more socialization and experiences for their own owned cats!

As a 100% street cat rescue we have over 80 weekly volunteer teachers working with these cats to give them the skills they need to pass their final exams, taking hissy little street cats and graduating Ivy League lap cats.

Please help out with the cat overpopulation issue.  Help with local Trap/Neuter/Return in your area or spend some time at a local rescue!

www.kittybungalow.org

story:
****UPDATE****

101 Celsius was selected as a finalist for the Global Cleantech Cluster Association Late Stage Awards, we'll be competing in Atlanta Oct 28, 2013. Thank you to the judges at the Chicago Clean Energy Alliance compettion for selecting us as a finalist.

***UPDATE 2****

We are removing the name of the organization that selected the TAC-Q to help remove any confusion that this fundraisig campaign is for anything other than to raise funds to bring two patent pending components into the commercail market.  I also understand that some people feel that there should be a video narration included in this campaign, I agree, my accountant did not.  If you want a feel for our efforts so far, please check out our website, LinkedIn or FB pages.

101 Celsius' Tac-Q system was chosen from over 128 designs for testing against two --- designs that each received $125K grants to develop. 101 Celsius did not receive any grant money to develop the Tac-Q  system. 

Your help brings two components of this system into the commercial solar market place and allows us to build version 2 of this system to keep competing. We designed the Tac-Q system for Relief agencies and the military realized two components solve several issues that have delayed or prevented commercial solar thermal systems from being installed.

The Tac-Q provides hot water for showers and kitchens in deployed areas and can be used to create potable water.  This reduces fuel usage and the need for re-supply convoys, the leading cause of casualties.Tac-Q v2.0 removes weight, speeds and simplifies installations and has two components that transforms the commercial solar market.

101 Celsius llc, is a developer of solar thermal systems for industrial, commercial and residential systems.  We designed the Tac-Q system for the Military and Relief agencies and realized two components solve several issues that have delayed or prevented commercial solar thermal systems from being installed.  The mounting system increases thermal output, reduces wind loading and the need for structural modifications to buildings.  The mounting system maximizes Solar A/C Systems in the summer and Solar heating systems in the winter and allows systems to be installed on wall, flat roof or pitched roofs.  The DC powered pump station allows the system to operate where electricity is expensive and can be used world-wide regardless of Grid voltage.

What We Need & What You Get

Product design is a hard category to fund, so I've made as many gifts, systems, and options to buy systems available as possible.  If you have a gift idea you'd like to see please don't be shy. 

To prove we are devoted to providing low carbon solutions where ever possible.  I organized the 101 Celsius Electrified and Alt-fueled vehicle Rally in Chicago.  It was the first  EV rally held in below freezing weather and the first to re-create the 1895 Times-Herald race using EVs.  14 electrified vehicles and trucks, and one VW Passat TDI participated in the Rally.  Details can be found at the FB page of 101 Celsius dot com, or the Goggle plus page.

Need More details:

Every donation and ounce of energy goes to pushing the improvement in technology and getting more solar thermal systems installed so that we create a self perpetuating chain reaction of installed low carbon solutions.

The Impact

The impact of the mounting system nearly doubles the output of the collectors and allows one collector system to power Solar A/C in summer and Solar heating systems in the winter.  The mounting allows solar thermal systems to beat Hydraulically Fracked Natural-gas at it's current low price, allows systems to be easily installed on roofs without structural modifications including Hurricane regions.

The DC Pump station allows systems to operate independent of the Electrical grid and can be used where the system is co-located with PV systems, allowing both system types to operate most efficiently.

Short term the system will help in Disaster relief and military operations where 70 percent of casualties are the result of resupply operations, where water is the primary good delivered.  Making water on site and reducing fuel consumption allows the military to resupply by air and further reduce casualties.  The leading cause of death in Disaster areas is often water borne diseases, not the actual event. By boiling the water most pathogens are destroyed.

Long term the system will be used to develop the solar resources of the world by increasing the sites available to install solar systems.  The Tac-Q system and technology works well from the equator to the polar areas.  Other system types ie; Concentrators require high direct solar insolation and do not work well outside the tropics.

Version 2 will be substituted during the testing phase as the changes, are to equipment other than the Collectors and does not change the Energy Yields just the speed of deployment & Shipping and weight reduction.  The same companies I used to build the first prototype will be used to build Version 2.

Stretch Goals

To hire a Project manager for the commercial and residential systems that are going to be generated from this campaign. Fund one system on a commercial gymnasium pool system to monitor and prove the financial model to a National gym outfitter and let their dealers have a new product line. To have a 2nd system ready to be sent to disaster relief areas. There seems to be no limit on what needs to be done.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand if you can't contribute monetarily, but spreading the word via FB / Pinterest and other social networks helps in many ways.  Think of every person or organization you can get the word to, as a social dollar toward the campaign. Encourage students to get organized and force their campus and future campus to use Low carbon systems and vehicles.  Indiegogo share tools can help!

My sincerest thanks to all the people who have helped get the Tac-Q prototype completed; Ben Beiler, Ed Reicin and the entire staff at MPC International for the office space, CAD computer, collapsible water tank, machine shop, shipping and all the coffee.  To ACA ,Aluminum Coil & Anodizing, for the material and Nova Metals for the bending and re-bending and re-bending again.  To The Kelly Group of Indiana, and especially Archie Smith, who took the CAD drawing and made it reality through their CNC water jets and talented tradesmen.  A special thank you to the Researcher, who after reading 128, twenty page submittals, decided that my unsolicited offer was worth reading and a system worth buying.

“Success has many fathers, failure is an orphan” - unknown.  You are all fathers to this project and again my sincerest thanks for your contributions, time and talents.

story:
"Life changing," "re-affirming," and "empowering" are just some of the ways past participants have described their experience attending the Climate Reality Leadership Training. 

I have a passion to change the world and help stop climate change. One of the best ways to do this is through training with the Climate Reality Leadership Corps, led by Al Gore.

Through this training, I hope that I can bring my knowledge back into the ski communities that we live in, to create real change both locally and globally. It is my belief that ski towns should be model examples of what a renewable energy communities look like and can share this with the rest of the world. 

It is my goal to raise $3,500. All the funding will go towards the transportation, lodging, and visa fees required to travel to Rio de Janeiro in Brazil. Climate Reality will cover the cost of the training. 

More Info About the Trainings

Climate Reality Leadership Corps training in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, which will be held November 4-6, will bring together a select group of individuals committed to addressing the impacts of climate change and implementing the solutions that will define us to future generations. This training is an opportunity to join a global network of leaders committed to solving the climate crisis.

Over the course of three days, I will have the opportunity to hear from experts who will share information about the science behind the climate crisis as well as their experiences educating and engaging diverse networks and communities. I will also have the chance to connect with a group of extraordinary leaders from a variety of sectors and countries around the world.

View this video of a Dr. Susan Pacheco, a current Climate Reality Leader

story:
Who we are - Project Manaia in short :-)

The non profit called "Project Manaia" has been founded to give researchers a platform to conduct their projects with guidance on a shoestring budget. The big difference to huge research vessels is not only that we can offer our service on a much smaller budget but also that we remain flexible and can react on new topics on short notice!



I am Manuel - a Marine Biologist, Diving Instructor, skipper, Photographer and Environmentalist. 

I've spent the last couple of years sailing around the world for an environmental organisation witnessing destruction, pollution, overfishing and other disasters at high seas.

I do believe that actions speak louder than words, but I also believe that facts are harder to argue with.


How you can support us and what we can do for you

What we need to get started is the funding to buy and redesign a boat, big enough to accommodate a crew of 8 (The minimum size for small documentary teams) and seaworthy enough to operate around the world

  • The boat will be entirely self sustained, with electric propulsion, solar panels, inverters and all the gear needed to do research as well as offshore passages
  • We will try to get as much of the gear second hand and upgrade as we go, of course always with the safety aspect in mind! But the main thought is to keep the footprint of the boat and of the people on it as small as possible.
  • We want to give independent researchers and college graduates eager to work on environmental issues the perfect platform to do their work
  • People who help us with the funding will be the first ones to join us on our voyages! Depending on your perk you can join us for a week or a day. Every little donation will get our honest gratitude, others can get Manaia gimmicks, as shirts, hats, buttons and so on
  • If we can't reach the full goal we will have to step back a bit and start smaller. The boat will go ahead, but won't be outfitted to the perfect standard right away which will for the time being limit operation to coastal waters with improvements for the future in mind!
  • If you have projects in mind that YOU would like to conduct on a boat like this, NOW is the time to share those, please leave a comment and we will get back to you as soon as we can.
  • Partnerships with Universities do already exist but more are welcome, everybody with an idea to make the most out of this project is welcome to share!
  • We already partner with Organisations to clean our oceans and this will be the first focus of the project, also "The Ocean Cleanup" showed interest in using us as a platform in future work with their Ocean Cleanup project!
  • If you know partners of interest, organisations that could be curious about working with us, please share and we will get back to them as soon as we can!


The Impact

The reasons why we want to get all this started are simple

  • Research provides facts and the beautiful thing about facts is, they are hard to argue with. It is one thing to tell someone to stop doing something, but if you have done your homework and know the risks and consequences you can explain what we are heading into and let people make up their own mind about it!
  • A sailboat is the most sustainable way to move around the world, particularly if you are eager to head to remote places, like the pacific islands or the garbage gyre in the middle of the ocean. So sailing really is the only option!
  • A small scale research boat is easier and cheaper to run than the big research ships out there, so environmental work on a shoestring budget becomes possible
  • We already partner with organisations like "The Clean Oceans Project" and "The Ocean Cleanup" and they already asked to use the boat once it is finished.


Risks & Challenges

Of course Projects like this never have a smooth path ahead of them, so the first big challenges will come along pretty fast

  • Finding the perfect hull for us will be the first big step. In the 15 meter range, Aluminum or steel, a pilothouse for shelter in colder regions and of course big enough to accommodate everyone and have a small room for a laboratory on board
  • Outfitting the boat will be straight forward, given the funds are sufficient it will be done within a year. Extra hands and helpers are of course always welcome to join in and help us first hand!
  • We are already in search of hulls and have two great candidates in our minds, one of them in northern Germany and one currently sitting in Italy. Both need a bunch of work done to them, but that was always the plan!

Other Ways You Can Help

No money but eager to help? - No problem! The best ways everyone can help are easy:

  • Spread the word about our project, share it on Facebook, get folks around you excited about the idea. Share the project right off the indiegogo website and spread the word on twitter, FB and all the other social networks!
  • Come and work with us! There is always work to be done on a boat and extra hands are always needed! If you have time and a way to get to us feel free to swing by and help out for a few hours or days - whatever suits you!
  • If you have gear, that can be useful for a boat, we appreciate those donations as much as any other as well! Got a spare radio, blocks, fenders, tools, ... everything is needed at this stage!

Thank you very much for reading through all of this and thanks to all our supporters!


Meet our Partners and Supporters


The Clean Oceans Project

 Electric Yachts of Annapolis

 Clean Adriatic Sea Alliance



And Organisations already asking for the research boat in the future
story_txt:
Who we are - Project Manaia in short :-)

The non profit called "Project Manaia" has been founded to give researchers a platform to conduct their projects with guidance on a shoestring budget. The big difference to huge research vessels is not only that we can offer our service on a much smaller budget but also that we remain flexible and can react on new topics on short notice!
   I am Manuel - a Marine Biologist, Diving Instructor, skipper, Photographer and Environmentalist. I've spent the last couple of years sailing around the world for an environmental organisation witnessing destruction, pollution, overfishing and other disasters at high seas.I do believe that actions speak louder than words, but I also believe that facts are harder to argue with.How you can support us and what we can do for youWhat we need to get started is the funding to buy and redesign a boat, big enough to accommodate a crew of 8 (The minimum size for small documentary teams) and seaworthy enough to operate around the world

story:
Hi! I’m Elijah Schumacher

I'm from Vermont and I'm a pretty lucky guy.

I've been blessed with a great family,

An amazing girlfriend,

And the opportunity to pursue a bachelor's degree in Environmental Studies (focused on Ecology and Biology) at Cornell College in Iowa.

(with some pretty great people, I might add)


This fall I'd like to give back by helping out some people and animals who are a bit less fortunate than myself, while working to complete my degree at the same time! 

As I enter my senior year of college, I'll be completing a capstone project which is the culmination of my studies at Cornell.  I have a great opportunity to volunteer in Madagascar this fall and help research lemurs and reptile/amphibian species there. With your help, I can take advantage of this unique educational opportunity and make a difference there through a program called Azafady.

The Program 

“Azafady” is an all-purpose Malagasey word which means “please” or “excuse me” or, more literally, “let it not be taboo to me”. It is essentially an expression of respect and I’m told that it’s a term that I, as a foreigner, can expect to use regularly in my interactions with the Malagasey people. The organization, Azafady,  chose this word for their name because it displays the holistic and respectful viewpoint that defines their charity. They are dedicated to building and supporting communities, both human and non-human, in the Anosy (south-east) region of Madagascar.

Azafady has a lot going on. They offer humanitarian aid to struggling local human communities, building schools, latrines, and other necessary structures; providing better education opportunities; helping prevent and control malaria outbreaks; and much, much more. They also strive to protect and support non-human communities that rely on the fragmented littoral (coastal) forest in the Sainte Luce area. These plant and animal communities are astonishingly rich and diverse but, unfortunately, incredibly threatened since most of them (more than 85%) exist only in Madagascar. If you’re interested in learning more about Azafady, or want to volunteer yourself, check out their website at http://www.madagascar.co.uk/about-azafady/index.htm

If you're interested in learning more about Madagascar, please keep reading!

The Project 

I will be working with their Azafady Conservation Programme to study Lemur and herpetological (reptile and amphibian) populations. The programme’s goals are

·  To establish the density and distribution of the diurnal and nocturnal lemurs and reptile and amphibian populations in the Sainte Luce forest fragments.

·  To investigate the influence of edge effects on lemur and reptile and amphibian density and distribution in the Saint Luce forest fragments

In addition to collecting data for Azafady, I will be conducting my own research project studying lemur/ reptile and amphibian habitat fragmentation and the consequences of edge effects and human interaction. This project will serve as the Capstone project for my Bachelor’s degree in Environmental Studies and Ecology. I’ll be keeping a diary recording my involvement with Azafady and my personal observations in Madagascar, writing a paper detailing my research, and presenting on my experience when I get back to the U.S. (sometime in December). I’ll also write a blog based off my diary, which you can easily get access to (check out my perks!) I'll spend time studying the wild-life of the region, but also talking to  locals to hear their point of view on, well, pretty much anything we can talk about. Hopefully they'll be able to share some of their wisdom acquired from years of living in and with the forest. 

Although I plan on being actively involved in their lemur and herpetology research, Azafady  makes a point of placing their dedication to helping build strong local communities above individual volunteer preferences. It's a large part of what helps their charity make a difference in the region. That means that on a given day I could be out collecting data, helping replace threatened trees and plants, building much needed structures, teaching local kids about malaria prevention and sustainable environmental practices, or doing pretty much anything else I'm needed for. Regardless of what, specifically, I spend my time doing, I am sure of two things:  that I can help Azafady positively affect this struggling region and that I can form a strong capstone project based off my experience there.

Please help me take advantage of this amazing opportunity. This is precisely the kind of work I hope to make my career in and brings into play everything I’ve spent the last three years learning. It really is the perfect culmination of my studies at Cornell and will provide me with real-world experience (not to mention an incredibly unique capstone project) as I prepare to look for a job that will allow me to do what I love. I’ve spent my life in wonder of nature’s fascinating creatures and their beautifully intricate and complex interactions; I am passionate about helping preserve the natural diversity that makes our world so awe-inspiring. I’m also focused on finding ways for humans to co-exist positively within their eco-systems without having to face a choice between their own survival and survival of the wild-life around them (as many in Africa and other developing countries do). We, as Americans, rarely have to make that choice, so please help out so that others don’t either!


Primary Costs:

Azafady requires a minimum donation of £1,150 for the four weeks that I’ll be there (that’s $1,971.00 US dollars)

Air Travel cost: estimated $2,000

Travel insurance and vaccination/medical costs (with the danger of malaria and other scary diseases widespread and Africa currently experiencing its largest Ebola outbreak ever, I can’t take too many precautions regarding health) : estimated $1,000

Total cost: $5,000

As you can see, my actual costs are quite a bit more than what I’m asking for here. I’m hoping that my college will be able to provide some funding and I’m spending the summer working as a roofer to try and pay as much as I can myself. It’s hard (and hot) work, but it’ll be worth it if I can make my way to Madagascar. However, I won’t be able to raise as much as I need on my own, so I need your help, especially since much of this (especially plane tickets) needs to be paid for well in advance of my departure. Remember that your donation is going towards a registered charity, committed to humanitarian work and vital conservation and research efforts, either directly, as part of the required donation, or by helping me get to Madagascar to help them out! If I don't reach my goal and the money raised is not enough to send me to Madagascar, I will donate the entire sum to Azafady.

The Impact

The work done by the Azafady Conservation Programme is increasingly important as Azafady has recently expanded their areas of research to include two forest fragments that lay in the Rio Tinto/ QMM mining path and are ear-marked for ilmenite (titanium ore) mining. This mining is expected to remove two thirds of the remaining forest (which is already suffering from logging and agricultural disturbance), drastically affecting the rare species living there. Several types of geckos and snakes have never been seen anywhere but in these threatened areas!  Azafady’s research will help us better understand the largely unknown habits and ecologic niches of the lemurs, reptiles and amphibians in the area so that they can be effectively trans-located to more secure forest homes. It is likely that many of the herpetological (reptile and amphibian) species are specialists on particular plants, meaning they can only live on one certain type of plant! That’s extremely important information for properly managing the trans-location of the species. For example; moving a lot of threatened geckos to an area that doesn’t have any of their favorite spiky pandanus plants won’t do any good at all because they won’t have anywhere to live!

About Madagascar                    

I'll be working out of Tolagnaro (formerly known as Fort Dauphin) which you can see at the bottom of the map.

Madagascar is the fourth largest island in the world and can be found right off Africa's south-east coast. It is a particularly amazing place because it has one of the highest rates of endemic wild-life in the world (meaning they exist only in Madagascar!) with 80% of the vegetation and 90% of the animal life endemic to the island! Madagascar is the only place you can see a lemur in the wild - and you might see any one of over 100 species and sub-species. Madagascar is also home to two thirds of the world's chameleon species (including the worlds smallest chameleon, about the size of a Bumble Bee), a unique, cat-like predator called the fossa (pronounced "foosha"), and myriad plant species including palms, boabs, orchids and the Madagascar periwinkle, which has been used to treat leukemia and Hodgkin's Disease, as well as other cancers. Unfortunately, all these incredible plants and animals are seriously threatened. 90% of the island's original forest has vanished and dozens of animal species have dissappeared, including the ten foot tall elephant bird and several of the larger lemur species (one of which was as big as a gorilla!) More will surely follow. 

The native Malagasey people are also struggling. Madagascar is the 11th poorest nation in the word with 69% of the population living below the poverty line of one dollar per day. Many work in the agricultural sector on vanilla, cloves, or ylang-ylang plantations which are often operated un-sustainably by foreign corporations and continue to encroach on what remains of the country's natural forest. Mining for metal ores and oil also continue to contribute to habitat destruction and degradation. Azafady's holistic approach focuses on Malagasey communities, as well as the environment they live in, and works to help them live sustainably. When people are forced to make the decision to help preserve endangered plants and animals or simply survive, survival will always take first priority. Azafady aims to alleviate stresses on local communities so that they can help preserve their beautiful and rare surroundings without having to struggle for their daily existence. They offer a variety of humanitarian aid, and focus on providing education while also striving to learn from the Malagasey, as I hope to do. However well educated, no ecologist has as deep a connection to and understanding of the land as someone who has grown up in and lived from the forest.

A quick lemur fact: since lemur's pelvic bones are developed for life in the trees (and not bipedal ground motion) they have a unique way of moving on the ground...


Its pretty hilarious and sort of adorable too

Risks and Challenges

This project is going to take a lot of work, but its something I'm super excited to be working for. 

Here are some of the many risks and challenges I'll face:

  • I'll need to learn as much Malagasey (the native language) as I possibly can
  • I'll have to learn to communicate with people without a common language.
  • Not only have I never been out of the USA, I jumped out of the only airplane I've ever set foot in. It was awesome, but now I have to learn to navigate airports.
  • I may (worst case scenario) get malaria, need emergency medical care, and get expatriated.
  • I may get bitten by a lemur! Yikes!
  • I have to submit (and get approved)  my project proposal to my capstone team, comprised of trusted professors and mentors at Cornell College.

Other ways you can help

I realize that not everyone can make a monetary contribution.

If that's you but you still want to help; get the word out about my campaign!  Tell your friends, send out an e-mail, promote it on social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, etc) or use the handy Indiegogo share tools!

Remember, every little bit helps!

Thanks so much for reading whether or not you're able to make a contribution!

story:
What Is Our Elevator Pitch?

Growing mountains of solid waste in Lusaka are a complex problem that impacts many lives. aimwith is launching a partnership project enabled by our unique funding mechanism to drive sustainable, positive impact for better education, transportation and collaboration capabilities to solve this issue.


What Inspired Us To Do This? 

My journey started after a personal invitation by Madam Edith Nawakwi, Zambia’s former minister of finance, to visit its’ capital Lusaka to explore a pilot project for my social equity startup, aimwith. During this trip, we met with many amazing and courageous people working in the public/private sector, in social enterprises, as experts, and people from the local community. Together, we investigated their perspectives on the complex challenge of managing the growing mountains of uncollected waste. We discovered that no single entity was responsible for leading a solution and that there had never been a joint effort with a clear and mutually beneficial outcome attached. This lack of ability to invest in change together left the problem not only unresolved, but also is making it also increasingly worse. This reaffirmed for me that aimwith was needed in the world.

What Is The Problem?

Waste management is one of the biggest environmental issues in Africa. With Zambia experiencing record growth and GDP projected at 7.3% by end of 2013, tackling this issue before it impacts more people’s lives is crucial. While there are many ongoing but fragmented efforts by multiple stakeholders to deal with this issue, only 40% of the waste (trash) of Lusaka's population of 3 million is collected, also posing serious health and economic risks.


What Are We Doing About It?

We are raising $50,000 on Indiegogo to conduct an initial feasibility study in Lusaka, Zambia for a targeted population of 20,000 households. The study will verify and quantify the problems we discovered with the Lusaka-based social enterprise, Neighbour’s Friend, and identify measurable goals for a successful outcome. It will also build the business case for all parties involved so they can invest in change, together. This study will serve as a new, best-practice example/approach to the solid waste management issue and help us attract investors to this capital-intensive, but promising project. As a result, we'll be able to tackle the solid waste management issue in an honest and sustainable manner. 


A feasibility study is an analysis of the potential of a particular project. This research will allow us to...

1. Define the social issue: What are all the issues people face that lead to waste mismanagement?

  • Analyzing and gathering data on population trends and root issues to be addressed
  • Collaboration amongst stakeholders to understand strategic objectives
  • Decide on geographical focus

2. Define the outcome metric: How do we know we are ultimately successful?

  • Research and decide on desired outcomes for the targeted population
  • Assessment of measurement options

3. Define the intervention: What action needs to be taken to reach the common goal?

  • Verify the current specific needs of the target population  
  • Research on interventions to meet these specific needs

aimwith is partnering up with Neighbour's Friend on this project. aimwith is a online social equity marketplace for social and environmental impact. Our market-based approach brings together crowdfunders, impact investors, and philanthropic foundations to fund outcome-based projects carried out by the most innovative social enterprises. Our unique model includes crowdfunders to jointly fund our projects along with impact investors. As a result, creating this multi-party partnerships to address these issues will give working capital and autonomy to Neighbour's Friend to shape their waste management operations to fit the current specific needs of the targeted population of 20,000 households to focus on the predefined outcome.

What Will We Do With Your Money?

  • Travel- (Flights)- $3,500
  • Feasibility Study- $40,000
  • Indiegogo Perks- $3,000
  • Indiegogo Fees- $3,500

What Is The Measurable Impact That Will Happen?

Neighbour’s Friend, a nonprofit created by ambitious local women, is looking to expand their solid waste management operations by buying more equipment and trucks, hiring youth, educating the communities about handling waste and offering their services to more customers. This project will be addressing some of the root causes we have already identified as well as other such as: Transportation will require more vehicles so local entrepreneurs can meet demand as subcontractors. A community education and engagement program will need to be implemented to raise awareness for proper waste disposal, addressing illegal dumping and burning, and the resulting health impact. Capital will need to be injected to build functional capacity for this but also to incentivize a sustainable, multi-party collaboration. 

What is the impact to date and expected impact in the future?

Since our trip, we have established the trust of Lusaka’s Waste Management Association to join our partnership with Neighbour's Friend along with other organizations in the public and private sector. Also, we have verified and documented that Neighbour's Friend is a community-trusted social enterprise that can meet our expectations. To raise awareness, we filmed a documentary to showcase the tremendous opportunity in helping the Zambian community improve the management of waste on Nov. 6th, 2013 on our YouTube channel.
The longer-term capabilities we seek to build will include producing energy from landfills, recycling plastics and turning biodegradable materials into fertilizer or building materials. 



MORE QUESTIONS? EMAIL ME AT founder@aimwith.org

story:
Our Story

Dear Friends, 


A year ago I had the opportunity to travel to a Tibetan community located in a far eastern part of India.  My uncle Rodney had befriended a Tibetan monk, Lama Tashi Bapu, and promised him he would help him help his people. I was more or less tagging along for an epic adventure in the Himalayas. I knew that uncle Rodney was planning on helping Tashi build a water filtration system for a school and university that Tashi ran, but I really didn't know what I was getting myself into. Fortunately I had my sister by my side. 

After a long journey we arrived at the Tibetan Cultural Institute to the dreadful news that of the 190 students, about 20 had reported cases of Typhoid.  Others were sick and had not seen a doctor and a handful of others still had confirmed cases of hepatitis A. Both diseases are fatal if untreated. 


All this was due to contaminated drinking water. Generally human or animal feces would get washed into streams during heavy downpours and without any real filtration would end up in the drinking water. The nearest public hospital is a few days journey away. Fortunately, in this case, the military hospital and road workers hospital nearby saw and treated the sick students, but full medical testing for the variety of ailments related to the consumption of contaminated water was prohibitively expensive and went undiagnosed.

 

The students at this school are not the only ones drinking contaminated water. There are countless villages in the region that rely on the same supply. The lack of accessible medical facilities compounds the problem, in many cases turning avoidable maladies into fatal illnesses.


It is our plan to return to this beautiful and remote part of the world and provide the inhabitants with the tools and the education to improve their quality of life. With your help, we can help these people take immediate steps toward longer and healthier lives.


Thank you for your support! 


-Yasmine




The Impact

Improve the lives of the inhabitants of rural Tibetan India, saving the lives of countless people in the process. 


The Plan 

A two-pronged approach:

1. Provide families with small point of use water filtration kits that will last several years and only cost about $40 each.

2. With the help of Lama Tashi and his students we will provide basic sanitation and healthcare education to ensure that everyone understands how and why to use the filters. 


The Goal 

Our goal is use the funds from this campaign to purchase 150 filters (or more!). All funds will be used directly on the filters. Travel and shipping costs will be covered separately. 


**All donations are 100% tax deductible and will go through Rodney's nonprofit, International Voices for Care, a registered 501(c)(3) non-profit charity.** 




Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out!!!

If you are unable to make a donation today or just want to help in other ways, please tell all your friends and your friends' friends. The more people we get involved, the more good we can do!

 

This is just the tip of the iceberg. There are countless other projects like building a clinic or bringing books so the students can have a library.


If you are interested in volunteering or helping in other ways we encourage you to check out our website and contact us today! www.voices4care.org


Thank you!
