story:
UPDATE 17 APRIL 2014

Meet Patricia Cori at the event! Singing the Oceans Alive coincides with her new book The Emissary. Check out this clip to learn more!

The children are out there, Singing the Oceans Alive. Won't you add your voice? The oceans are calling out.

A Concert for Dolphins and Whales!

Singing the Oceans Alive
Featuring the Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra and wonderful artists from around the world.

Presented by Patricia Cori 
CEO and founder of Save Earth's Oceans
Produced by Peter Brightman
CEO of International Entertainment Corporation

25th April 2014
Fairfield Halls, Croydon, UK

If ever you were in any doubt as to how damaging sonar is to whales, please watch this clip SONAR DISRUPTS THE WHALES: courtesy of Brian Smith, Earthjustice.org:


(A portion of the monies raised, after production costs of our fundraising concert, SINGING THE OCEANS ALIVE, will be allocated to Earthjustice for their fight against navy sonar testing in our oceans).


Thank you for visiting this incredibly important campaign!

Singing the Oceans Alive is a benefit concert, at Fairfield Halls, (Croydon), London on 25 April 2014. It is designed as a dynamic collaboration of artists from around the
world, who are offering their music by way of celebrating the music of whales and dolphins of our oceans, to be played along with the world-renowned Royal Philharmonic Concert Orchestra.

What is the concert about?

Music is a universal language made up from various frequencies, and we know that cetaceans also communicate using frequencies: some we can hear, but others we cannot. It's those we cannot hear which are of interest, and researchers are hoping, in time, to shed light on what these frequencies may mean to humans.

Many marine biologist and scientists are actively pursuing research that involves breaking the language code that they believe is being communicated from whales and dolphins alike. It is believed their music is not merely about mating rituals, or for hunting and other physical activities but, rather, that it represents a complex, universal language of its own.

Cetaceans in peril!

With recent reports of yet more military sonar experimentation in the oceans being carried out, it looks likely that untold damage to whales and dolphins can be expected to all but wipe out vast communities of these magnificent cetaceans, and with that, all knowledge of what we may find out, with so little yet known, will also die.

The Navy’s mid-frequency sonar bombards whales with noise so intense - up to 236 decibels - that it can actually cause their internal organs to haemorrhage. Navy ships are scheduled to conduct torpedo tests, bombing exercises and underwater explosions - some 1.1 million of these events overall. That’s an average of one detonation every two minutes for the next five years, with many of them in and around sensitive whale habitat where cetaceans mate and feed.

We don't know exactly how many marine mammals will die from this activity, but the projected take of marine mammals is anywhere from 11- 33 million…this is almost incomprehensible, and most definitely not acceptable. The damage to communities of cetaceans is a major issue, and one that needs to be addressed. 

 "Save Earth’s Oceans, Inc, is dedicated to helping resolve the ecological problems that we all know are destroying our oceans." says Ms. Cori, adding "We aim to help raise awareness around sonar activity. I have recently started a petition to help bring a stop to the barbaric practice of sonar experiments that is so damaging to marine life, and in particular to whales and dolphins.”

Singing the Oceans Alive to put you in the picture!

What we aim to deliver on April 25, 2014 is a greater understanding of how, like the whale and dolphin song that we seek to understand, our music is also a universal language that transcends cultures, races and borders. It is an evening of tribute to the music of the entire planet, and an awakening to the majesty of these incredible sea beings.

We need your help please!

The costs of creating such an event successfully are intensive, and we need help from the community to do this right to get the message out to the world through the mainstream media. Meeting our goal will pay for an adequate public relations effort, transportation for artists, accommodation, technical staff and equipment. We hope to be able to raise enough funding to be able to stream this event worldwide.

We need your help! We have rallied people from many other organisations, and now we are calling out for your support, asking you to be part of this noble effort to reach out to the global community, and help people recognise the vital importance the cetaceans play on our planet, weaving the music of the oceans while they struggle to survive, as many are on the endangered species list.

If you care about whales and dolphins, and want to do something positive to help raise global awareness and a deeper understanding of their importance—to adults and children around the world—please help us fund this worthy project by donating what you can.

This is a strictly non-profit event. Any proceeds will go to Save Earth's Oceans, Inc., to fund campaigns we will undertake for the protection of the oceans, with a specific focus on helping the cetaceans strive and live as free, sovereign beings.

For the whales and dolphins, and all the ocean beings, we thank you for everything you do to help protect our oceans, and keep the music alive.

And lastly, don't forget, if you are contributing from the U.S., because Save Earth's Oceans Inc,. are officially recognised as a non-profit with full status from the IRS, your donation can be deducted from your U.S. taxes!

www.singingtheoceansalive.com
www.saveearthsoceans.org

About Patricia Cori

Last year, Patricia co-founded the global non-profit organisation, SAVE EARTH’S OCEANS, INC., which is dedicated to help clean up the beaches and oceans of our planet worldwide, to awaken people to the importance of protecting the sea mammals, and to help restore the balance of our fragile ecosystems of the oceans. As President and CEO of the organisation, she is determined to raise the consciousness of human beings around the globe to the potential of the human spirit to alter the course of our destruction of the environment and to re-establish the harmony of Earth in balance.

Patricia Cori is a tireless campaigner and active supporter of many initiatives around raising awareness of the plight of cetaceans and Earth’s fragile eco-system. Through her own radio shows, public speaking and published books, she is helping awaken people to the peril facing whales and dolphins, and all marine life. She is an advocate for solution-based initiatives, having not only undertaken her own research first hand on several whale expeditions and swimming with wild dolphins, she also actively assists in helping fundraise for like-minded organisations’ campaigns. Using her powerful position as a best-selling author with the media, and her global readership, she is able to drive home the urgency – not only to the already involved and aware people around the globe, but also to the greater public.

Her latest book, THE EMISSARY, (published by North Atlantic Books/Random House distribution), is to be released in the U.K. March 24th 2014. Her first novel, she cleverly weaves the message of whale and dolphin conversation and this very question of their communications into the enthralling story, which is already receiving accolades from key voices in media. The film and TV rights have already been acquired by Global Universal Pictures in Hollywood, to be developed into a major motion picture. Her message and her passion for the work she has embarked upon are definitely reaching the mainstream.

Patricia has recently launched a campaign against the sonar testing by the military. 
To support this petition, please visit: http://www.thepetitionsite.com/400/292/287/stop-navy-sonar-impact-on-the-whales-and-dolphins-plain-and-simple/

Patricia has recently launched a campaign against the sonar testing by the military. To support this petition, please visit: http://www.thepetitionsite.com/400/292/287/stop-navy-sonar-impact-on-the-whales-and-dolphins-plain-and-simple/

story:
Though you wouldn't know it from the name, we are an Organic Surf Wax company, using 100% of or profits to Provide Clean Drinking Water Systems to communities that don't have access to clean water, worldwide.

  • We are a group of environmentally conscious surfers and photographers, with backgrounds in renewable energy, water distribution/treatment, and the will to make a difference in the world.
  • We have several surf shops selling our wax, consistently reordering, and adding new shops weekly.
  • We have already delivered several of our filters to Tanzania, Africa, and Tijuana, Mexico.
  • This campaign is our chance to build on the existing momentum and create awareness around our environmentally responsible surf wax, and apparel, in effort to continue delivering our filtration systems, free of charge, to communities abroad.  
  • For each dollar earned in this campaign, we will provide 10 gallons of filtered drinking water.  That means for every $1,000 raised, we will deliver and set up 10,000 gallons of water purification systems, as we have done in Africa (Orphanage and Villages) and Mexico (Orphanages).

What We Need:

        

1.  We need to raise funds that allow us to purchase our Surf Wax ingredients, beeswax and tree resin, in bulk, so that we can drive down our costs and have more funds available to supply more water purification systems.

2.  We have outgrown our garage production, and are moving into a commercial facility in Santa Ana California to keep up with our current demand.

3.  The more we can raise, the faster we can get our water filters to people that are in desperate need.

   = 

The Impact:

You will have the most direct impact on families in need of water, around the globe. 

  • The Wax:  Being organic, we produce a surf wax that is safe for the ocean and it's inhabitants. 
  • The Water:  Purchase with a Purpose - We are a Surf company based on a culture of providing a much needed resource, around the world.
  • The success of this campaign will generate 100,000 gallons of purified water, and hopefully much more.
  • You will be able to see your filter system installed as it is tracked on Facebook and Instagram.


    Challenges:

    • We have more demand from our re-sellers than we can currently meet.
    • We need more funds to ramp up to a much larger production level, including more wax melting equipment
    • We hope that this 30 day campaign enables us to far exceed our goals. 
    • The only risk is that we are unable to generate the revenue to ramp up immediately, which doesn't hurt the business, but delays the time to get water filters out to people that need them now.

           

      Other Ways You Can Help:

      • Don't Surf?   Buy some lip balm, a sticker, or a shirt from our website!  Every dollar counts!
      • No funds to spare?  Spread the word!  
      • Follow us on Instagram: @HuevosWax     www.instagram.com/huevoswax 
      • Find us on Facebook:  Huevos Wax    www.facebook.com/huevoswax

      And that's all there is to it :)

      Thank you so much for your contribution, or for just spreading the word!

      The Huevos Wax Team

      www.HuevosWax.com

story:
This video is a presentation of Novi Sad made by Luka Grozdanic and Miracle studios .

Novi Sad is 2nd biggest city in Serbia and its and lies on the banks of the river Danube. Exit festival has brought many people from all over the world to our city and im sure, all of them quickly realised why we love our city so much.
Beautifull fortress saves a lot of good memories, parks and first kisses on the bench, this city has given us so much ... We want to give back all the love with this great project.

Our goal is to improve environment in our city by teaching school kids to recycle and preserve the nature. Containers we install in schools will develop a habit of correct waste disposal and raise  the awareness for nature conservation. Best thing about our approach is the fact that kids influence their families and chage the way their parents think about waste disposal.

Association of Citizens "Neighbor" has been around for 10 years and we put most of our efforts in the education of children and adults about the problem of pollution of nature. Educating children in schools affects the awareness of senior citizens, because their children and grandchildren often call for attention to this problem.

Serbia recycles only 6-7%, while the European average of about 60-70%, which explains how necessary it is to intensify efforts in this field.

The aim of our project is education and installing sets of special containers in schools, so that the children acquire the habit of collecting waste and its separation and learn about problems and possible solutions.
We use our good relations with local media to promote our project and inform citizens about necessity of recycling. Amongst all, we have active phone number which our citizens can use to contact us if they have all sorts of electronic waste they want to get rid off. We come to their address, free of charge, and collect it.

The biggest problem we currently face is the small purchase price for recyclable waste. Our expenses are greater than income and therefore we are not able to invest in the development of new containers as well as organizing events such as Waste collection days we occasionally organized in certain parts of the city and the villages.
We managed to install only few sets of recycling containers (currently only 5 schools in our area got the containers). To get to a point where we can earn enough to cover our expenses and invest in further development we need at least 25 more sets of containers.

Containers we installed in one of schools

Covering 30 out of 50 schools in our area would give big boost to our efforts since we could cover our expenses and speed up our progression.
Education of school kids is important and its good way to prevent further pollution which will lead to cleaner environment.
Using reward system, where schools get something in return for collected waste we motivate kids and give their efforts a sense of value. Once collected waste is sold, we use part of the profit to buy soccer balls, basketballs, other sport necessities, computers or we do needed repairs. 
In small village near Novi Sad, after successful "Recycling day" we repaired school soccer goals and kids were able to play soccer on that field for the first time after 10 years.

 This is how their goals looked before our intervention!!!

Kids responded to our call for action at very large amount and collected well over 500kg of electronic waste and about 200kg of paper and plastic.
Schools respond in great manner to our project, but without financial support it is impossible to increase our efforts. Due to quite poor financial situation in our country, most companies don't want or can't  invest funds in our project. That is why we ask, all of you good people at this site to help us in this good cause.

To give you just a slight hint of the problems we face in Serbia watch this movie:


This is the movie about biggest river in south Serbia and this river is just one of many polluted rivers. Pollution of this magnitude affects not only the citizens of Serbia, but also to all the countries in the region, and indirectly to the rest of the world since the water from the river into the Danube, and on its way to the black sea.


By placing a large number of these recycling containers would create the foundation for a constantly increasing number of schools involved in our activities, and thus would increase the number of citizens who would be informed about the problems.

This way we would, in a very short time, raise the percentage of recycling in our city, as well as in Serbia. With the growth of our project we would impact on the consciousness of the rest of Serbia which would lead us to our ultimate goal: a cleaner and nicer Serbia and cleaner and nicer Earth.

What We Need

  • We need necessary funds for production of sets of containers that will be placed in elementary and high schools. Making each set of containers costs 500 USD (4 containers - paper, plastic, aluminum cans, small electronic devices). These containers would be placed in schools of Novi Sad and the more important places in our city. For the profitability of our project need to put at least 25 sets of containers.
  • One part of the money will be used to organize Recycling days in the surrounding villages and smaller towns, specific actions to clean illegal dump sites, particularly the vulnerable localities, as well as raising awareness of the Serbian population about the problems we face. 
  • Even if we don't manage to collect desired funding, it's a start. Money would still be invested production of containers and everything over this amount will be used in organisation of Recycling days, cleaning illegal dump sites and activities needed to clean polluted rivers.

The Impact

As mentioned earlier, our campaign would initialy rise percentage of recycling in our country, which would indirectly affect the pollution reduction at the global level.

More waste recycled would mean cleaner rivers, which would again reduce pollution of Danube (2nd biggest river in Europe), Black sea and indirectly Mediterranean sea and Atlantic ocean.

We are witnessing a growing climate change at the global level, and any contribution is very important. Success of our mission would hopefully be copied in other countries which would produce chain reaction that leads to a cleaner planet.
Association of Citizens "Neighbor" actively contributes to the preservation of nature for many years and is very well-known locally. Awarded by the Provincial authorities for their contribution in nature preservation.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Help us to spread the word about our project, use the Indiegogo share tools and let's save our planet while there's still something to be saved!!!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Clean & Proud started with two people sharing a passion for nature and the country of Malawi. After noticing the amount of litter degrading all areas of the country we decided to do something about this issue.

Our background is in environmental sciences, we have both worked in the African bush and some of the most beautiful areas in the world. Seeing such natural beauty degraded by haphazard discard of rubbish is heart breaking – especially as it is a solvable problem. Malawi as a country does not have the means to address this problem unless we all come together to aid in reversing this situation.

In 2018 Clean & Proud was born and we set to work building the foundations for a plastic recycling enterprise that will make a difference and address the increasing amounts of plastic waste.

WHERE WE ARE AT NOW

Currently, we have based our first branch in Mzuzu (the biggest city in the North). We are working with two machines to process plastic that has been collected on the street and create new products from it.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Having expended £3000 of our personal finances to set the foundations up, we now seek your assistance.

  • To go carbon neutral with a workshop powered by solar avoiding the environmental impact of running machinery off electrics.
  • To expand and create new workshops around Malawi.
  • To change the current mind-set of people in Malawi regarding waste management for a lasting impact by employing outreach officers that will educate communities and youth.

 

NEEDS

COSTS

QUANTITY

Workshop in Mzuzu

Solar system

£5250

1

Bicycle with trailer for collection

£60

1

Workshop in Kande (Nkhata Bay district)

Shredder

£305

1

Compressor

£170

1

Transport of machines

£30

1

Mould

£37.5

2

Solar system

£5250

1

Bicycle with trailer for collection

£60

1

Both locations

Outreach officer

£210 per year

2

TOTAL

£11,582.50 = $14,834.00

 

PERKS

For every donation above £25, we will provide the local school with 1 recycled plastic pencil case produced from our workshop.

For every donation above £50, we will provide the local school with 1 recycled plastic school bag produced from our workshop.

For every donation above £100, we will provide a pair of recycled tyre and leather sandals to the most productive plastic collector.

For every donation above £200, we will provide 1 recycled plastic pencil case and 1 recycled plastic school bag to the local school and 1 recycled tyre and leather pair of sandals to the most productive plastic collector.

Every donor will receive updates on donations to the school, project progress and new product ranges with the chance to give us advice and help develop the project.

 

If we do not reach our fundraising goal of £11,600, we will continue with the expansion and outreach program as far as donations will allow us. However, we will wait for further capital to equip our workshops with solar systems and expansion will be much slower, reducing our immediate impact.

 

OUR CHALLENGES

  1. Changing the general mind-set on plastic waste.

Our solution - Outreach officers – educating communities and the youth, combined with financial rewarding for bringing plastic to our recycling collection points.

  1. Ensuring that our recycled plastic products have a long life span and the     potential to be recycled again.

Our solution – All plastic products we produce have the international label according to their plastic category which helps in secondary recycling.

If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help us! Please share this with as many people you can and make as much noise about what we are doing.

story:
"This mentoring fellowship is happening only because of the generous donations made possible by the Elyssa Rosen Memorial Fund. It's absolutely incredible what Elyssa's legacy has created, her spirit truly lives on." 

- Beth Parke, Executive Director, Society of Environmental Journalists

Voices for the Environment; Elyssa Rosen's Legacy

Elyssa Rosen's life will be forever defined by her ability to bring to light the most important stories and news focused on conserving our world's most important natural resources. She gave voice to the environment so that future generations might live in a world better than she found it. And she believed wholeheartedly in the importance of environmental journalists. 

In October of 2013, while at a major conference to establish Marine conservation areas near Antarctica, Elyssa passed away tragically in a SCUBA diving accident off the coast of Tasmania. Though she is missed greatly, her legacy lives on through all those she touched, worked with, laughed with, and loved life with. 

As her family, friends, and colleagues came together to celebrate her life, it became clear that she would not want the work to stop. 

To honor Elyssa and carry on her legacy, her family, friends, and colleagues partnered with the Society for Environmental Journalists (SEJ) to establish the 2014 Elyssa Rosen Memorial Mentoring Fellowship Fund.


$10,000 Raised - Help Raise an Additional $10,000!

As a result of an incredible outpouring of support, an initial $10,000, was raised for SEJ's mentoring fellowship for aspiring environmental journalists, providing travel costs for mentor-mentee pairs to meet up at SEJ’s 2014 Annual Conference in New Orleans this September. 

This fund helps these rising journalists to gain valuable experience, strengthen their reporting skills, and build stronger relationships for a lifetime.

SEJ has received nearly a dozen qualified applications for the mentoring fellowship and it's great news! Thank you to everyone who contributed to the first $10,000 (see the list below). However, the $10,000 in initial funding will only allow SEJ to accept half of the qualified applications. 

Our goal is to raise an additional $10,000 to fund every qualified applicant.

Elyssa understood this opportunity. Whenever she could she would try to attend the conference. It was a place she believed was so important to the future of environmental news coverage. 

As Elyssa's family we're calling on her friends and those in journalism and conservation communities to help us double the impact of this program by making contributions and help us raise another $10,000 to reach a total of $20,000 to honor Elyssa. 

We're not sure if we'll be able to do this every year, so we hope that this year we can establish a legacy for SEJ to build on and show that a mentoring fellowship of this size will leave a lasting impression.

If there's one thing that Elyssa taught us, is that our work is never done, that we must keep pushing forward to finish what we started. 

We hope you'll join us in honoring the living memory of Elyssa's life.  


About the "Perks" - Become
An Honorary Penguin For Life

We're not in a position to offer you anything in return for your donation, other than the incredible distinction that you've helped to carry on Elyssa's legacy. Elyssa was extremely fond of penguins and during her work on the Antarctic Marine Sanctuaries she embraced PEW's Global Penguin Conservation campaign to raise awareness and famously shared with so many the online quiz "What's Your Penguin Personality?" (Elyssa and her two sisters test results indentified them all as Chinstrap Penguins). 

So when you donate to Elyssa's fund we've decided that you automatically become an honorary penguin for life - something we know Elyssa would love and remind you of - and hope you'll carry that distinction with you. Learn more about the different types of penguins. 


More About Elyssa Rosen

The Environment's Voice

When Elyssa passed away the world lost a leader in environmental media, advocacy, and education. 

Elyssa knew the value of environmental and natural resource focused journalists. She dedicated her life to working with them, telling important stories, and constantly seeking out the best and brightest reporters to bringing forward stories about natural resource issues, all too often pushed to the back page or never pursued because of a lack of resources or understanding. 

In addition to her tireless work over three decades - spanning from her time with the Sierra Club, to her work to protect Nevada's Great Basin, to the project she was working on with the global community and the PEW Environment Group when she passed away to establish marine reserves in the Southern Oceans of Antarctica - she was deeply passionate about sharing her work and experience with the next generation of environmental journalists and emerging media professionals. 

Here are a number of ways that Elyssa was and is remembered, and some of her work that was featured by environmental journalists. 

Reflections & Remembrances of Elyssa's Life

  • PEW Environment: Remembering Our Friend & Colleague Elyssa Rosen
  • Stuff.Co.NZ - Sea sanctuaries as lasting tribute 
  • Inspired to Act: For the Oceans, For a Great Friend
  • Reno News Review - Left Foot Forward by Sheila Leslie - Thanks for good friends gone
  • To My Lady Friends - A Remembrance by Launce Rake

Some of Elyssa's Work as Covered by Environmental Journalists

  • Sierra Magazine: Canada's Forgotten Coast
  • 10 reasons to create marine reserves around Antarctica
  • High Country News: Gold mines are sucking aquifers dry
  • SFGate: Firm wins OK to log redwoods
  • Las Vegas Sun: Heavy price for gold
  • The Planet: Forging Non-Traditional Alliances
  • The Colorado Independent: Wildfire fuels debate on state versus national roadless rules
  • KNPR: Nevada Mining - Children (listen below)


    Ky Plaskon visited a Nevada Gold mine and explored some of the environmental controversy surrounding one of Nevada's most profitable industries. One way the industry maintains favor in the state is by donating to politicians like most industries do. Mining donated more than 4-million to congress and 100-thosand dollars to Nevada politicians last year. Another way mining companies gain favor is through educating children about the industry. KNPR's Ky Plaskon reports. 


Founding Contributors:
First $10,000

2014 Contributors:

story_txt:
"This mentoring fellowship is happening only because of the generous donations made possible by the Elyssa Rosen Memorial Fund. It's absolutely incredible what Elyssa's legacy has created, her spirit truly lives on." - Beth Parke, Executive Director, Society of Environmental Journalists
Voices for the Environment; Elyssa Rosen's Legacy
Elyssa Rosen's life will be forever defined by her ability to bring to light the most important stories and news focused on conserving our world's most important natural resources. She gave voice to the environment so that future generations might live in a world better than she found it. And she believed wholeheartedly in the importance of environmental journalists. In October of 2013, while at a major conference to establish Marine conservation areas near Antarctica, Elyssa passed away tragically in a SCUBA diving accident off the coast of Tasmania. Though she is missed greatly, her legacy lives on through all those she touched, worked with, laughed with, and loved life with.  As her family, friends, and colleagues came together to celebrate her life, it became clear that she would not want the work to stop. 
To honor Elyssa and carry on her legacy, her family, friends, and colleagues partnered with the Society for Environmental Journalists (SEJ) to establish the 2014 Elyssa Rosen Memorial Mentoring Fellowship Fund.$10,000 Raised - Help Raise an Additional $10,000!As a result of an incredible outpouring of support, an initial $10,000, was raised for SEJ's mentoring fellowship for aspiring environmental journalists, providing travel costs for mentor-mentee pairs to meet up at SEJ’s 2014 Annual Conference in New Orleans this September. This fund helps these rising journalists to gain valuable experience, strengthen their reporting skills, and build stronger relationships for a lifetime.SEJ has received nearly a dozen qualified applications for the mentoring fellowship and it's great news! Thank you to everyone who contributed to the first $10,000 (see the list below). However, the $10,000 in initial funding will only allow SEJ to accept half of the qualified applications. 
Our goal is to raise an additional $10,000 to fund every qualified applicant.Elyssa understood this opportunity. Whenever she could she would try to attend the conference. It was a place she believed was so important to the future of environmental news coverage. As Elyssa's family we're calling on her friends and those in journalism and conservation communities to help us double the impact of this program by making contributions and help us raise another $10,000 to reach a total of $20,000 to honor Elyssa. We're not sure if we'll be able to do this every year, so we hope that this year we can establish a legacy for SEJ to build on and show that a mentoring fellowship of this size will leave a lasting impression.If there's one thing that Elyssa taught us, is that our work is never done, that we must keep pushing forward to finish what we started. We hope you'll join us in honoring the living memory of Elyssa's life.  About the "Perks" - BecomeAn Honorary Penguin For LifeWe're not in a position to offer you anything in return for your donation, other than the incredible distinction that you've helped to carry on Elyssa's legacy. Elyssa was extremely fond of penguins and during her work on the Antarctic Marine Sanctuaries she embraced PEW's Global Penguin Conservation campaign to raise awareness and famously shared with so many the online quiz "What's Your Penguin Personality?" (Elyssa and her two sisters test results indentified them all as Chinstrap Penguins). So when you donate to Elyssa's fund we've decided that you automatically become an honorary penguin for life - something we know Elyssa would love and remind you of - and hope you'll carry that distinction with you. Learn more about the different types of penguins. More About Elyssa RosenThe Environment's VoiceWhen Elyssa passed away the world lost a leader in environmental media, advocacy, and education. Elyssa knew the value of environmental and natural resource focused journalists. She dedicated her life to working with them, telling important stories, and constantly seeking out the best and brightest reporters to bringing forward stories about natural resource issues, all too often pushed to the back page or never pursued because of a lack of resources or understanding. In addition to her tireless work over three decades - spanning from her time with the Sierra Club, to her work to protect Nevada's Great Basin, to the project she was working on with the global community and the PEW Environment Group when she passed away to establish marine reserves in the Southern Oceans of Antarctica - she was deeply passionate about sharing her work and experience with the next generation of environmental journalists and emerging media professionals. Here are a number of ways that Elyssa was and is remembered, and some of her work that was featured by environmental journalists. Reflections & Remembrances of Elyssa's Life
PEW Environment: Remembering Our Friend & Colleague Elyssa Rosen

Stuff.Co.NZ - Sea sanctuaries as lasting tribute 
Inspired to Act: For the Oceans, For a Great Friend
Reno News Review - Left Foot Forward by Sheila Leslie - Thanks for good friends gone
To My Lady Friends - A Remembrance by Launce Rake
Some of Elyssa's Work as Covered by Environmental Journalists
Sierra Magazine: Canada's Forgotten Coast
10 reasons to create marine reserves around Antarctica

High Country News: Gold mines are sucking aquifers dry


SFGate: Firm wins OK to log redwoods


Las Vegas Sun: Heavy price for gold

The Planet: Forging Non-Traditional Alliances

The Colorado Independent: Wildfire fuels debate on state versus national roadless rules


KNPR: Nevada Mining - Children (listen below)Ky Plaskon visited a Nevada Gold mine and explored some of the environmental controversy surrounding one of Nevada's most profitable industries. One way the industry maintains favor in the state is by donating to politicians like most industries do. Mining donated more than 4-million to congress and 100-thosand dollars to Nevada politicians last year. Another way mining companies gain favor is through educating children about the industry. KNPR's Ky Plaskon reports. 

Founding Contributors: First $10,0002014 Contributors:Jane Braxton Little  |  Andrew Burness | Abigail Clark | Jeanne Cragin  |  Jane Danowitz | Michael Gaebler | Laura Greenstein  |  Elizabeth Karan  |  Tony Livernois  |  The Pew Charitable Trusts  | Velma Smith  |  Imogen Zethoven2013 Contributors:Rachel Brittin  |  Todd Denton  |  Marie Dolcini & Giovanni Guerrera  |  Mary Engel  |  John Franzen  | Michelle Geis & Thom Wallace  |  Stephanie & Mitchell Greenblatt  |  Marilyn Heiman  |  Edrie Irvine  |  Andrea Kavanagh  |  Mel & Karen Kronick  |  Alicia LaPorte  |  Gerald Leape  |  Linda Lucas  |  Claire Moser  | Matt Newberry  |  Sue Newberry  |  Lane Nothman  |  Andi Pearl  |  Alex Rate  |  Susan Roberts  |  Erik Robinson  |  Joanne Rosenbush  |  Julie Sigunick  |  Judith Stevens & Martin Greenstein  |  JoAnn Stokes  |  Elisabeth Visser  |  Deb Waterstone  |  Joshua Wenderoff  |  Elisabeth Whitebread  |  Susan Whitmore

story:
Summary

Powershift Pilipinas is a historic gathering of more than 200 passionate and committed youth leaders from across the Philippines seeking a qualitative leap in the climate justice movement, particularly issues and concerns of communities directly impacted by climate change. It is also a clear response to the impacts brought by Super Typhoon Yolanda (international name: Haiyan) as the foremost climate issue the country faces today.

Organizers at Powershift Pilipinas have invited us attend this gathering in order to help close the gap between communities on the front lines of climate change in the Philippines and Filipino communities in Canada.

As Filipino Canadians, Climate justice, as we are only recently discovering, seems to be the absolute that pulls our two stories (thus far) together.  And with typhoon Haiyan that has greatly affected the Philippines—it seems only fitting to go to the Philippines and learn about climate justice.

What’s that?

There’s an opportunity that fits that criteria exactly?

NO WAY.

Yes way.

Powershift Pilipinas will be our space to come together, learn, share, strategize, bond, celebrate, empower, and collectively build a unified movement that can rise to the urgency and scale of the climate crisis. 

Supporting this cause is a way to support a transformative new chapter in our stories and the stories of 800,000 other Filipino-Canadians in their steps toward fighting for climate justice.

With your support for this opportunity, we will have the chance to learn invaluable skills and knowledge to continue on in our journey to mount these challenges against climate change and dispossession, to develop lifelong connections for collective social change, and to return to Canada transformed and ready to create a revolution with other passionate Canadians.

Thank you for listening.


The Impact

Once we return from this transformative journey we will seek to make climate justice an issue understandable on a personal level among the nearly 800,000 other Filipino-Canadians. One way this goal can be achieved is via creative outlets that are universally understood: music, poetry, dance, stories etc.

Using leadership skills that we both already have, along with with new ones we will forge while participating in this astounding opportunity, will allow us to organize cultural events that will establish a platform for sharing stories from affected communities in the Philippines to Filipino-Canadian communities in Canada. These shared stories will aim to connect Filipino-Canadians, such as ourselves (Shaina and Sol) and 800,000 others, to communities on the frontlines of seeking climate justice.

About Shaina and Sol

Hey you. Yes you.

How are you? Kamusta na kayo? We are Sol and Shaina. We have a story to tell you.

I, Sol Diana, was born to a Filipino mother from the province of Cavite, Phillippines, and a white father whom I know next to nothing about. And this is precisely where my story begins. When I was three my father left the family. At the age of 4 my, then single, mother met her partner and both took on the role of raising me. I call both my mothers. Being raised by two women of color made me a witness to the myriad of struggles they faced: homophobia, racism, sexism etc. and I was therefore brought up with the notion of analyzing the problems that exist in a colonial, racist and sexist society and, without second thought, standing with the people who seek to challenge this particular system.

My case is interesting however, because I look white. Everyday I realize more and more how Canadian society is systematically designed to benefit people who look just like me. I thereby learned young the significance of dissecting my privilege as a seemingly white, straight male. As a person seeking to dissect the cultural privileges that come with being a settler on stolen land—one outlet that I can get involved in is climate justice.

I, Shaina, am a second-generation Montrealer-Torontonian-Pinay-Canadian queer anti-colonial, anti-racist femme-inist. I'm also part-time head-scratcher, part-time songstress, and full-time culinary visionary (a nice way to say that I think about food all the time). My mother was raised by Candelaria, Quezon rice-fields, and my father, brought up around the earth, winds, fires, and waters of Roxas, Mindoro. As a child of the diaspora, my body, mind, and spirit have always felt that the waves of migration that eventually brought my parents to Canada were fueled by ineffable losses. As I've grown into consciousness over the past 22 years of life, I have been lent the vocabulary to understand and articulate the connections between the my family's migration, colonialism, neo-colonialism, land dispossession, cultural amnesia, and the socio-political conditions that create climate change.

We are pretty overcome with a sense of emotional, spiritual and political revival, inspiration, and revolution since receiving word of the opportunity to partake in this transformative journey to be part of an incredibly timely and important conversation in the Philippines about climate change.

For me, Sol, the process of dissecting my privilege, and the encouragement and reinforcement by my family and community to do so, naturally lead to an interest in indigenous struggles. It was not until high school that I began to identify myself as a settler on stolen land, but since then, I remember and acknowledge that everything I do is on unceded Coast Salish Territory— and that since I am a settler I thereby perpetuate the colonial and violent regime that has displaced and subjugated indigenous populations for centuries. One of the main issues that come with indigenous struggle in Canada is climate justice, especially with the multiple proposed pipelines that threaten to further destroy and displace indigenous communities and land.

For me, Shaina, my experiences as a woman of color in various predominantly-white sustainability spaces (I go to McGill!) have heightened my acute awareness of the value of spaces that connect discussions about sustainability and climate change with discussions about race and colonialism. The opportunity to engage with Filipino-centered discussion about climate change would be invaluable for me to make my climate justice work stronger. I am passionate about uncovering and challenging the realities of climate change as they intersect with the personal narratives of the Filipinos whose lives are being so imminently impacted by land dispossession and a lack of autonomy over Filipino resources. Climate justice work in Canada, the Philippines, and elsewhere globally is necessitated by interlinking processes of neo-colonialism, land- dispossession, and natural resource privatization and commoditization. These processes in themselves and the climate change generated by them exacerbate and create more of the "push factor" conditions of "lack of opportunity" in the Philippines, despite its wealth of natural resources, that are causing the exodus from the Philippines that is making temporary foreign workers a proliferating reality.

While these processes we’ve both mentioned fundamentally impact everyone in ways beyond climate change, climate change is one enormous effect of these processes that has such stark, imminent, physical, devastating, catastrophic impacts, as Typhoon Haiyan exemplifies, that it is unforgivable not to name and tackle climate change as a culmination of these processes.

That being said, we are passionate about addressing climate change and its roots not only because we think it's unforgiveable to not do everything in our power to prevent another Typhoon Haiyan, but also because we’re passionate about challenging the conditions that dispossess Filipinos in a variety of harmful ways. Moreover, our statuses Filipino-Canadian on unceded Indigenous territory makes it our responsibility to learn and challenge the conditions that make climate change a process that dispossess and violates the autonomy of Indigenous communities in particular, in a way that is similar but certainly not commensurate to the way that climate change disproportionately impacts the countries in the global south such as the Philippines.

What We Need

We need to cover the following costs

  • Food and accommodation.
  • Registration fee for Powershift Pilipinas
  • Travel to, from and within the Philippines.

*If we surpass our goal, surplus funds will be used to offer this same opportunity to another Filipino Canadian and to support climate justice organizing efforts upon our return.


SONG CREDITS:

Joanna Delos Reyes
Sol Diana

http://www.halftimesharksuit.com

www.twitter.com/halftimesharksu
www.instagram.com/halftimesharksuit

Partnership Opportunities, Media, and Customer Support - please email:
halftimesharksuit@gmail.com


Wanna dance in your own halftime shark suit? Now you can.

Hey all, I'm sure we all saw that huge televised event where we fell in love with the our favorite dancing shark. Now, let's make that shark suit a reality while helping the environment at the same time (100% of profits to charity!)

PLEASE DIRECT ALL MESSAGES TO HALFTIMESHARKSUIT@GMAIL.COM


Here's what you can get!

Shark Suit Stickers - $5 each
3"x3" stickers with your favorite shark!


Shark Suit Cloth Template - $15 each
Get a cloth template so you can make your own shark suit! 



Shark Suit 

UPDATE: YOU ASKED. WE LISTENED. RELEASED MORE PREORDER SLOTS!!!

Pre-order your very own Shark Suit!
  • Early Bird at $69 each
  • Preorder Tier 1 at $89 each
  • Preorder Tier 2 at $99 each

  • Full Retail Price at $119 each 

    (Donate now to get yours faster and cheaper than everyone else!)

SIZING: Please specify in comments or email: Child - 4'8", Adult Short - 5'6", Adult Medium - 5'9", or Adult Tall - 6'1"

SHIPPING: USA included, Canada add $30, UK add $50. For other international, please contact directly before ordering. Dates are ESTIMATES and will change according to manufacturing needs.


Design/Manufacturing

Having worked in procurement, I'll perform the due diligence necessary to find us the best manufacturer that will provide the best value. This will ensure a quality suit for you and plenty of money raised for charity.

UPDATE: Good news: a professional fashion designer and an industrial design intern have joined the team and will be helping me in the design/manufacturing process as volunteers!

The Impact

It's no secret that our earth is suffering and our wildlife is in big trouble. Let's work together to do something about it!

  • I'm David Lam and I'm passionate about environmentalism
  • I went to Rutgers University for environmental engineering, founded an Engineers Without Borders Water Project in Kenya, and trained in sustainable design under renowned Permaculture instructor Andrew Faust

With your help, we will select an environmental nonprofit to benefit such as World Wildlife Fund or the Wildlife Conservation Society or a renewable energy nonprofit.

100% of the profits will be donated.


 




Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign!
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Please donate a small sum to reduce the production cost (anything helps!)

Thanks so much!

Much Love,
Dave


HalftimeSharkSuit.com
HALFTIMESHARKSUIT@GMAIL.COM


Thank You to the Interns:
Gabe DeGuzman, Henessa Gumiran, Krishna Patel, Mike Perez

Partners


Black Shell Media is a multimedia marketing studio
www.BlackShellMedia.com




Special Thanks To:
Klaus Riel - NYC Club Promoter - promoting the campaign pro bono

story:
Our family started Bee Heaven Farm in 1996 on a 5-acre slice of paradise 30 miles south of Miami in the Redland farming area just north of Homestead, Florida. By 2002 we were already certified organic when we started the first multi-farm Community Supported Agriculture program serving Miami-Dade, Broward and Monroe counties, growing and delivering weekly veggies and selling at local markets and events. Over the years, we’ve mentored WWOOFers, apprentices and interns. Several  have since started their own successful farms. Always, at the forefront of all our endeavors, our focus and motivation has been promoting daily FLOSSing—growing and eating FRESH * LOCAL * ORGANIC * SEASONAL * and * SUSTAINABLE food.


Over the years, we’ve had the privilege and pleasure of seeing others follow our example. Whether for backyard gardeners, urban farmers, or big commercial growers, we’ve raised awareness of the great diversity of crops that can be grown in our tropical area. We’ve shown how you can do this without using chemical pesticides, herbicides, and synthetic fertilizers, and we’ve awakened the lust for heirloom varieties of tomatoes, beans and other vegetables that are full of flavor.


But one thing was lacking—access to organic seedlings and transplants! Sure, you could order them shipped in, at a HUGE cost and risk of damage in transit. Or, you could buy seed packets that always seem to have WAAAY more seeds than you needed, or get starts at your local big box garden store. But those are full of chemicals, and most often are not varieties best suited for our neck of the woods.


We've always grown more transplants than we needed—especially the heirloom tomato varieties with fanciful names and mouth-watering descriptions that we just couldn’t resist trying out, so we started selling the extras. Demand grew, and soon we found ourselves bringing our seedlings to festivals, where we’d quickly sell out.


 


Our little home-made shade house has served us well, but after 10 years, we’ve outgrown the space. In order to be able to grow the quantity, diversity, and quality of plants that our customers want, we have to take it up a notch or two.

So, we’re reaching out to you, our loyal customers, partners and friends, to help us take this next evolutionary step in our growing operation—putting in a greenhouse!

We're excited that the greenhouse will allow us to grow seedlings in controlled conditions so they're vibrant and healthy.  It will also allow us to do protected growing and season extension - letting us start crops earlier before the rainy season is over, and later into the start of summer. And perhaps most exciting, we'll be open to the public!


Our initial goal:  $42,200


  • $29,000  Build 60'x90' greenhouse (two gutter-connected,  30' bays, benches, tie-downs, doors, roll-up sides, concrete workpad, basic irrigation setup)

  • $ 1,200  Land preparation (tree removal, chipping, stump grinding, ground leveling)

  • $ 12,000  Build 60'x12' heavy-duty pole shed to house equipment, potting mix, supplies and irrigation controls (and future home for roof-mounted solar panels)


Our final goal:  $55,000


After our initial goal is exceeded, additional funds will go towards installing a solar energy system to power greenhouse operations (irrigation, lighting, cooling, etc) freeing us from reliance on the electric grid

  • $11,000 Solar energy system (solar panels, controllers, batteries,pump, etc)

  • $ 1,800  Tie-in to existing or new irrigation well (pipe, trenching, hookup)


Please help us out. In return, we'll reward you with great perks like free seedlings, discounts, bumper stickers, T-shirts, farm bags and pens. You can help fund a school garden or receive a biweekly CSA share this upcoming season. The more you give, the more you get!


If we don't meet our goal...we'll push on, and begin operations with the basic greenhouse, but we'll need to raise prices to help us defray the costs of this project. We don't want to do that-we want to keep our seedlings affordable for all!



 Bee Heaven Farm is the first USDA certified organic seedling producer in the Southeast Florida area. We do not use any synthetic pesticides, herbicides, or fertilizers—we use only inputs approved for use in organic production. Do you have chemical sensitivities? You can be comfortable with our seedlings! Concerned about the impact of pesticide and herbicide use on the environment and our groundwater? No worries, we don’t do that!


 Want seedlings for garden installations? School gardens? Chef gardens? Row cropping? Permaculture installations? With our new facility, we can take on custom orders, big or small.



 We're undertaking this project with confidence that YOU, our loyal supporters, will stand behind us once again. Back in 2006 we had a successful fundraising campaign to help us upgrade our chicken tractors to state-of-the-art aluminum units. It helped reduce predator attacks and we no longer had to build new wooden ones every couple of years, only to watch them rot in our humidity. The chicken tractors are our workhorses, still in use today, safely housing happy hens that lay eggs for our CSA members in the winter and everyone in the summer.


 The biggest risk we face is, by far, the threat of hurricanes. How can we minimize the risk? Before a hurricane strikes, we'll remove/roll up the plastic covering from the greenhouse, allowing storm winds to move more freely through the structure. It may still suffer damage, but the plastic won't be there to act as a sail and carry the whole structure away. Insurance? If we DO find a company that will underwrite it, it'll be way beyond our budget. However, with proper precautions, damages should be fairly easy to repair.


 If we don't raise enough funds to pay for the solar-powered irrigation system and the modifications needed to hook it up to our existing irrigation well, we'll have to run it off our house electricity and house well, or install a separate FPL meter, which will also be costly.



 Even if you can't contribute $$, you can still help!

  • Spread the word about this greenhouse building campaign to friends and colleagues who may like to support our cause.

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools shown at top of the page to pass along this campaign. Click on the Facebook, Google Plus or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks.


 We're looking forward to a successful campaign!

By 2002 we were already certified organic when we started the first multi-farm Community Supported Agriculture program serving Miami-Dade, Broward and Monroe counties, growing and delivering weekly veggies and selling at local markets and events. Over the years, we’ve mentored WWOOFers, apprentices and interns. Several  have since started their own successful farms. No worries, we don’t do that!  Want seedlings for garden installations? School gardens? Chef gardens? Row cropping? Permaculture installations? With our new facility, we can take on custom orders, big or small.  We're undertaking this project with confidence that YOU, our loyal supporters, will stand behind us once again. Back in 2006 we had a successful fundraising campaign to help us upgrade our chicken tractors to state-of-the-art aluminum units. However, with proper precautions, damages should be fairly easy to repair.  If we don't raise enough funds to pay for the solar-powered irrigation system and the modifications needed to hook it up to our existing irrigation well, we'll have to run it off our house electricity and house well, or install a separate FPL meter, which will also be costly.  Even if you can't contribute $$, you can still help!
Spread the word about this greenhouse building campaign to friends and colleagues who may like to support our cause.

story:
Summary

Hi everyone, my name is Guilherme. I'm from Brazil.
I'm doing a project called World Coast Journey for the Preservation of the Seas. The idea of the project is to make the entire coast of the World by bike and sailboat to speak to as many people I can to aware them about the problem of the garbage, trash and mainly about the plastic problem in the beaches and in the Oceans.

  • Did you know that every year 1 million see birds and 100 mille marine mammals die because of debris?
      

  • Did you know that we have islands of plastic in the middle of the Ocean? The biggest one is in the north of Pacific Ocean, the size is compared with the state of Texas in the USA.

       


  • Did you know that the turttles eat the plastic bag thinking they are medusa?And than died because that.

                 

  • Did you know that the plastic in the ocean become microplastic that the fishes eat and than we eat the fishes stay bad and don't know why?

Let's do something to solve these problems.

Help me to continue this journey trying to concius as many people I can around the world.

World Coast Journey 

The project will aware the people around the World cycling and sailing the World Coast for the Preservation of the Seas. The journey is split in 8 parts around the globe.

  1. Mediterranean Sea = 15.000 km and 10 countries
  2. Europe = 15.500 km and 14 countries
  3. South America = 25.500 km and 8 countries
  4. Central America=12.000 km and 13 countries
  5. Australia (still under construction)
  6. Africa (still under construction)
  7. Asia (still under construction)
  8. North America (still under construction)

With Europe, Mediterranean, South and Central America the journey already have almost 70.000 km crossing 52 countries.

By now I'm doing the Mediterranean Coast, I already cycled more than 10 thousand kilometers in 5 months, speaking with more than 1.700 people about the project and these problems. During this time I cycled around the coast of Italy including Sardinia and Sicily, also Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia, Montenegro, Albania, Greece and now I'm going to Turkey. The idea was to make Siria, Libano, Israel following the North Africa doing the entire round of the Mediterranean Sea. But by now is not the moment to make it. It's dangerous and I decide to change this part going to Istanbul and make the coast of Turkey taking a boat back to Genova - Italy finishing this part of the journey in the Strait of Gibraltar crossing the coast of France and Spain completing 10 countries and approximatelly 15 thousand kilometers. When I complete this part I'm going to Gran Canarie to work in a sailboat to learn how to sail crossing the Atlantic Ocean to Santa Lucia - Venezuela. Then I will stop for a while to make a documentary of the Mediterranean Coast and maybe write a book.



Also I will take the time to prepare and decide the next part of the project that will be South or Central America.

The Impact

Marine debris impacts the environment, economy, and human health and safety. The extent of the impacts is determined by the type of marine debris and where it settles in the ocean (e.g., submerged, floating, or within a sensitive habitat). Fishing nets, plastic bags, and tires can sink to the ocean floor and break and smother coral reefs. Fishing line can float along the ocean surface and catch vessel propellers causing costly damage. A syringe can wash up on the beach and be stepped on by a beachgoer resulting in a wound and possibly an infection. Regardless of the type or the location of the marine debris, it can have serious impacts.

It is now believed that there are 5.25 trillion pieces of plastic debris in the ocean. Of that mass, 269,000 tons float on the surface, while some four billion plastic microfibers per square kilometer litter the deep sea. (1)

Hundreds of thousands of sea turtles, whales, and other marine mammals, and more than 1 million seabirds die each year from ocean pollution and ingestion or entanglement in marine debris. Marine debris is manmade waste that is directly or indirectly disposed of in oceans, rivers, and other waterways.


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  1. Reduce, Reuse and Recycle the waste

  2. Be a Sponsor or Partner of this journey

  3. Like us on our Facebook page and Instagram

  4. Follow us on Twiter

  5. You can help simply by spreading the message using Facebook using the hashtag #WorldCoastJourney and aware the greatest number of people about it.

  6. See 10 Things You Can Do to Save the Ocean from the National Geographic site

  7. Spread the Preservation of the Seas

  8. Raise aware greatest number of people you can

Access our Website here.
