Access our Website here.

story:
Il testo in Italiano é sotto
 Text in English below

Español

Mi nombre es Davide, soy Italiano (aunque dentro de pocos meses tendré la doble nacionalidad) y vivo en República Dominicana desde julio 2004. He trabajado en diferentes instituciones, en las áreas de Derechos Humanos, Desarrollo, Educación, pero ahora llegó el momento en que quiero poner mi propia actividad, coherente-mente con los Derechos Humanos, que pueda ser Educativa y que aporte al Desarrollo.
Compré una tierra, con mi esposa, en las lomas al norte de la ciudad de Santiago de los Caballeros donde vimos con nuestro hijo, a 15 minutos de casa. En esta tierra quiero sembrar cacao y aguacates (el cacao necesita ser intercalado por plantas más grandes que le ofrezcan un poco de sombra). Quiero que sea orgánico, porque hay que cuidar la salud de los consumidores y el mundo en que vivimos. Quiero que sea cerca de la ciudad, porque la gente tiene que tener la posibilidad de visitar el proyecto y acercarse a las producciones orgánicas, entender porqué son mejores para la salud y para el medio-ambiente. Quiero que sea un proyecto donde no se explote la mano de obra de nadie, donde los trabajadores sean justamente remunerados y el objetivo sea la sostenibilidad económica y no la rentabilidad a toda costa.
Con los fondos recaudado voy a sustituir la vegetación presente con un bosque de cacao y aguacate y crearé la infraestructura para poder dar seguimiento en los tres años que aproximadamente hacen falta antes de cosechar los primeros frutos.
En total dispongo de 30 tareas, aproximadamente 18.000 metros cuadrados, empezaré a trabajar y llegaré hasta donde los fondos me permitan. Primero necesito limpiar el terreno, después sembrar las plantas de cacao y las plantas para la sombra. Finalmente hay que dar mantenimiento a todo por tres años, hasta que la primera cosecha pueda empezar a  dar sostenibilidad al proyecto. Si ustedes me ayudarán a lograr mi sueño con más de US$ 30.000 trataré de ampliar mi proyecto a terrenos sin cultivos que se encuentran colindantes, si no llegaremos al monto empezaré primero con una parte del terreno.
Paralelamente voy a desarrollar la producción de abono orgánico, todo el material que se producirá con la limpieza del terreno será transformado en abono para las mismas plantas, la tierra nos da todo lo necesario, no hace falta envenenarla con productos químicos.
Ya cuento con algunos equipos, con la asesoría del ministerio de Agricultura, con los contactos de los exportadores, lo que me falta es tu ayuda para empezar a sembrar. 
¡Colabora con mi sueño!
Necesitamos que se entienda la importancia de las producciones orgánicas, que la gente entienda que pueden estar cerca de los hogares donde vivimos, necesitamos tener la posibilidad de un lugar donde se produzca y se disfrute de la producción sana, cerca de las casas de las personas, para poder ofrecer al mundo un producto de calidad, desarrollando en un ambiente social consciente libre de explotación (de la tierra o de las personas) que hace de la producción algo sostenible.

    Quisiera una finca donde se pueda producir, pero también donde cualquiera pueda subir a visitar lo que significa cultivar de forma orgánica, respetuosa del medio ambiente y de la salud de los consumidores. Un espacio educativo para las niñas y los niños y relajante para los adultos.

    ¿Cómo ayudar?

    Ahora necesito arrancar, sembrar las matas y darle mantenimiento, después, en aproximadamente tres años, voy a empezar a cosechar, a hacer sostenible la finca y se podrá abrir a los visitantes y a todas las actividades colaterales que surgirán, producción de chocolate y cualquier otra cosa podremos lograr!
    Me puedes ayudar con una donación o compartiendo esta campaña con tus contactos, siempre hay un amigo interesado en apoyar una iniciativa como esta.

    Italiano

    Il mio nome è Davide, sono italiano (anche se tra pochi mesi avrò doppia nazionalitá) e vivo in Repubblica Dominicana da luglio 2004. Ho lavorato in diverse istituzioni, con diritti umani, sviluppo, istruzione, educazione, ma ora è venuto il momento in cui voglio mettere su una attivitá mia, che sia coerente con il rispetto dei diritti umani, e che possa essere educativa e contribuire allo sviluppo.

    Ho comprato un terreno sulle colline a nord della città di Santiago de los Caballeros, dove vivo, a 15 minuti da casa mia. In questa terra voglio piantare cacao e avocado (il cacao deve essere intervallati da piante più grandi che offrono ombra). Voglio che la coltivazione sia organica, perché si deve tutelare la salute dei consumatori e del mondo in cui viviamo. Voglio essere vicino alla città, perché le persone devono essere in grado di visitare il progetto e l'approccio alla produzione biologica, affinché capiscano i vantaggi per la salute e per l'ambiente. Vorrei un progetto in cui i lavoratori siano pagati in maniera giusta, in maniera sostenibilie, senza abusi.

    Con i fondi raccolti sostituiró la vegetazione attuale con alberi di cacao e avocado e creeró la struttura necessaria per gestire la piccola piantagione, soprattutto nei tre anni che serviranno prima di vedere i primi frutti.

    In totale ho circa 18.000 metri quadrati di terra, che inizieró a preparare con i fondi raccolti, fino a dove i fondi mi permetteranno. Per prima cosa ho bisogno di sgombrare il terreno e poi devo piantare il cacao e le piante per l'ombra. Ultimo passo devo mantenere per tre anni tutto in ordine fino ai primi frutti che daranno sostenibilitá al progetto. Se con il vostro aiuto otterró piú dei 30.000 dollari che sto cercando di raccogliere, cercheró di ampliare la produzione ai terreni incolti vicini, se otterró meno, inizieró con una parte.

    Contemporaneamente inizieró a produrre fertilizzante organico, con le piante che sono in questo momento nel terreno,  la terra ci dà tutto il necessario, non c'è bisogno di avvelenare con sostanze chimiche

    Ho già alcune attrezzature, la consulenza del Ministero delle Politiche Agricole, contatti con esportatori, quello che mi serve è il vostro aiuto per iniziare la semina.

    Collabora con il mio sogno!

    Abbiamo bisogno che si capisca l'importanza della produzione biologica, che la gente capisca che si puó produrre a Km 0, abbiamo bisogno di luoghi vicino a casa dove apprezzare la bellezza della produzione sostenibile.

    Vorrei una azienda agricola dove si può produrre, ma anche il luogo dove chiunque può visitare e vedere cosa significa produrre in modo organico, rispettoso dell'ambiente e della salute dei consumatori. Uno spazio educativo per bambini e ragazzi e di relax per gli adulti.

    Come aiutare?

    Ora ho bisogno di avviare, far crescere le piante e mantene il terreno fino alle prime produzioni, poi tra circa tre anni, cominceró a raccogliere, per rendere sostenibile il progetto e potró avviare tutte le attività collaterali che saranno possibili, visite, produzione di cioccolato e di qualsiasi altrimenti possiamo ottenere!

    Mi puoi aiutare con una donazione o condividendo questa campagna con i tuoi contatti, c'è sempre un amico interessato a sostenere una iniziativa come questa.

    English

    My name is Davide, I'm Italian (although in a few months I will have dual nationality) and live in Dominican Republic from July 2004. I have worked in different institutions, human rights, development, education, but now I want to start an own activity, respecting human rights, and that it can be educational and contribute to the development.

    I bought some land in the northern hills of Santiago de los Caballeros, where I live, 15 minutes away from my house. In this land I want to plant cocoa and avocado (the cocoa must be interspersed with larger plants that provide shade). I want them to grow organically, because we have to protect the health of consumers and the world we live in. I want to be close to the city, because people should be able to visit the project and approach organic production, to understand the benefits to health and the environment. I would like a project in which workers are paid in the right way, sustainable without abuse.

    With the funds raised I will replace the existing vegetation with cocoa and avocado trees and I will create the necessary structure to manage the small plantation, especially in the three years before I will see the first fruits.

    In total I have about 18,000 square meters of land, that I will start to prepare with the funds raised, up to where the funds will allow me. First I need to clear the ground and then I have to plant cocoa and plants for shade. Last step I have to keep everything in order for three years until the first fruits that give sustainability to the project. If I will get more of the $ 30,000 that I'm trying to raise, I will try to expand production to fallow land nearby, if I will get less, I will start with one part.

    At the same time I will start to produce organic fertilizer, with plants that are at this time in the soil, the earth gives us everything you need, there is no need to poison with chemicals the land.

    I already have some equipment, the advice of the Ministry of Agriculture, contacts with exporters, what I need is your help to start planting.

    Cooperate with my dream!

    We need people to understand the importance of organic production, to understand that you can produce near the city, we need places accessible  where you can enjoy the beauty of sustainable production.

    I would like a farm where you can produce, but also a place where anyone can visit and see what it means to produce organically, environmental and consumer healthy. An educational space for children and relax for adults.

    How to help? 

    Now I need to start, grow plants and maintain the ground until the early productions, then in about three years, I will begin to gather, to make the project sustainable, and I will be able to start all the others activities that will be possible, visits, chocolate production and whatever else we can get!

    You can help me with a donation or sharing this campaign with your contacts, there is always a friend interested in supporting an initiative such as this.
story_txt:
Il testo in Italiano é sotto Text in English belowEspañol
Mi nombre es Davide, soy Italiano (aunque dentro de pocos meses tendré la doble nacionalidad) y vivo en República Dominicana desde julio 2004. He trabajado en diferentes instituciones, en las áreas de Derechos Humanos, Desarrollo, Educación, pero ahora llegó el momento en que quiero poner mi propia actividad, coherente-mente con los Derechos Humanos, que pueda ser Educativa y que aporte al Desarrollo.Compré una tierra, con mi esposa, en las lomas al norte de la ciudad de Santiago de los Caballeros donde vimos con nuestro hijo, a 15 minutos de casa. En esta tierra quiero sembrar cacao y aguacates (el cacao necesita ser intercalado por plantas más grandes que le ofrezcan un poco de sombra). Quiero que sea orgánico, porque hay que cuidar la salud de los consumidores y el mundo en que vivimos. Quiero que sea cerca de la ciudad, porque la gente tiene que tener la posibilidad de visitar el proyecto y acercarse a las producciones orgánicas, entender porqué son mejores para la salud y para el medio-ambiente. Quiero que sea un proyecto donde no se explote la mano de obra de nadie, donde los trabajadores sean justamente remunerados y el objetivo sea la sostenibilidad económica y no la rentabilidad a toda costa.Con los fondos recaudado voy a sustituir la vegetación presente con un bosque de cacao y aguacate y crearé la infraestructura para poder dar seguimiento en los tres años que aproximadamente hacen falta antes de cosechar los primeros frutos.En total dispongo de 30 tareas, aproximadamente 18.000 metros cuadrados, empezaré a trabajar y llegaré hasta donde los fondos me permitan. Primero necesito limpiar el terreno, después sembrar las plantas de cacao y las plantas para la sombra. Finalmente hay que dar mantenimiento a todo por tres años, hasta que la primera cosecha pueda empezar a  dar sostenibilidad al proyecto. Si ustedes me ayudarán a lograr mi sueño con más de US$ 30.000 trataré de ampliar mi proyecto a terrenos sin cultivos que se encuentran colindantes, si no llegaremos al monto empezaré primero con una parte del terreno.Paralelamente voy a desarrollar la producción de abono orgánico, todo el material que se producirá con la limpieza del terreno será transformado en abono para las mismas plantas, la tierra nos da todo lo necesario, no hace falta envenenarla con productos químicos.Ya cuento con algunos equipos, con la asesoría del ministerio de Agricultura, con los contactos de los exportadores, lo que me falta es tu ayuda para empezar a sembrar. ¡Colabora con mi sueño!Necesitamos que se entienda la importancia de las producciones orgánicas, que la gente entienda que pueden estar cerca de los hogares donde vivimos, necesitamos tener la posibilidad de un lugar donde se produzca y se disfrute de la producción sana, cerca de las casas de las personas, para poder ofrecer al mundo un producto de calidad, desarrollando en un ambiente social consciente libre de explotación (de la tierra o de las personas) que hace de la producción algo sostenible.

Quisiera una finca donde se pueda producir, pero también donde cualquiera pueda subir a visitar lo que significa cultivar de forma orgánica, respetuosa del medio ambiente y de la salud de los consumidores. Un espacio educativo para las niñas y los niños y relajante para los adultos.   ¿Cómo ayudar?
Ahora necesito arrancar, sembrar las matas y darle mantenimiento, después, en aproximadamente tres años, voy a empezar a cosechar, a hacer sostenible la finca y se podrá abrir a los visitantes y a todas las actividades colaterales que surgirán, producción de chocolate y cualquier otra cosa podremos lograr!Me puedes ayudar con una donación o compartiendo esta campaña con tus contactos, siempre hay un amigo interesado en apoyar una iniciativa como esta.Italiano
Il mio nome è Davide, sono italiano (anche se tra pochi mesi avrò doppia nazionalitá) e vivo in Repubblica Dominicana da luglio 2004. Ho lavorato in diverse istituzioni, con diritti umani, sviluppo, istruzione, educazione, ma ora è venuto il momento in cui voglio mettere su una attivitá mia, che sia coerente con il rispetto dei diritti umani, e che possa essere educativa e contribuire allo sviluppo.
Ho comprato un terreno sulle colline a nord della città di Santiago de los Caballeros, dove vivo, a 15 minuti da casa mia. In questa terra voglio piantare cacao e avocado (il cacao deve essere intervallati da piante più grandi che offrono ombra). Voglio che la coltivazione sia organica, perché si deve tutelare la salute dei consumatori e del mondo in cui viviamo. Voglio essere vicino alla città, perché le persone devono essere in grado di visitare il progetto e l'approccio alla produzione biologica, affinché capiscano i vantaggi per la salute e per l'ambiente. Vorrei un progetto in cui i lavoratori siano pagati in maniera giusta, in maniera sostenibilie, senza abusi.
Con i fondi raccolti sostituiró la vegetazione attuale con alberi di cacao e avocado e creeró la struttura necessaria per gestire la piccola piantagione, soprattutto nei tre anni che serviranno prima di vedere i primi frutti.
In totale ho circa 18.000 metri quadrati di terra, che inizieró a preparare con i fondi raccolti, fino a dove i fondi mi permetteranno. Per prima cosa ho bisogno di sgombrare il terreno e poi devo piantare il cacao e le piante per l'ombra. Ultimo passo devo mantenere per tre anni tutto in ordine fino ai primi frutti che daranno sostenibilitá al progetto. Se con il vostro aiuto otterró piú dei 30.000 dollari che sto cercando di raccogliere, cercheró di ampliare la produzione ai terreni incolti vicini, se otterró meno, inizieró con una parte.
Contemporaneamente inizieró a produrre fertilizzante organico, con le piante che sono in questo momento nel terreno,  la terra ci dà tutto il necessario, non c'è bisogno di avvelenare con sostanze chimiche
Ho già alcune attrezzature, la consulenza del Ministero delle Politiche Agricole, contatti con esportatori, quello che mi serve è il vostro aiuto per iniziare la semina.

Collabora con il mio sogno!
Abbiamo bisogno che si capisca l'importanza della produzione biologica, che la gente capisca che si puó produrre a Km 0, abbiamo bisogno di luoghi vicino a casa dove apprezzare la bellezza della produzione sostenibile.
Vorrei una azienda agricola dove si può produrre, ma anche il luogo dove chiunque può visitare e vedere cosa significa produrre in modo organico, rispettoso dell'ambiente e della salute dei consumatori. Uno spazio educativo per bambini e ragazzi e di relax per gli adulti.

Come aiutare?
Ora ho bisogno di avviare, far crescere le piante e mantene il terreno fino alle prime produzioni, poi tra circa tre anni, cominceró a raccogliere, per rendere sostenibile il progetto e potró avviare tutte le attività collaterali che saranno possibili, visite, produzione di cioccolato e di qualsiasi altrimenti possiamo ottenere!
Mi puoi aiutare con una donazione o condividendo questa campagna con i tuoi contatti, c'è sempre un amico interessato a sostenere una iniziativa come questa.
English

My name is Davide, I'm Italian (although in a few months I will have dual nationality) and live in Dominican Republic from July 2004. I have worked in different institutions, human rights, development, education, but now I want to start an own activity, respecting human rights, and that it can be educational and contribute to the development.
I bought some land in the northern hills of Santiago de los Caballeros, where I live, 15 minutes away from my house. In this land I want to plant cocoa and avocado (the cocoa must be interspersed with larger plants that provide shade). I want them to grow organically, because we have to protect the health of consumers and the world we live in. I want to be close to the city, because people should be able to visit the project and approach organic production, to understand the benefits to health and the environment. I would like a project in which workers are paid in the right way, sustainable without abuse.
With the funds raised I will replace the existing vegetation with cocoa and avocado trees and I will create the necessary structure to manage the small plantation, especially in the three years before I will see the first fruits.
In total I have about 18,000 square meters of land, that I will start to prepare with the funds raised, up to where the funds will allow me. First I need to clear the ground and then I have to plant cocoa and plants for shade. Last step I have to keep everything in order for three years until the first fruits that give sustainability to the project. If I will get more of the $ 30,000 that I'm trying to raise, I will try to expand production to fallow land nearby, if I will get less, I will start with one part.
At the same time I will start to produce organic fertilizer, with plants that are at this time in the soil, the earth gives us everything you need, there is no need to poison with chemicals the land.
I already have some equipment, the advice of the Ministry of Agriculture, contacts with exporters, what I need is your help to start planting.


Cooperate with my dream!
We need people to understand the importance of organic production, to understand that you can produce near the city, we need places accessible  where you can enjoy the beauty of sustainable production.
I would like a farm where you can produce, but also a place where anyone can visit and see what it means to produce organically, environmental and consumer healthy. An educational space for children and relax for adults.

How to help? 
Now I need to start, grow plants and maintain the ground until the early productions, then in about three years, I will begin to gather, to make the project sustainable, and I will be able to start all the others activities that will be possible, visits, chocolate production and whatever else we can get!
You can help me with a donation or sharing this campaign with your contacts, there is always a friend interested in supporting an initiative such as this.
campaign_city: Santiago de los Caballeros, Dominican Republic

story:
Inspiration in Antarctica for Change at Home

In March 2016, over 100 young business and community leaders from around the world will travel to Antarctica for two weeks as part of an annual expedition held by the 2041 Foundation and polar explorer Robert Swan. Expedition members will see first hand the impacts of climate change and human activity on the remote and surprisingly fragile Antarctic continent.

Expedition members commit to making their companies and communities more sustainable and resilient with initiatives ranging from increasing access to public transit in a hometown in India to helping Californians get by with less water. Only by building resilient, sustainable communities will we be able to protect the Antarctic wilderness and our quality of life at home.

With your help, our team of four colleagues from management consulting firm Bain & Company can join the expedition. Our normal days are spent helping clients solve their most challenging business problems by creating lasting change. For those two weeks, we will turn our full attention towards coaching the expedition members on how to translate their bold environmental and social ambitions into actionable, achievable plans with meaningful results. This type of coaching for corporate clients would typically cost many times more than the expedition fees needed to send our team on this expedition.

Our coaching and ongoing support will ensure that the expedition members are successful in the projects they pursue after returning home. We hope this will lead them to a lifetime of environmental advocacy and civic engagement. Your contribution will make this global impact possible.

Our team consists of four consultants from across North America. While we all work for the same company, we are making a personal commitment to this endeavor and are not sponsored by Bain.

  • Eitan Rovero, Mexico City, consultant to governments and retail companies; electronic engineer; passionate about photographing and sharing the wonders of our planet
  • Nikki Yurkoski, Dallas, consultant to technology and retail companies; former neuroscience student and researcher; passionate about traveling
  • Ann Alampi, Houston, consultant in the energy sector and for an international education non-profit; former geology researcher/student; committed to improving science education
  • Andrew Olesen, Washington DC, consultant to industrial and technology companies; former Navy nuclear engineer; passionate about wilderness

What We Need & What You Get

  • Expedition fees start at $11,000 each plus additional travel expenses.
  • We need your contribution to get us on the expedition. Your contribution will enhance the team's substantial personal investment of time and money.
  • Sponsors will be regularly updated on our progress and may be eligible for some exclusive perks.
  • After the expedition, we will remain in touch with other members and report back on the results achieved and our role in them.

The Impact

Your donation today will help over 100 young leaders create valuable change in their communities worldwide for decades to come. This expedition is a chance for these young leaders to commit to their ideas and make them real, with our team there to provide coaching and support.

Our team will be investing heavily in training and preparation with some of the world's leading experts on business coaching and change management. We have a track record of meaningful impact, both individually and as evidenced by the results of Bain & Company colleagues on prior expeditions.

  • Eitan was the director of a sustainable development oriented youth-movement in Mexico City and is currently involved in different science education and climate change awareness initiatives
  • Nikki previously worked at the Nashville Entrepreneur Center supporting start-ups across multiple industries; currently she is working with other Bain consultants and city leaders to develop and implement a "smart city sustainability plan" for Dallas, Texas
  • Ann co-founded and coached US Department of Energy science teams; at Bain, has supported efficiency improvements at a global energy company and now is building a volunteer recruiting strategy for an international service/education non-profit
  • Andrew helped save taxpayers millions of dollars while enhancing the Navy's ability to protect the environment from radiation; then came to Bain and helped a major industrial company rethink how they approach their supply chain.
  • After the 2014 expedition, Diego from Bain returned to help a global retailer reduce plastic and metal waste, saving them over $200M
  • On the 2013 expedition, the team developed plans for an Australian student who wanted to make her university 100% renewable, a Swedish environmental journalist who wanted to mobilize her audience to pursue their own environmental ambitions, and a UK utilities employee with grand energy efficiency ambitions for the whole country.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Any contribution, from $5 to $5,000, matters deeply to us
  • Please share our campaign with friends and co-workers
  • Post ideas using the comments section to suggest how we can enhance the impact of the expedition

Thank you for your support!

story:
Did you know there are more than 5 trillion pieces of plastic in the oceans?

Plastic pollution has emerged as one of the biggest threats to marine life and ocean health. A study published just this month estimates the 90% of sea birds have consumed plastic and 2050 every sea bird on earth will be consuming it.

Who am I?

My name is Tegan Mortimer; I am a marine biologist and I will be sailing from Senegal to Brazil as a science crew member of eXXpedition Ascension. I will be conducting research on marine plastics and biodiversity in the equatorial South Atlantic.

Why Should you Support me?

Science is a hard sell, it always has been. Science doesn't provide a tangible "thing" you can hold on to after it all and it's very rarely profitable. The science and research I will be conducting on board eXXpedition however will be important. I am partnering with organisations like 5 Gyres, Indigo V Expeditions, and National Geographic and with researchers like Professor Jenna Jambeck from the University of Georgia. These are leaders in their fields who create real change in policy and legislation.

When you think of ocean plastic pollution you might think of the "Giant Pacific Garbage Patch" which is the center of the Pacific gyre where the currents meet and plastic gets "dumped". Plastic pollution is closer to home as well and it occurs in the coastal waters that we use to sail, swim, and fish. I have been studying trash in the Stellwagen Bank National Marine Sanctuary for the past two summer seasons. Over that time my team and I have observed over 600 pieces of trash. The skills I gain through the new (to me) research I'll be conducting in the South Atlantic can be brought home and applied to understanding the risks here.

Education is the key to reducing marine plastic pollution.

80% of plastic pollution comes from land based sources and in the US its the trash that "falls through the cracks". Its the plastic bag on the side walk that blows into a storm drain or the plastic bottle you put in the overflowing trashcan on the beach or the balloon you let float away. Educating children and adults is one of the key ways to reduce the amount of plastic waste that is produced and the amount that could make its way into our oceans. In my position as a whale watch educator I educate over 20,000 people every season about the oceans and its threats. If just 10% of that number stopped using plastic grocery bags just one week a year it would make a huge difference.

“People protect what they love” Jacques Yves Cousteau

eXXpedition will create an engaging and exciting narrative to talk about marine pollution, science, and the environment. Particularly aimed at children and young people it will inspire them to make a change and to rethink how we use plastics in our lives.


What I need and What You Get?

The money raised in this campaign will go to supporting my participation in this important research. It will pay for my right of passage on board our expedition vessel - Sea Dragon- as well as helping me to get to our departure point in Dakar, Senegal and home again from Recife, Brazil.

While I have set my target at $3,000 the total cost of the expedition is closer to $10,000. Any additional funds I raise will go to the create of educational materials and outreach activities after my return from Brazil.

Along the course of the expedition I will provide exclusive updates and photos to all of my supporters. In addition, I will make sure that you're kept up to date on all scientific news and activities so you can see the true outcomes of your support.

We have flooded the ocean with our plastic trash and now is the time to turn the tide.

What are the risks?

I have a proven track record of producing scientific and outreach results. I presented my research on the potential risk of marine plastics to whales at the Ecological Society of America’s Annual Meeting in Baltimore last month and will present further research at the Society of Marine Mammology Biannual Conference in San Francisco later this year.

In 2013 and 2014 I provided educational materials to support Dave Rearick’s solo circumnavigation on board Bodacious Dream. These eleven “Science Notes” covered topics ranging from weather patterns to bird migration and sea bird conservation to glaciers and culminated in an article about the legacy of “voyages of discovery”. They can be viewed here on the Bodacious Dream Expeditions website. I will be writing a further two articles for Bodacious Dream Expedition about my research and experiences on board eXXpedition Ascension and plan to partner with Dave again to provide education content for next year’s Atlantic Cup.

There are always risks associated with this sort of expedition. Every effort has been made in the planning stages to ensure we’re successful in our mission but there are always unexpected and unaccounted for circumstances.

Can't contribute but still want to make a difference?

Turning the tide of ocean plastics is something we can all make a positive impact on.

  • Carry a reusable water bottle, utensils, or shopping bag so you can refuse these items on a regular basis.
  • Buy locally or shop for items with minimal packaging so you can reduce plastic waste.
  • Find other uses for single use items so you can reuse your plastics.
  • Always make sure you clean and recycle your plastic waste.
  • Rethink how you use plastic and try to find non-plastic alternatives

Share the word! Tell you friends and family about how they can reduce plastic pollution in the ocean and about eXXpedition and my campaign.

Find out more about eXXpedition Ascension at eXXpedition.com and about my educational and research initiative Ocean Talk at oceantalk.org

Thank you,

Tegan Mortimer


"Thank you for helping to make my home cleaner and healthier"

"Thank you for helping to make my home cleaner and healthier"

story:
Sally battling Giant Japanese Knotweed. Look at the size of the things!

This is the seed-head of a single Giant Hogweed plant, it can shower 50,000 seeds into the surrounding area, each capable of producing a 3m high plant that kills everything around it.  It is creating an impenetrable jungle, in places, on the Bollin banks

We're BEACON (Bollin Environmental Action and Conservation) a scheme to control destructive invasive weeds which are proliferating like mad in the inaccessible parts of the 200 sq.km River Bollin Valley*, in Cheshire.  Money is needed to buy weed-killing chemicals, spray suits, goggles and spraying equipment, as shown above, and get them to where they're needed.

Your contribution will go direct to BEACON's bank account.

The project has a full-time Project Officer, Sally Potts (that's Sally, above and in the video). In the past, DEFRA (The Department of Environment, Farming and Rural Affairs)  has paid her to do this work - but this funding will dry-up next March, 2015. 

(The recession may be over but the Government cuts live on!)

Everyone else involved in BEACON is a volunteer.

We want to preserve the Bollin's natural environment for the thousands of local people who enjoy it; for strolling, dog-walking, children's recreation or simply enjoying a breath of fresh air in the natural world.

We’re making good progress, large tracts of the accessible paths around the river are relatively clear of the three main culprits. The less accessible stretches are still 'seed factories' for the invaders.  After years of work, it would be tragic to see these pervasive weeds regain control, disrupting the whole ecological balance. 

That's why we're asking all the people who use the Bollin and its surroundings to give us just a few pounds a year, say, £5 or £10. It will make a huge difference, reducing the amount of damage being done by rapidly-spreading infestations of Japanese Knotweed, Giant Hogweed and Himalayan Balsam.

This crowd-fund will be used for the sole purpose of tackling these highly destructive plants. 

Please contribute what you can afford to keep the Bollin Valley environment viable, or if you prefer, buy one of our 'perks'.

 For more info, check out our regular website. 

www.bollinnonnatives.co.uk

Thanks for your attention.  Please, please send us a small contribution (or a big one of you feel strongly about what we're trying to do!)  Just hit the 'Contribute now' button. You can debit your card in two  minutes.        >>>>>>>>>>>>

This is our first crowd-fund. Thanks to everyone who's  chipped-in.

With your help we'll kill lots of these huge, poisonous weeds and keep the Bollin  diverse and beautiful.

Thanks.   

Sally and the volunteer team.

*The Bollin river runs from the Macclesfield Forrest to the Ship Canal, near Warburton; though Macclesfield, Prestbury, Wilmslow, Styal, Ringway, Hale Barns, Hale, Ashley, Bowdon and Dunham. The catchment is 200 squ. km.

---------------------------------------------

The Enemies

Theses are the three giant plants threatening to competely overwhelm our beautiful river's ecosystem;

Giant Hogweed

Leaves the size of doormats! Stems like signposts. Toxic

Japanese Knotweed and Giant Japanese Knotweed.

Taking a stranglehold on the river banks

Himalayan Balsam  

Looks pretty but soon dominates every other plant within 4 metres.

Let's keep the Bollin a place fit for kingfishers, woodpeckers, sandmartins, salmon, trout, otters and our grandchildren to enjoy! Thanks.
story_txt:
Sally battling Giant Japanese Knotweed. Look at the size of the things!This is the seed-head of a single Giant Hogweed plant, it can shower 50,000 seeds into the surrounding area, each capable of producing a 3m high plant that kills everything around it.  It is creating an impenetrable jungle, in places, on the Bollin banksWe're BEACON
(Bollin Environmental Action and
Conservation) a scheme to
control destructive invasive weeds which are proliferating like mad in the inaccessible parts of the 200 sq.km River Bollin
Valley*, in Cheshire.  Money is needed to buy weed-killing
chemicals, spray suits, goggles and spraying equipment, as shown above, and get them to where they're needed.
Your contribution will go direct to BEACON's bank account.The project has a full-time Project Officer, Sally Potts (that's Sally, above and in the video). In the past, DEFRA (The Department of Environment, Farming and Rural Affairs)  has paid her to do this work - but this
funding will dry-up next March, 2015.  (The recession may be over but the Government cuts live on!) 
Everyone else involved in BEACON is a volunteer.

We want to preserve the Bollin's natural environment for
the thousands of local people who enjoy it; for strolling, dog-walking, children's recreation or simply enjoying a breath of fresh air in the natural world.
We’re making good progress, large tracts of the accessible paths around the river are relatively clear of the three main culprits. The less accessible stretches are still 'seed factories' for the invaders.  After years of work, it would be tragic to see these
pervasive weeds regain control, disrupting the whole ecological balance. 
That's why we're asking all the people who use the Bollin and its surroundings to give us just a
few pounds a year, say, £5 or £10. It will make a huge difference, reducing the amount of damage being done by
rapidly-spreading infestations of Japanese Knotweed, Giant Hogweed and Himalayan
Balsam.
This crowd-fund will be used for the sole
purpose of tackling these highly destructive plants.  Please contribute what you can afford to keep the Bollin Valley environment viable, or if you prefer, buy one of our 'perks'.  For more info, check out our regular website. www.bollinnonnatives.co.ukThanks for your attention.  Please, please send us a small contribution (or a big one of you feel strongly about what we're trying to do!)  Just hit the 'Contribute now' button. You can debit your card in two  minutes.        >>>>>>>>>>>>This is our first crowd-fund. Thanks to everyone who's  chipped-in. With your help we'll kill lots of these huge, poisonous weeds and keep the Bollin  diverse and beautiful.Thanks.   Sally and the volunteer team.*The Bollin river runs from the Macclesfield Forrest to the Ship Canal, near Warburton; though Macclesfield, Prestbury, Wilmslow, Styal, Ringway, Hale Barns, Hale, Ashley, Bowdon and Dunham. The catchment is 200 squ. km.---------------------------------------------The EnemiesTheses are the three giant plants threatening to competely overwhelm our beautiful river's ecosystem;Giant Hogweed Leaves the size of doormats! Stems like signposts. ToxicJapanese Knotweed and Giant Japanese Knotweed.Taking a stranglehold on the river banksHimalayan Balsam  Looks pretty but soon dominates every other plant within 4 metres.Let's keep the Bollin a place fit for kingfishers, woodpeckers, sandmartins, salmon, trout, otters and our grandchildren to enjoy! Thanks.

story:
Short Summary

The East African Marine Transect (EAMT) aims to action a globally important marine-based scientific expedition to explore the relationship between humanity, our marine environment, science, technology and how new knowledge is communicated and shared in an open-sourced manner. The key driver is imagery, and the power of film. 

www.marinetransect.org

Inspired by Caine Delacy TEDxSeaPoint presentation:  www.tedxseapoint.com (where ideas can change the world!)

Team Introductions:

SIX CORE EXPEDITION TEAM MEMBERS:

Mike Markovina: Mike has a Masters degree in Ichthyology and Fisheries Science. After working on leatherback turtle conservation and fisheries management projects for the Mayumba Marine Park in southern Gabon for the Wildlife Conservation Society, he and Linda began a two-year expedition using photography and film to illuminate the positive uses of marine resources they found across Africa, Asia and Europe (42 countries in 24 months). Passionate about the oceans, Mike currently works extensively in East Africa on illegal fisheries (Monitoring, Control and Surveillance), from the shores of Lake Victoria to the dynamited reefs of Tanzania. With years of diving experience the world over, and driven by a deep passion for the marine environment, Mike aims to live a life of respect, appreciation and continued exploration, sharing with the world ideas, innovation new technologies.

Justin Beswick: A high impact entrepreneur with a BSc in Biotechnology and honours in Financial Analysis & Portfolio Management.His primary passion is where the leverage points in a system can be found, so that he can intervene to bring about the greatest positive change. He also has an undying passion for entrepreneurship and enabling others – with the greater goal of facilitating the development of entrepreneurship, through culture and mindset changes. In this regard, Justin has successfully launched organizations/companies that demonstrate and facilitate these efforts and has been selected as a Brightest Young Mind and World Economic Forum Global Shaper.

Rhett Bennett: Having grown up at the coast, spending his childhood fishing, snorkelling, SCUBA diving and surfing, Rhett developed a passion for fish and the marine environment, which eventually led to a PhD in Ichthyology and Fisheries Science. Rhett has worked in a number of areas, including fishing hotspots, marine protected areas (MPAs) and estuaries, along South Africa’s coastline, focussing on fish movement patterns, the benefits  of MPAs, the ecological effects of fishing on fish communities, as well as the design of long-term monitoring programmes for assessing reef fish communities. 

Tanith Grant: Tanith grew up in the land-locked wildlife-rich areas of Zimbabwe, and had to go far afield on adventurous family holidays (aka “selection course”) in  order to visit the ocean. These holidays involved expeditions along the pristine Mozambican coastline, which left its vivid imprint of sights and smells and the ocean’s warm caress lingering for years to come. With these influences, Tanith was only interested in working towards environmental conservation and went on to complete a degree in Geography and Environmental Science. Not quite satisfied in that field, she continued with an MSc in Zoology, investigating leopard population and movement patterns in Zimbabwe. Tanith’s education, hobbies and  passion are well integrated and have resulted in a well-rounded background in GIS, 4x4ing, telemetry, navigation, SCUBA diving, travel, fishing, conservation, photography and soon-to-be sailing!

Linda Markovina: Linda is a passionate traveller and conservationist. She spent two years as the better-looking half of the Marine Resource Expedition, which travelled the globe filming and photographing people making a change in marine conservation. After successfully completing the expedition in 2010 she is now co-director of Moving Sushi along with Mike Markovina. Together, the two are dedicated to bringing about inspiration and change in marine and ocean conservation through science, film, photography and open-access information.  Linda is a freelance writer, environmental journalist and photographer who has been published in various magazines in South Africa and internationally, and currently blogs for The Africa Report and Getaway Magazine on marine conservation issues as well as being a TIES ecotourism ambassador.  

Caine Delacy: With a PhD in marine ecology, a dive master qualification and a healthy dose of adventure, Caine has been travelling the world working on coral and temperate reef ecosystems. He is interested in the patterns and processes influencing reef ecosystems at large scales – such as along entire continental margins. He is also interested in and has worked on many marine protected areas (MPAs) and considers these one of the key components for the future health of reef ecosystems. He has played a role in both the design and implementation of monitoring programs for MPAs across the world. Caine also recognises the importance of engaging the volunteer community to play an important role in science and conservation, and that volunteers can contribute to research surveying and data processing. When not underwater or taking photos, you will find Caine rock climbing, surfing, snowboarding or trying to get lost in the mountains

Campaign description:

The EAMT  is  a  cross‐border,  multifaceted  research  expedition, linking  science,  cutting  edge  technology  and  social  media to  create  awareness  and  provide meaningful,  useful  and accessible  data to inspire solutions,  strategies  and  positive  and  constructive  outcomes for  East  African  coral  reef  fishes. Using sterio-imagery,  for  four  months  EAMT  will dive  and  film from South  Africa to  Kenya to  provide  the FIRST  baseline  assessment of  the  fish  fauna  spanning  the  length  of  the  East  African  ecosystem. This expedition represents the first of its kind, and will influence greatly future research initiatives on coral reef systems worldwide. We leave on the 12th of November 2012.

YOU CAN TAKE THIS TO A GLOBAL AUDIENCE:

While it is important to conduct research within the scientific realm, the real value is in communicating the knowledge to a global audience. It is possible the the coral reefs of East Africa, the lifeline to millions of people, is dying, which will exacerbate social and food security issues in the region. Through the EAMT expedition we will be able to film and understand just how far down the line we are. But the only way to communicate this globally is through emotive, real documentaries and powerful images, this is where we need you help!

What We Need & What You Get

Our key focus is to raise the necessary funds to produce a hard hitting, yet inspiring documentary detailing the expedition process, our findings and discoveries. To do this we require:

  • US$ 40 000 to cover documentary post production expences. 
  • All funds raised through this campaign weather it is more or less than that asked for will go to the production of the documentary - it is criticle in desiminating the right message. 

By contributing to production of our documentary, we will in turn offer rewards that showcase the level of your support, may it be you joining the expedition, or, we will create a viral video clip dressed up in fish costumes on a busy Cape Town beach thanking you for your support. We are a dynamic team with an imagination, so we look forward to creating fun, personal, meaningful and authentic rewards. 

The Impact

Our first expedition where we drove a 4x4 from Cape Town to Japan and back to highlight the positive contributions of change makers really impacting marine conservation initiatives (Moving Sushi) has finally culminated in the post production of the documentary. The funding drive to make that happen prolonged the message getting to the world - your contribution in facilitating post production of EAMT expedition documentary will bring the message to the world immediately - to us this is invaluable. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us drive the expedition by blogging, tweeting, sharing our website, following the teams progress underwater and building a relationship with the expedition. We are driven to get out there and change the world - and we are interested for you to be part of that change. If you think of crazy, interesting and strategic ideas that we could adopt in creating awareness towards our message on a global scale, let us know, we are willing to take a challenge!!

story:
הינכם מוזמנים

לאירוע הציפה המוני להצלת ים המלח בהשתתפות הצלם ספנסר טוניק

במלאת שנה לצילום המפורסם חוזר ספנסר טוניק לישראל, לתמוך במאבק להצלת ים המלח.

האירוע יתקיים לקראת הזריחה, בלילה שבין 13.9-14.9
בחוף של מלון פרימה אואזיס בים המלח

במקום יערך הפנינג מוסיקה  ומעגלי דיונים בהם ייקחו חלק מאות פעילים סביבתיים וחברתיים.

הסעות מסודרות לאירוע ייצאו  בלילה של יום חמישי 13.9 מהחניון שליד רכבת מרכז בתל אביב  מהשעה 24:00 -01:00

הסעה מירושלים תצא מבנייני האומה בשעה 01:30

לרכישת כרטיסים להסעה

https://tixwise.co.il/he/deadsea

http://www.indiegogo.com/deadsea

עלות ההרשמה  להסעה הינה 100 ₪ והיא כוללת הסעה הלוך וחזור לים המלח

 

 תוכנית האירוע*

  • יציאת אוטובוסים מתחנת רכבת מרכז בתל אביב ומירושלים בחצות הלילה שבין חמישי לשישי.

  • 3:00 – הגעה לחוף אואזיס בים המלח.

  • 3:00 – 5:00  -אירוע מוזיקלי והופעות על החוף בהשתתפות הרכבים אתניים ומקוריים:ארי גורלי,

    ג'אם לבו וחברים : מוזיקת עולם: שמואל ליבוביץ', רוני אדר, מושום ויטורי, יוהנה רוטמולר,טלי בירנברג ודרור גולדשטיין, רבי סול  ברוס בורגר: יוצר מנגן ושר בזיקה לשיריו של רבי שלמה קרליבך, עם תבלינים ממוסיקת גז , רוק , מוסיקת עולם ומוסיקה אפריקאית.

    אודל נמרודי ועוד

  • ·      5:00 – 6:00 – טקס פתיחה, מעגלי שיחה על ים המלח ועתידו דברים מפי פעילים סביבתיים וחברתיים בין הדוברים: דפני ליף, חיים וסביבה, מגמה ירוקה, ידידי כדור הארץ

  • 6:00 – 7:00 – ספנסר טוניק יזמין את כולם להיכנס למים לציפה המונית

  • 7:00 – 8:00 –צילומים חופשיים

  • 08:00 – יציאת האוטובוסים חזרה לתל אביב (ולמקומות אחרים– בהתאם לביקוש)

  • בשעה 12:00 שיחה עם ספנסר טוניק ודפני ליף על צילום מחאה ומחויבות  חברתית (למוזמנים בלבד)

הינכם מוזמנים להביא כלי נגינה ומגבות!

*האירוע אינו בעירום

למידע נוסף: איריס טייטלבאום- deadseaevent@gmail.com

 טלפון לבירורים לגבי ההסעה: 052-5345960

 * התוכנית נתונה לשינויים

אירוח  במחיר מיוחד לסוף שבוע זה ניתן להזמין במלון פרימה אואזיס ים המלח  http://www.prima.co.il/save_dead_sea

חפשו אותנו גם  ב: http://www.facebook.com/events/476815572334048/

 

איך אפשר לעזור?

  1. לבוא!

    למימון הוצאות ההפקה, בעת ההרשמה נבקש מכל משתתף תרומה סמלית מינימאלית של 4 ש"ח (הרשמה בעמוד האירוע ב- Indiegogo).

    נודה לתמיכתכם ברמות תרומה גבוהות יותר, האירוע לא יוכל להתקיים ללא תמיכתכם!

  2. הזמינו חברים והפיצו את האירוע, גם בפייסבוק: https://www.facebook.com/events/476815572334048/

    גם אם לא תוכלו להגיע, נבקש את תמיכתכם בהפצת האירוע בקרב מעגלי החברים שלכם.

  3. תרומה לאירוע – על מנת לקיים את האירוע, אנו עובדים עליו בהתנדבות מזה חודשים ארוכים. יחד עם זאת, יש עלויות לקיום הציפה ההמונית, ולשם כך אנו מבקשים את תרומתכם לשם כיסוי העלויות הישירות של ההפקה.

למידע נוסף על ספנסר טוניק ומיצב הצילום בים המלח Naked Sea:

האתר של ספנסר טוניק: http://www.spencertunick.com/

אודות פרוייקט Naked Sea: www.nakedsea.info

וידאו על מיצב הצילום Naked Sea: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uA0vv5HlLtY

 

Spencer Tunick is returning to Israel. Please join him on September 14th at the Dead Sea. www.nakedsea.info 

We are using Indiegogo as a platform for getting the word out internationally and for organizing the local production. You need to contribute something (as low as $1) to attend the event. Bus Transportation from Tel Aviv is $35

It has been nearly 1 year since you helped Spencer Tunick achieve his historic art installation at the Dead Sea. Your participation resulted in many key accomplishments:

  • Spencer Tunick created some of his best work of art in Israel

  • The world media took notice and over 500 million people saw a new positive image of Israel and learnt about the environmental issues of the Dead Sea

  • Spencer gave amazing quotes to the press reinforcing his love for Israel, the Israeli people, and the environment

  • We succeeded in elevating the Dead Sea to the Final 10 list in the New 7 Wonders of the World Competition

  • The religious parties in Kneset led by Shas and Bayit Heyehudi failed in their attempt to suppress Freedom of Speech in Israel and to block our art installation

Unfortunately the battle is not yet over and the Dead Sea is still in danger. 

It is for these reasons that Spencer Tunick has decided to return to Israel and to the Dead Sea. He is partnering with the grassroots organization "Save Our Sea" www.saveoursea.org.il who is focused on the unique medical/healing properties of the Dead Sea that people from all over the world depend on.  Each year they hold an annual Dead Sea Float to raise international awareness.  This year they have decided to hold their event around the same time of the 1 year anniversary of our installation. Spencer is coming to Israel for this event and we would like you to join him !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 

Our proposed agenda is (which is still subject to change):

  • Buses leave Tel Aviv around 12am on Friday morning to arrive at the Dead Sea by 3am

  • From 3-5am we'll gather on the beach for a jam session with accoustic music (bring your guitars and drums to join in).  

  • From 5am – 6am we will have our opening ceremony along with enviromental activists who will share their opinions about the dead sea and its future 

  • From 6am – 7am Spencer Tunick will invite everyone into the water to float together

  • From 7am -9am \With Spencer's guidence, photographers will take pictures of the participants – both individually and collectively

  • 10am – The buses will return to Tel Aviv and elsewhere

  • Please note that this is not a nude event

To learn more about our work with Spencer Tunick & the Dead Sea visit:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uA0vv5HlLtY

https://www.facebook.com/events/476815572334048/

Some recent press about this can be seen at:

http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4262189,00.html 

http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-07-30/spencer-tunick-to-join-mass-floating-event-to-save-dead-sea

http://www.greenprophet.com/2012/08/spencer-tunick-naked-dead-sea/

Please help us by joining the float in body and/or spirit. We would like to bring thousands of people to the Dead Sea and need your active participation. Please help spread the word. This is not a nude event - we expect people to wear clothes - but clothing is optional. 

Sincerely,

Shlomit Yarkoni & Ari Fruchter: Naked Sea www.nakedsea.info

Jon Sekular: Save Our Sea www.saveoursea.org.il

 

P.S. You can also take a look at our Kickstarter campaign from last year which raised $116K and helped fund the project. The work by Shlomit and me is voluntary and all funds raised are used to pay for direct costs associated with production.  Spencer Tunick is an invited guest to Israel and is not involved nor responsible for the production of this event.

http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/nakedsea/naked-sea-spencer-tunick-dead-sea-installation 

http://www.spencertunick.com/
story_txt:
הינכם מוזמנים
לאירוע הציפה המוני להצלת ים המלח בהשתתפות הצלם ספנסר טוניק
במלאת שנה לצילום המפורסם חוזר ספנסר טוניק לישראל, לתמוך במאבק להצלת ים המלח.
האירוע יתקיים לקראת הזריחה, בלילה שבין 13.9-14.9בחוף של מלון פרימה אואזיס בים המלח
במקום יערך הפנינג מוסיקה  ומעגלי דיונים בהם ייקחו חלק מאות פעילים סביבתיים וחברתיים.
הסעות מסודרות לאירוע ייצאו  בלילה של יום חמישי 13.9 מהחניון שליד רכבת מרכז בתל אביב  מהשעה 24:00 -01:00
הסעה מירושלים תצא מבנייני האומה בשעה 01:30
לרכישת כרטיסים להסעה
https://tixwise.co.il/he/deadsea
http://www.indiegogo.com/deadsea
עלות ההרשמה  להסעה הינה 100 ₪ והיא כוללת הסעה הלוך וחזור לים המלח
 
 תוכנית האירוע*


יציאת אוטובוסים מתחנת רכבת מרכז בתל אביב ומירושלים בחצות הלילה שבין חמישי לשישי.


3:00 – הגעה לחוף אואזיס בים המלח.


3:00 – 5:00  -אירוע מוזיקלי והופעות על החוף בהשתתפות הרכבים אתניים ומקוריים:ארי גורלי,


ג'אם לבו וחברים : מוזיקת עולם: שמואל ליבוביץ', רוני אדר, מושום ויטורי, יוהנה רוטמולר,טלי בירנברג ודרור גולדשטיין, רבי סול  ברוס בורגר: יוצר מנגן ושר בזיקה לשיריו של רבי שלמה קרליבך, עם תבלינים ממוסיקת גז , רוק , מוסיקת עולם ומוסיקה אפריקאית.
אודל נמרודי ועוד



·      5:00 – 6:00 – טקס פתיחה, מעגלי שיחה על ים המלח ועתידו דברים מפי פעילים סביבתיים וחברתיים בין הדוברים: דפני ליף, חיים וסביבה, מגמה ירוקה, ידידי כדור הארץ



6:00 – 7:00 – ספנסר טוניק יזמין את כולם להיכנס למים לציפה המונית


7:00 – 8:00 –צילומים חופשיים


08:00 – יציאת האוטובוסים חזרה לתל אביב (ולמקומות אחרים– בהתאם לביקוש)


בשעה 12:00 שיחה עם ספנסר טוניק ודפני ליף על צילום מחאה ומחויבות  חברתית (למוזמנים בלבד)

הינכם מוזמנים להביא כלי נגינה ומגבות!

*האירוע אינו בעירום

למידע נוסף: איריס טייטלבאום- deadseaevent@gmail.com
 טלפון לבירורים לגבי ההסעה: 052-5345960
 * התוכנית נתונה לשינויים

אירוח  במחיר מיוחד לסוף שבוע זה ניתן להזמין במלון פרימה אואזיס ים המלח  http://www.prima.co.il/save_dead_sea

חפשו אותנו גם  ב: http://www.facebook.com/events/476815572334048/

 
איך אפשר לעזור?


לבוא!
למימון הוצאות ההפקה, בעת ההרשמה נבקש מכל משתתף תרומה סמלית מינימאלית של 4 ש"ח (הרשמה בעמוד האירוע ב- Indiegogo).
נודה לתמיכתכם ברמות תרומה גבוהות יותר, האירוע לא יוכל להתקיים ללא תמיכתכם!


הזמינו חברים והפיצו את האירוע, גם בפייסבוק: https://www.facebook.com/events/476815572334048/

גם אם לא תוכלו להגיע, נבקש את תמיכתכם בהפצת האירוע בקרב מעגלי החברים שלכם.


תרומה לאירוע – על מנת לקיים את האירוע, אנו עובדים עליו בהתנדבות מזה חודשים ארוכים. יחד עם זאת, יש עלויות לקיום הציפה ההמונית, ולשם כך אנו מבקשים את תרומתכם לשם כיסוי העלויות הישירות של ההפקה.


למידע נוסף על ספנסר טוניק ומיצב הצילום בים המלח Naked Sea:

האתר של ספנסר טוניק: http://www.spencertunick.com/

אודות פרוייקט Naked Sea: www.nakedsea.info

וידאו על מיצב הצילום Naked Sea: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uA0vv5HlLtY

 
Spencer Tunick is returning to Israel. Please join him on September 14th at the Dead Sea. www.nakedsea.info  
We are using Indiegogo as a platform for getting the word out internationally and for organizing the local production. You need to contribute something (as low as $1) to attend the event. Bus Transportation from Tel Aviv is $35
It has been nearly 1 year since you helped Spencer Tunick achieve his historic art installation at the Dead Sea. Your participation resulted in many key accomplishments:


Spencer Tunick created some of his best work of art in Israel


The world media took notice and over 500 million people saw a new positive image of Israel and learnt about the environmental issues of the Dead Sea


Spencer gave amazing quotes to the press reinforcing his love for Israel, the Israeli people, and the environment


We succeeded in elevating the Dead Sea to the Final 10 list in the New 7 Wonders of the World Competition


The religious parties in Kneset led by Shas and Bayit Heyehudi failed in their attempt to suppress Freedom of Speech in Israel and to block our art installation

Unfortunately the battle is not yet over and the Dead Sea is still in danger. 
It is for these reasons that Spencer Tunick has decided to return to Israel and to the Dead Sea. He is partnering with the grassroots organization "Save Our Sea" www.saveoursea.org.il who is focused on the unique medical/healing properties of the Dead Sea that people from all over the world depend on.  Each year they hold an annual Dead Sea Float to raise international awareness.  This year they have decided to hold their event around the same time of the 1 year anniversary of our installation. Spencer is coming to Israel for this event and we would like you to join him !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 
Our proposed agenda is (which is still subject to change):


Buses leave Tel Aviv around 12am on Friday morning to arrive at the Dead Sea by 3am


From 3-5am we'll gather on the beach for a jam session with accoustic music (bring your guitars and drums to join in).  


From 5am – 6am we will have our opening ceremony along with enviromental activists who will share their opinions about the dead sea and its future 


From 6am – 7am Spencer Tunick will invite everyone into the water to float together


From 7am -9am \With Spencer's guidence, photographers will take pictures of the participants – both individually and collectively


10am – The buses will return to Tel Aviv and elsewhere


Please note that this is not a nude event

To learn more about our work with Spencer Tunick & the Dead Sea visit:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uA0vv5HlLtY

https://www.facebook.com/events/476815572334048/
Some recent press about this can be seen at:

http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4262189,00.html 
http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-07-30/spencer-tunick-to-join-mass-floating-event-to-save-dead-sea
http://www.greenprophet.com/2012/08/spencer-tunick-naked-dead-sea/
Please help us by joining the float in body and/or spirit. We would like to bring thousands of people to the Dead Sea and need your active participation. Please help spread the word. This is not a nude event - we expect people to wear clothes - but clothing is optional. 
Sincerely,
Shlomit Yarkoni & Ari Fruchter: Naked Sea www.nakedsea.info
Jon Sekular: Save Our Sea www.saveoursea.org.il
 
P.S. You can also take a look at our Kickstarter campaign from last year which raised $116K and helped fund the project. The work by Shlomit and me is voluntary and all funds raised are used to pay for direct costs associated with production.  Spencer Tunick is an invited guest to Israel and is not involved nor responsible for the production of this event.

http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/nakedsea/naked-sea-spencer-tunick-dead-sea-installation 

http://www.spencertunick.com/

story:
PROJECT MISSION

We want to make an album of the most soulful Christmas carols, sung entirely by whales.

Some of us love the winter holidays, but for many it has lost its magic and much of the sacredness, warmth and connection seem to have been replaced by commercial jingles and the frenzy of shopping.

Using our species’ fascination and affinity for whales, we are creating a unique and personal connection to the grace and wonder of the season. And perhaps even a new joy that we had not experienced before.

 

PROJECT DESCRIPTION

Whale Christmas is a completely original album of traditional Christmas songs that connects listeners to the deep spirituality of the holiday while encouraging a direct experience of the sacredness of nature.

A variety of natural whale voices will be used to create a new kind of holiday carol. These songs will be orchestrated to a tempo reflecting the natural speed and rhythm of whale sounds in the wild. Only songs of an inherent soulful nature (such as Silent Night) will be used for the project (Jingle Bells will not be included).

 

BENEFIT TO OCEANS

Whale Christmas is partnering with BLUEMIND—a non-profit project that works with scientists to research and foster our species’ innate love for—and significant benefit from—direct experience of oceans.

Our goal is to fund BlueMind's major initiatives in 2012-13, especially their annual oceanographer/neuroscientist conference and the world's first study on the benefit of whale song on the human brain.

 

With gratitude,

Harold and Jessica.

story:
Short Summary

We’re a team from Minnesota and Uganda on a mission to deliver sustainability.

In Uganda, ninety percent of people cook food using charcoal, creating an industry that fuels deforestation. Uganda relies on its lush forests for wildlife habitats, tourism, and critical ecosystem services, so this destruction is unsustainable. Innovators in Kampala have created a viable alternative fuel - briquettes made from organic waste rather than living plants -  but have failed to revolutionize the market.

Kaloli Energy pairs home delivery of waste-based briquettes with the social value of trash collection, a service that 60% of Kampalans lack. For the same price as buying a week’s supply of charcoal at a marketplace, Kaloli’s employees deliver it right to a customer's door. In the same trip, we collect their trash for deposit in a local landfill rather than clogging sewers or being burnt in backyards!

If this business succeeds, it will clean the air and increase sustainability in a city of 1.9 million, while creating dozens or hundreds of jobs for locals.

We spent May to August 2017 in Kampala testing our assumptions, building local connections, and establishing a pilot version of the project. We've found subscribers and customers, and as we've gotten to know our customers, we've learned that we need to change the ways we deliver fuel to match local culture.

That’s where you come in.

The money we raise in this campaign will go towards paying salaries and buying supplies to keep Kaloli operating until we can hit our goal of 120 regular subscribers. With it, we’ll be able to run the business for three months longer, and buy tons more of sustainable charcoal (literally). Help us spark the growth of Kaloli and help with Kampalas journey down the path to a greener future.

What We Need

Kaloli has accomplished two months of market research and an additional two months of piloting our business with the $6000 we earned as grand-prize winners of the University of Minnesota's BizPitch and Acara Challenge startup competitions.

Now that we have supplies and premises, the money we earn in this campaign will keep us afloat through three additional months of business pivots and development. Your gift will extend the time we have to test the following core strategies:

  1. Adapting our subscription model. Subscription services don't match Kampalans' cultural norms, so we'll realign our business to sell single-serving bags of waste-based briquettes.
  2. Moving to a new neighborhood. We established our business in a lower-income neighborhood than our original target, so we will research whether a different region of the city might be more amenable to our model.
  3. Changing the way we market subscriptions. Subscriptions don't match Kampalans' expectations, but are a great way for customers to save money. Doing more market research will help us understand how best to approach this topic.
  4. Focus on briquette delivery. Market tests show that some people are content with their current trash management. While we will continue to offer waste collection, we hope to focus even more on how to improve our delivery and become more well known in the community.

Every dollar spent will go towards delivering your perk and developing Kaloli Energy - the co-founders will earn nothing from this campaign. Any gift you give helps us pay Lydia and Ivan, our employees in Kampala, buy waste-based briquettes, and keep our delivery motorcycle on the road. 

What You Get

For $5, we will give you a shout-out on our Facebook page, along with the chance to see the co-founders pied in the face! For every $100 raised under a co-founder’s name, they will be hit in the face with a whipped-cream pie! The co-founder with the largest total money donated will be pied in the face once for every $50 raised. We'll record a video and post it to the Kaloli Facebook page.
Stretch Goal! If these perks raise a combined $500, Kaloli will publicly host this event on the University of Minnesota campus!! 

For $10, you can own a Kaloli-branded laptop sticker, printed by our friends at Print Magic in Kampala! Stickers are approximately 8" x 4" (20cm x 10cm) and feature our Kaloli logo. Fun fact: these are the same stickers we used to brand our briquette buckets!

For $15, you will receive a hand-written thank you note from the co-founders in gratitude of your support!

For $25, you can receive a stylish Kaloli-branded t-shirt (sizes small through large)to up your fashion game in the fall and throughout the year. Lydia, one of our employees, is modeling the shirts in the photo below.

For a $50 gift, Kaloli will give an eco-stove to a family in Kampala. Eco-stoves cook more efficiently-- utilizing less fuel and keeping the air cleaner. This stove will be used by the family for many years to cook meals in their homes and leave a smaller impact on the environment. We will also send you a personal thank-you card for your support.

Also at the $50 level is a chance to grab coffee with two Kaloli co-founders! We'll buy you coffee at your choice of cafe in the Twin Cities area to discuss Kaloli, Kampala, and learn from your insights.

For $500 total, we will barbecue for you! We will bring our own Kampalan cookstove to your home to prepare the Kampalan dish, rolex-- a traditional food made with chapati (a type of flatbread), eggs, and vegetables. We will also be offering traditional Minnesotan cookout food as we describe our time in Kampala and discuss our plans for next steps.

The Impact

Kaloli wants to make alternative energy so convenient that it becomes the obvious choice. Your gift will support the briquette innovators fighting to decrease the deforestation of Uganda driven by the charcoal industry. When we reach 200 customers, we will be saving 50 tons of trees per month, and in a city of 1.9 million the sky is the limit.

Kaloli also provides employment to Ugandans. As a sustainable business, we provide stable, well-paid jobs to our employees, who in turn provide us with critical perspectives of how others might perceive our project.

Risks & Challenges

We believe in the Kaloli business model, but we know that we need more customer interaction to determine whether the idea will sink or swim long-term. Doing a pilot of a company is all about hypothesis-testing, which means that no matter how hard we try there’s a chance Kaloli will not appeal to the people of Kampala.

Our backgrounds qualify us to explore these questions thoroughly, and search diligently for solutions. 

  • Maggie Kristian's background in environmental studies and management has trained her to analyze the impact of our solution. Her three months of dedicated business development on-site in Kampala, shows that she has the perseverance to see the project to its conclusion, and the adaptability to keep looking for new solutions.
  • Peder Garnaas-Halvorson's graduate studies in environmental policy complement his experience running a nonprofit in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. His insights about how to handle cultural differences, or negotiate better paths to a solution, have been invaluable.
  • Ben Ihde has been on the team of four startups including Kaloli, and uses that leadership and business experience to improve communication  within the team,  and connect to the local innovator community.
  • Claire Irwin brings a business background to the team thanks to her studies in finance and international business. As a source of novel business strategies and connections to mentors within the University, she also helps us keep our books balanced.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like the idea, but don’t have money to give right now, pass this page along to a friend, relative, or community that might be able to help us out. Here’s the link to help you out (IndieGoGo website link).

Educate yourself about about the problems caused by charcoal:

  • Black Star News breaks down why the problem persists at an individual level.
  • The UN Development Project breaks down the macroscopic issues caused by charcoal, and details its high-level plan of how to address the issue.

Thanks for all your help!

Claire Irwin brings a business background to the team thanks to her studies in finance and international business. As a source of novel business strategies and connections to mentors within the University, she also helps us keep our books balanced.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you like the idea, but don’t have money to give right now, pass this page along to a friend, relative, or community that might be able to help us out. Here’s the link to help you out (IndieGoGo website link).
Educate yourself about about the problems caused by charcoal:

Black Star News breaks down why the problem persists at an individual level.
The UN Development Project breaks down the macroscopic issues caused by charcoal, and details its high-level plan of how to address the issue.
Thanks for all your help!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
During the 1980s, a "mysterious group" took to sabotaging ski resorts and nuclear power developments that were threatening grounds held sacred by American Indian nations of the Grand Canyon region. 

The group, a predecessor to the Earth Liberation Front, was known as the Evan Mecham Eco Terrorist International Conspiracy (EMETIC) and caught newspaper headlines across the southwest as the power lines and ski lifts toppled.

As a member, Peg Millett was profiled and targeted. Through a program they called THERMCON, the FBI paid agents to use romantic coercion and other methods to entrap EMETIC and the Earth First! organization in a largely manufactured conspiracy to use thermite grenades against nuclear weapons facilities.  She was ultimately sentenced to 3 years in federal prison, but not before two ski lift developments, A nuclear power facility and a uranium mine were sabotaged.

You can help bring Peg and her incredible story of daring clandestine action, deep personal FBI infiltration, surviving prison and lessons learned, along with performing her Earth First! style folk music to Burning Books here in Buffalo!

"As we were talking away, Mark Davis tells me what he wants to do the Snow Bowl ski lift.  I had been dialoging in the Earth First! Journal and talking to people about monkeywrenching.  Is it viable?  Is it effective?...  I went out and did my share of things at night... but just piddily stuff.  He presented to me the opportunity to see if monkeywrenching really was going to work.  So I said, "Okay.  I'm in."

-Peg Millett

story:
We want to support the populations of the Amazon in their struggle to defend the rainforest.  
And we need your support to support them!
In February we are going to Brazil. We will go to the Amazon, to meet cooperatives in several parts of the region, and we will investigate conditions for buying and selling their products - starting with the most important product currently: The Brazil nut.

Do you wanna be part of all this?
You can support us pre-ordering Brazil nuts. You can also choose to get a gift (we don't know yet exactly which kind of gifts we are going to bring from the Amazon – but it will surely be nice...). You get a master shell with stories. You can come to a party. But most importantly, you can tell us it matters.


The packages will be handed over to our supporters at a homecoming party  in Christiania, Copenhagen. Are you not able to come to the party, the package can be sent to you by snail mail (we will charge the cost in addition).

Who are we?
At the moment our initiative counts with two persons:

 Di Ponti, an Indian/Portuguese, lives in the free town of Christiania, Copenhagen. After an academic life and always in the mood for creative endeavors, Di is now turning their attention to social projects and conflict management/restorative circles.

Christian Kaarsberg, a Danish/Brazilian, worked in the 90s with the National Council of Rubber Tapperers in the Northern Amazon. Since then Christian has been working with development projects for different organizations in different parts of South and Central America. Christian has published several books and produced documentaries about Amazon and Brazil.  

The Amazon and deforestations
The Amazon rainforests are threatened by deforestation, with unforeseeable consequences - not only for the local inhabitants themselves: the clearing of the rainforests affects climate and living conditions in large parts of Latin America, and it contributes very likely to global climate changes that are observed in recent years, with serious consequences especially in the poorest areas of the world.
The clearing of the Amazon rainforests during recent years follows a growing interest for the exploitation of forest and subsurface resources in the region. Roadworks open the region for investments in mining, sawmills, cattle and agriculture, and the economic development of the region is increasingly based on activities involving the exploitation of the region's natural resources.
The indigenous peoples of the Amazon and the traditional riverine populations – the socalled “caboclos” - build their lives on the renewable resources of the rainforest - their lives are, in other words, dependent on the preservation of the forest. Therefore deforestation is also threatening the indigenous people's physical and cultural survival.
Conversely the indigenous cultures represent the only known development model, which does not represent a threat to the rainforests. The most promising attempt to formulate strategies for sustainable development in the Amazon region is therefore based on the indigenous people's civilizatory experiences.
As we succeed in developing models for the exploitation of rainforest resources that are economically, socially and ecologically sustainable, so the communities that seek to realize this model will be strengthened.
And then these groups will have a special interest in defending the rainforest against deforestation.
 
Extractive reserves as a model for defending the Amazon
In the 1990s the Brazilian organisation Conselho Nacional dos Seringueiros (The National Counsel of Rubber Gatherers), today called Conselho Nacional das Populações Extrativistas (The National Counsel of Extractive Populations) presented a strategy for the defense of the Amazonian rainforests based on the organization of forest reserves, where deforestation was not allowed, and where the local indigenous and caboclo communities were allowed to explore the regions renewable resources on certain conditions - most importantly, they should present a development plan for their areas, based on the renewable resources of the rain forest.
The strategy elaborated by this organization was accepted by the Brazilian government and turned into official policy for the Amazon region. In the following years socalled "extractive reserves" were established in various parts of the Amazon, creating "bufferzones" in areas with high risk of invasions by cattle ranchers, mining or timber companies, gold prospectors or small farmers.
And the rubber gatherers proved right. With legal rights assuring the forest communities, they organized cooperatives, health clinics and schools in the reserves. And they stood up defending the forest, whenever cattle ranchers or petty peasants in search for cultivable lands tried to establish themselves within the borders of the extractive reserves.

Two different models for the future of the Amazon: Slavery or democracy, landlords or free cooperatives
Until recently the collecting of Brazil nuts and most other products from the rainforest was carried out by slaves – or, formally they were not slaves, but eternal debt to the landlord secured the landlord control over his subjects in a system known as debt bondage – practically a desguised form of slavery.
With the opening of roads through the forests the landlord’s control over his subjects has been weakened – and furthermore, the creation of extractive reserves has created free spaces, where the landlords do not have the power they enjoyed in former years. And where the landlords withdraw from their earlier positions, these are taken over by the newly formed cooperatives in the extractive reserves.
