And where the landlords withdraw from their earlier positions, these are taken over by the newly formed cooperatives in the extractive reserves.

story:
Save historic Long Wharf Park in Boston Harbor!

Long Wharf Park, at the seaward end of historic Long Wharf in Boston Harbor, is threatened with extinction. For four years, we, the North End Ten, have been defending the park against two Goliaths--the Boston Redevelopment Authority (BRA) and the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection (DEP)--who want to turn it into a late-night restaurant and bar.

In 2011, a Superior Court judge agreed with us, ruling that a privatization of public parkland requires a two-thirds vote of the legislature, as mandated by the Massachusetts Constitution. Now the fate of Long Wharf Park is on appeal before the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court. Constitutional rights are upheld, or lost, in court. Fortunately, we have retained the oldest environmental law firm in New England, involved in park protection and litigation for over 35 years. For legal expenses, we need to raise $35,000, and are turning to our strongest supporters and asking for your contribution.

Don't keep your money molding in your wallet! It cannot do more good than in protecting this historic place, a park of quiet and repose at the end of the oldest working wharf in the United States. If the BRA wins, Long Wharf Park will cease to exist, and all parks created under urban renewal will be exempt from constitutional protection. With your contribution, you will know that you are protecting public parkland across the state, in every city with urban renewal powers. You will know that you are holding government accountable to the citizens, so that, as John Adams intended, "it may be a government of laws and not of men."

Frequently Asked Questions

Q. Has the press covered the story?

A. Yes: see http://savelongwharfpark.org

Q. How else can I help?

A. Tell your friends and contacts, including journalists (print, blog, television).

Q. What is special about Long Wharf Park?

Long Wharf Park is at the harbor end of the oldest working wharf in the United States, and is Boston's farthest projection into the harbor. In colonial times, it was the landing site for nearly all British troops that came to Boston, and in March 1776, was their evacuation point.

Q. Who are the North End Ten?

A. We are ten Massachusetts residents connected to Boston's North End neighborhood who oppose the city and state's flipping a historic park in violation of the Massachusetts Constitution. The Ten are professionals and retirees, without any personal interest, and want to retain the park free for public use as the most beautiful and serene spot on the waterfront of a busy city. We have fought for the park without any outside financial support.

Q. How did you fund the legal expenses before?

We are unusual as a citizens' group in having represented ourselves in the administrative and Superior Court proceedings. We stayed up late researching and writing our legal briefs, and investing collectively 2000 hours of sweat equity. However, by appealing to the Supreme Judicial Court, the BRA and DEP have said, "Double or nothing!" To defend our victory in Superior Court, and have the largest chance of protecting Long Wharf Park, it is now time for outside legal help. Even David needed a slingshot.

Q. Who pays the BRA and DEP's legal fees?

A. The DEP is represented by the office of the Massachusetts Attorney General, so the Massachusetts taxpayer is funding their case. The BRA is represented by two to three law partners at an outside law firm; the funds are coming from the BRA's income and assets (which once belonged to the public).

We had filed a freedom of information request asking how much they had spent on legal costs. They mostly refused to give the information, but eventually said that they had spent $67,000 on outside counsel. Although this cost was prior to the Supreme Judicial Court appeal, it seems unrealistically low.

Q. Why shouldn't the park become a late-night restaurant?

A. The park is protected by Article 97 of the amendments to the Massachusetts Constitution, which requires a two-thirds vote of both houses of the legislature before parkland can be converted to other uses. This vote has never happened, and the BRA claims that the vote is not needed. Meanwhile, there are a half-dozen restaurants and bars within a five-minute walk of Long Wharf Park, and nearly 100 restaurants in the nearby North End neighborhood. There is no need for another restaurant and bar.

Q. What is the BRA and DEP's argument?

A. The BRA argues that, because it took the land for urban renewal, it was taken for a public purpose distinct from the environmental protections that are the subject of Article 97. The DEP argues that its license to the BRA does not violate the constitution, because it is not a change of use or a change of control. We disagree with their arguments (as did the Superior Court judge).

If the BRA's view should prevail, the BRA could invoke motherhood, apple pie, and parks to gain support for urban renewal, later flipping the parks when convenient or profitable.

Q. What is the constitutional protection for parkland?

In Massachusetts, public parks, and other natural-resources lands, have had constitutional protection since 1972, when Article 97 was passed by referendum. It requires a two-thirds vote of both houses of the legislature before public parkland can be converted to other uses. This vote, and the public debate it would require, has never happened.

Q. How did the case get to the Supreme Judicial Court?

A. In 2008, in a DEP administrative proceeding, we appealed the DEP's license, and we lost in 2010. In 2010 we sued the BRA and DEP in Superior Court, and we won in 2011. The BRA appealed directly to the Supreme Judicial Court, who will hear oral arguments this fall.

Q. Where can I learn more details, such as the court documents?

A. See http://savelongwharfpark.org/LegalDocuments

Q. Where can I learn more details, such as the court documents?

story:
350 Philly is a group of volunteers working to bring climate justice to our families, our cities, and the planet.  Through grass-roots education, non-violent action, and cross-city, cross-organizational collaboration we are building a vision for the 21st century that nurtures all people. 

What we need and what it will do!

As we plan to mobilize for the People's Climate March and to convene our coalition for Divestment and Reinvestment of the City's funds, your funds will help us:

  1. Book buses for Philadelphians to get to NY on September 21st for the biggest climate march in history.
  2. Print flyers, leaflets, posters. 
  3. Provide food and space for cross-city, cross-organizational meetings. 
  4. Purchase supplies to develop and build awesome creative arts-based displays, installations, and flash mobs!

Impacts

This money allows us to do the hard work of tipping the scales away from climate crisis toward climate balance:
  • Rapid response to emerging climate related events (oil trains!  weather events! marches!).
  • Long-term planning for city-wide change that puts the health and well-being of our families and communities ahead of profits for the fossil fuel industry. 
Risks & Challenges

We know their are big obstacles.  In these hard times, everyone is struggling to make ends-meet and find their way forward through a stagnant economy, and make connections in a culture that divides us.  We believe that by building connections between those ready for change, we can stimulate our economy and move our city into a new era of cooperation, sustainable economics, and a balanced climate. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

    • Get the word out about 350 Philly
    • Come to our meetings! Email 350philadelphia@gmail.com for more information.
    • Get involved with climate justice wherever you are, however you can. 

    It's going to take all of us to turn this ship around!

story:
In September, I will be attempting to complete my first triathlon...

After seeing what was out there I decided to create my own course (inspiration for the course is owed to Megan Taylor, from who I stole the idea). So there you go, a do-it-yourself triathlon: completely un-organized, open to everyone, with no entry fees.

Here is the map of the course:

Try-Athlon (googlemap)

Often races like these raise money for charities, so i've decided to do the same. For every kilometer that I complete  I'm asking people to contribute a little cash.

Because of funding technicalities, all cash raised will go towards my trip to California, but I pledge to give a matching amount + $37.00 to support prop 37 to label Genetically Engineered foods in California. You can get more information here: http://www.carighttoknow.org/

If you are in California and would like to participate, all you have to do is get yourself a little support team and show up at Pillar Point on Saturday September 22nd at 1pm.

Try-Athlon (googlemap)
Often races like these raise money for charities, so i've decided to do the same. For every kilometer that I complete  I'm asking people to contribute a little cash.
Because of funding technicalities, all cash raised will go towards my trip to California, but I pledge to give a matching amount + $37.00 to support prop 37 to label Genetically Engineered foods in California. You can get more information here: http://www.carighttoknow.org/
If you are in California and would like to participate, all you have to do is get yourself a little support team and show up at Pillar Point on Saturday September 22nd at 1pm.

story:
Paraguay Verde: A National Environmental Youth Camp: Empowering Youth Leaders in Environmental Conservation

The Challenge:

Paraguay is a nation rich in environmental resources, notable especially for migratory bird populations, diverse wildlife and some of the last remaining stands of the Upper Paraná Atlantic Forest. Yet much of the country's biodiversity faces many challenges, such as: land-use conversion, over-hunting and grazing, and other environmentally damaging practices. Many Paraguayans recognize these problems and are seeking ways to take action to preserve, replenish, and sustainably manage their country's natural resources.

The Opportunity:

While Paraguay is environmentally rich, its best resource is its people. With over half of the population under the age of 25, Paraguayan youth are shaping the future of their country and its impact on the world. By providing young Paraguayans with the tools and guidance, we can foster a new generation of informed and dedicated young leaders to pioneer and inspire a movement of environmental sustainability and stewardship across the country.

                                   

The Plan:

A Todo Pulmon, Paraguay Respira, a Paraguayan NGO, in partnership with Peace Corps Paraguay will host the third “Paraguay Verde” National Youth Camp in June 2013. A Todo Pulmon, Paraguay Respira works nationally on reforestation projects and the beautification of public spaces, all with the objective of improving the Paraguayan quality of life.  

By bringing together over 100 youth from across the nation, young Paraguayans will have the opportunity to learn more about environmental problems in Paraguay, share ideas and experiences, and collaborate on solutions for their respective communities. The camp provides a national platform for young Paraguayans to discuss local issues and share strategies for solutions in a fun and empowering atmosphere. Youth return to their communities capable of starting or enhancing an environmental youth group and implementing an action plan. Paraguay Verde also provides the opportunity for youth to develop a dialogue on environmental themes, promoting their inclusion in the local and national discourse around Paraguay’s sustainable future.

Successes:

The fantastic successes of the past two Paraguay Verde youth camps, held in February and October of 2012, has led to a network of youth leaders already hard at work across Paraguay.  New environmental youth groups are being formed and many communities are organizing environmental events, such as tree plantings. Over 150 Paraguayan youth attended the past two camps where they strengthened leadership skills, met other young environmental leaders from across the country, learned about global and national environmental issues, and developed action plans to tackle these issues in their own communities.

During the past two camps Paraguayan youth planted over 100 native tree species, participated in youth leadership panels, practiced worm composting, and made eco-bricks, plastic bottles filled with inorganic wastelike plastic bags and Styrofoam, to demonstrate more sustainable and economically beneficial methods of waste and resource management.

After attending a Paraguay Verde camp, one group carried out a campaign to collect 100 kilos of batteries at their schools while educating their peers about the potential contamination caused by disposing the batteries in the nearby wetlands. Another group used the eco-bricks they learned to make during a Paraguay Verde camp to build wall out of eco-bricks outside the community’s health post.

How you can help:

We need your support to put our plan into action! Your contribution will go directly towards funding the third Paraguay Verde camp for the 100 youth expected to come this year. It only takes $75 to sponsor one youth for the duration of the camp, enabling young environmental leaders who may otherwise be unable to attend, to participate in this transformative experience!  The youth themselves will also be contributing to their experience by fundraising locally to cover transportation expenses to the camp.

You can also help us by sharing this campaign on social media and with your family and friends. Thank you for your support and for helping to promote a sustainable future, in Paraguay and beyond.

https://www.facebook.com/atodopulmonparaguay

https://www.facebook.com/ParaguayVerde

 

Paraguay Verde: Fortaleciendo Jóvenes Líderes en la Conservación del Ambiente.

El Desafío:

Paraguay es una nación rica en recursos naturales, por sus poblaciones de mamíferos, reptiles, peces, aves migratorias, más de 710 especies de aves, muchas de ellas endémicas a eco-regiones únicas en el mundo como es el Bosque Atlántico del Alto Paraná (BAAPA). Sin embargo, gran parte de la biodiversidad del país enfrenta muchos desafíos, como son:  cambio de uso de tierra, la caza furtiva, el pastoreo descontrolado y otras prácticas dañinas para el ambiente. Muchos paraguayos reconocen estos problemas y están buscando maneras de tomar acciones para conservar, reponer y gestionar de manera sostenible los recursos naturales de su país.

La Oportunidad:

Mientras que Paraguay es rico en biodiversidad, su mejor recurso es su gente. Más de la mitad de la población paraguaya es menor a 25 años, jóvenes paraguayos están dando forma al futuro de su país y su impacto en el mundo. Al proporcionar a los jóvenes paraguayos  herramientas,  orientaciones y conectarlos en un encuentro nacional al menos una vez al año creando una red donde más de 100 jóvenes tienen los mismas metas y deseos, podemos fomentar una nueva generación de jóvenes líderes informados y dedicados a trabajar juntos y explorar e inspirar un movimiento de sostenibilidad ambiental y la administración sustentable de sus recursos a nivel local, regional y en el futuro de todo un país.

                                  

El Plan:

A Todo Pulmón, Paraguay Respira, una organización que tiene por objetivo reconstruir bosques, mejorar espacios públicos y recuperar la calidad de vida junto con Voluntarios del Cuerpo de Paz Paraguay lanzarán el tercer Campamento “Paraguay Verde” en junio de 2013, un evento nacional que apunta a reunir y conectar a los jóvenes paraguayos que están  involucrados en el desarrollo sustentable de sus comunidades.

El evento pretende reunir a 100 jóvenes de todo el país, jóvenes paraguayos que tendrán la oportunidad de aprender más sobre los desafíos ambientales del Paraguay, compartiendo ideas y experiencias, y colaborando con posibles soluciones para sus respectivas comunidades. El campamento proveerá una plataforma nacional para que jóvenes paraguayos puedan dialogar sobre problemas locales y para compartir estrategias de soluciones en un ambiente divertido y participativo. Los jóvenes regresarán a sus comunidades con un plan de acción y capacitados para empezar o fortalecer a un grupo juvenil ambiental e implementar su plan de acción. Paraguay Verde también proporcionará la oportunidad para que los jóvenes puedan desarrollar un diálogo sobre temas ambientales, promocionando la inclusión de los mismos en el discurso local y nacional con respecto a un futuro sustentable en el Paraguay.

Éxitos:

El fantástico éxito de los dos últimos campamentos juveniles de Paraguay Verde, realizados en febrero y octubre de 2012, brindó la oportunidad de formar una red de jóvenes líderes que ya se encuentra trabajando en la promoción de mejor uso de los recursos naturales en el país . Nuevos grupos juveniles ambientales se formaron y muchas comunidades ya han organizado eventos ambientales, como la plantación de árboles en su comunidad y comunidades vecinas. Más de 150 jóvenes paraguayos participaron en los últimos 2 campamentos en los cuales tuvieron la oportunidad de fortalecer sus habilidades de liderazgo, conocer a otros jóvenes líderes ambientalistas de todo el país, aprender sobre asuntos ambientales a nivel global y nacional y desarrollar planes de acción para trabajar a favor del ambiente en sus comunidades.

Durante los dos últimos campamentos, jóvenes paraguayos plantaron más de 100 árboles de especies nativas, participaron en paneles de jóvenes líderes, practicaron lombricultura, y prepararon eco-ladrillos, botellas de plástico cargadas con residuos inorgánicos como bolsas de plástico e isopor, a fin de demostrar métodos más sostenibles y económicamente beneficiosos con respecto al manejo de residuos.

Después de asistir en el campamento de Paraguay Verde, un grupo organizó una campaña de recolección de pilas en sus escuelas, mientras educaban a sus pares sobre la contaminación potencial causada por desechar las pilas cerca de los humedales, logrando juntar 100 kilos de pilas en la comunidad. Otro grupo utilizó eco-ladrillos que aprendieron hacer durante el campamento Paraguay Verde para construir un muro de eco-ladrillos fuera del Puesto de Salud de la comunidad.

Otros de los logros incluyen:

  • La página de Facebook Paraguay Verde, como espacio para compartir proyectos, lecciones aprendidas y dialogar sobre estrategias locales.
  • El apoyo de la Entidad Binacional Yacyreta (EBY), en el último campamento
  • Varias empresas paraguayas han contribuido para cubrir la logística
  • La Secretaría de Turismo de Paraguay ha apoyado fuertemente las ediciones anteriores.   

Cómo nos puedes ayudar, Una forma innovadora y donde todos podemos ser parte:

Todos podemos y debemos contribuir! Una forma es a través del apoyo financiero. ¡Necesitamos de tu apoyo para concretar en junio de 2013 la participación de 100 jóvenes. Ayúdanos con tu donación haciendo posible la participación de jóvenes paraguayos.

Tú también nos puedes ayudar compartiendo esta campaña con tu familia y amigos en las redes sociales. Gracias por tu apoyo y por ayudarnos a promover un futuro sostenible en Paraguay y más allá.

 

https://www.facebook.com/atodopulmonparaguay

https://www.facebook.com/ParaguayVerde

story:
Jake is an artist who travels to conventions to display his art and Sara is an archaeologist who follows projects and contractors state-to-state. We are marrying on October 4th, and are building a Micro-Home. This sustainable, portable house will minimize our impact on the environment and allow us greater flexibility for both our professions. 

What Does Building a Tiny Home Require?

Sara has a good background in simple construction, and both of us have great resources in the form of relatives and friends who are dedicating time and brainpower to help with any kinks. 

Our first big purchase is our base -- a 24' flatbed trailer, but the majority of our funding will go toward building supplies. We have a detailed budget and have pegged the building costs to be just over $12,000. Where possible, we are using reclaimed and salvaged materials to help lower costs, but sustainability isn't cheap.
Our goal is to get as close to a zero-carbon footprint as possible. To maximize our energy efficiency we are using high performance insulation which will minimize our heating requirements. We are hoping to install photovoltaics to help with (or eliminate!) energy costs. We have a great friend who has made a career out of sustainability and off-grid living who will help us perfect these details. 

We have done a lot of research into the growing field of tiny homes. Our initial design (and inspiration) was based on Molecule Tiny Homes and Tumbleweed Tiny House Company though we are modifying materials and plans to decrease weight, increase stability and personalize the space.
Other great resources regarding the actual construction are Build A Tiny House and the Facebook-page blog, Ben Builds A Tiny House. 
Why Build A Micro-Home?
Reducing human impact on the environment is incredibly important. Building a tiny house is a fantastic way to commit to sustainable and minimalist living -- and what better time than when we're first starting out?
Housing costs are increasing and many families struggle with mortgages and debt. Our choice to live small gives us financial flexibility and incredible freedom.
What Are Some Challenges With Building?
Any building project has its fair share of potential risks. Luckily, we have several detailed floor-plans should issues arise with the design, and there are many options for building materials. Any contributions to the project will be invested in maximizing our energy efficiency. 
How Can I Help?
We need financial contributions, but that isn't all you can do to help us. Donations of time and materials are greatly appreciated too! Share our story and help get word out to those who would be interested!

    Thank you for helping us follow our dreams!

story:
Back To Basics
There isn't much meaning behind buying something in the store. People today are realizing that handmade products and food raised on small organic farms enriches your life in a way store bought never could. That used to be the norm. There was a time when all food was organic. Nature's natural course was understood and respected. Everything we spent our hard earned money on was handmade and helped support the person who's skill and effort went in to making it. That's what we want to do. We are leaving the city to go back to a more natural way of life. While at the same time sharing with others what we learn.
This summer we are cutting our ties to the conviences of modern life. Trading it all in for the satisfaction that comes from doing things yourself. We will build our own small home, raise animals, grow food, and homeschool. Making the most of our resources to produce what we need and also sharing them with others. We will share our experiences along the way so you can learn from our mistakes and successes.

How Will These Funds Be Used?

A down payment on land is our biggest obstacle! We would like to make as large a down payment as we can. We are hoping to put down $10,000. Any funds we are lucky enough to recieve past that will be put towards building expenses. We plan on building an earthbag house with papercrete inside and out. The cost for this project will be about $10,000 (3K for bags, barbed wire, & sand. 2K for roof. About 2K for papercrete plus other fixtures and expenses).We will be living in a temporary stucture until the completion. After that our main conserns will be clearing land to establish the chickens, rabbits, and goats. Now, don't get us wrong, we aren't waiting for help before we do this! At the end of June we are on our way. We work and are selling everything we own to make this happen. We just thought we would put this out in the universe. 
We are excited to show our gratitude for your support by offering perks that we make our selves on our homestead! 
  • All natural soaps and body products
  • Herbs
  • Pottery
  • Animal products (feathers for crafts, pelts, etc.)
  • Artwork
  • Wooden goods
  • More

Risks & Challenges

Yes! This is going to take a lot of work. Things always take longer than you think to get finished. There will be road blocks and unforeseen obstacles. We are going to push though them all while sharing with you our progress. We have a YouTube channel ( go to homestead MO on YouTube or  use this link          https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCFzrVUCvP1wTJl...) so you can see everything develop. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to make a donation, we would also appreciate help getting the word out!

  • Share our campaign on social media
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Facebook Event Here

Français

Castellano

The pirates of the Junk Raft Armada, need  your help to raise awareness of the unacceptable amount of waste our society generates, and how much of it is ending up in our rivers. 

The crew, consisting of an international mix of builders, activists and performers from as far as New Zealand and South Africa, have come together in Calafou in Spain. Our goal is to build a fleet of rafts, made mostly from things scavenged from the streets of Barcelona, and to sail them down the Rio Ebro. Along the way we plan to stage performances and spread awareness of how easily things get discarded, how objects that people consider junk can be repurposed and the critical level of pollution in our waterways and oceans. 

Once our fleet is completed we will navigate from Tudela all the way to Caspe, from the 20th of July to the 20th of August.

 

Your contribution will help us spread these urgent messages :

We live in a society that generally disregards the planet we inhabit. Our planet’s oceans are one of humanity’s most important natural resources. In recent times we have begun to push the limits of the oceans and we must start utilizing them in a more sustainable way.

There are various sources of pollution to the ocean –acidification, eutrophication, toxin run offs underwater noise and many to advocate but none are more prominent and threatening than plastic debris.

 

Every year, 300 million tonnes of plastic is produced. ½ of which is used once and thrown away and 14 billion pounds are dumped into the ocean.

The consequences are as widespread as the problem is complex. And the problem is not limited to the ocean.

We are destroying our most important resources.

We need to urgently alert people.

We need to work with the planet that sustains us, to stop wasting water, to reconsider the rate at which we consume and discard the amount of trash we are producing. We want to share the upcycling methods and solutions to the end this disaster.

In short, we want to help to keep our livelyhood running.

We are on-site now, working around the clock to ensure that this project is a success. We need your help to raise funds for the things we would rather not pick out of a dumpster,  essential safety equipment (life vests, radios, fire extinguishers...) We also prefer to use new fixings on the rafts (screws and bolts, ropes, as well as welding and drill bits – see a video of Ants trying to straighten an old nail, here.)

And then there is Mohamed, the beloved but not to be trusted old Mercedes van, who enjoys drinking way too much expensive fuels and uses only imported parts from Germany. We need him fixed up to transport all found materials to the build site and soon we need to get our rafts to the river!                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         

For all the donations we receive, we will send you presents! Fancy some limited edition Junk Raft Armada swag - we have screen-print patches, button badges, junk crafts and hand-made bunting flags!

 

 

You can also help us by taking a look at our website to see how else you can help (know someone along the Ebro that will let us shower in their garden!?) and what we desperately  need (maybe you live in Barcelona and can donate a barrel or a few suit jackets for our costumes...)

Share our links with your friends and family because the eco-pirates of the Junk Raft Armada can only set sail with contributions from landlubbers like you!  If you would like to participate in the build, you are a fire performer or experienced sailor interested in the voyage, or if you are an artist that would like to assist in the junk-crafting as incentives for donations, please contact junkarmada@gmail.com.   Those who can't donate can always help by spreading this page to all your awesome friends. 

Follow us on Junk Raft Armada, You Tube, Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr.

 

Thanks so much xx
